<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-72"><a href="#Taxis,_vehicles_for_hire,_and_trams"><span class="tocnumber">11.4</span> <span class="toctext">Taxis, vehicles for hire, and trams</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-73"><a href="#Streets_and_highways"><span class="tocnumber">11.5</span> <span class="toctext">Streets and highways</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-74"><a href="#River_crossings"><span class="tocnumber">11.5.1</span> <span class="toctext">River crossings</span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-75"><a href="#Cycling_network"><span class="tocnumber">11.6</span> <span class="toctext">Cycling network</span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-76"><a href="#People"><span class="tocnumber">12</span> <span class="toctext">People</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-77"><a href="#Global_outreach"><span class="tocnumber">13</span> <span class="toctext">Global outreach</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-78"><a href="#See_also"><span class="tocnumber">14</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-79"><a href="#Notes"><span class="tocnumber">15</span> <span class="toctext">Notes</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-80"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">16</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-81"><a href="#Further_reading"><span class="tocnumber">17</span> <span class="toctext">Further reading</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-82"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">18</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<p>In 1664, the city was named in honor of the <a href="/wiki/Duke_of_York" title="Duke of York">Duke of York</a>, who would become King <a href="/wiki/James_II_of_England" title="James II of England">James II of England</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup> James's elder brother, King <a href="/wiki/Charles_II_of_England" title="Charles II of England">Charles II</a>, appointed the Duke <a href="/wiki/Proprietary_colony" title="Proprietary colony">proprietor</a> of the former territory of <a href="/wiki/New_Netherland" title="New Netherland">New Netherland</a>, including the city of <a href="/wiki/New_Amsterdam" title="New Amsterdam">New Amsterdam</a>, when England seized it from <a href="/wiki/Dutch_people" title="Dutch people">Dutch</a> control.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Archdeacon2013a_44-0"><a href="#cite_note-Archdeacon2013a-44">[44]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_New_York_City" title="History of New York City">History of New York City</a> and <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_New_York_City" title="Timeline of New York City">Timeline of New York City</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_history">Early history</span></h3>
<p>In the <a href="/wiki/Pre-Columbian_era" title="Pre-Columbian era">pre-Columbian era</a>, the area of present-day New York City was inhabited by <a href="/wiki/Algonquian_peoples" title="Algonquian peoples">Algonquian</a> Native Americans, including the <a href="/wiki/Lenape" title="Lenape">Lenape</a>. Their homeland, known as <a href="/wiki/Lenapehoking" title="Lenapehoking">Lenapehoking</a>, included <a href="/wiki/Staten_Island" title="Staten Island">Staten Island</a>, Manhattan, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bronx" title="Bronx">Bronx</a>, the western portion of <a href="/wiki/Long_Island" title="Long Island">Long Island</a> (including the areas that would later become the <a href="/wiki/Boroughs_of_New_York_City" title="Boroughs of New York City">boroughs</a> of <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn" title="Brooklyn">Brooklyn</a> and <a href="/wiki/Queens" title="Queens">Queens</a>), and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lower_Hudson_Valley" title="Lower Hudson Valley">Lower Hudson Valley</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup>
</p><p>The first documented visit into <a href="/wiki/New_York_Harbor" title="New York Harbor">New York Harbor</a> by a European was in 1524 by <a href="/wiki/Italians" title="Italians">Italian</a> <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_da_Verrazzano" title="Giovanni da Verrazzano">Giovanni da Verrazzano</a>, an explorer from <a href="/wiki/Florence" title="Florence">Florence</a> in the service of the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_France" title="Kingdom of France">French crown</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Debo2013_46-0"><a href="#cite_note-Debo2013-46">[46]</a></sup> He claimed the area for France and named it <i>Nouvelle Angoulême</i> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_Angoul%C3%AAme" title="New Angoulême">New Angoulême</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rodgers_47-0"><a href="#cite_note-rodgers-47">[47]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">Spanish</a> expedition, led by the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_people" title="Portuguese people">Portuguese</a> captain <a href="/wiki/Est%C3%AAv%C3%A3o_Gomes" title="Estêvão Gomes">Estêvão Gomes</a> sailing for <a href="/wiki/Charles_V,_Holy_Roman_Emperor" title="Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor">Emperor Charles V</a>, arrived in <a href="/wiki/New_York_Harbor" title="New York Harbor">New York Harbor</a> in January 1525 and charted the mouth of the <a href="/wiki/Hudson_River" title="Hudson River">Hudson River</a>, which he named <span title="Spanish-language text"><i lang="es">Río de San Antonio</i></span> ('Saint Anthony's River'). The <a href="/wiki/Padr%C3%B3n_Real" title="Padrón Real">Padrón Real</a> of 1527, the first scientific map to show the <a href="/wiki/East_Coast_of_the_United_States" title="East Coast of the United States">East Coast of North America</a> continuously, was informed by Gomes' expedition and labeled the <a href="/wiki/Northeastern_United_States" title="Northeastern United States">northeastern United States</a> as <i>Tierra de Esteban Gómez</i> in his honor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1609, the English explorer <a href="/wiki/Henry_Hudson" title="Henry Hudson">Henry Hudson</a> rediscovered New York Harbor while searching for the <a href="/wiki/Northwest_Passage" title="Northwest Passage">Northwest Passage</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Orient" title="Orient">Orient</a> for the <a href="/wiki/Dutch_East_India_Company" title="Dutch East India Company">Dutch East India Company</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lankevich2002_49-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lankevich2002-49">[49]</a></sup> He proceeded to sail up what the Dutch would name the <a href="/wiki/North_River_(Hudson_River)" title="North River (Hudson River)">North River</a> (now the Hudson River), named first by Hudson as the <i>Mauritius</i> after <a href="/wiki/Maurice,_Prince_of_Orange" title="Maurice, Prince of Orange">Maurice, Prince of Orange</a>. Hudson's first mate described the harbor as "a very good Harbour for all windes" and the river as "a mile broad" and "full of fish".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hudsonnni_50-0"><a href="#cite_note-hudsonnni-50">[50]</a></sup> Hudson sailed roughly 150 miles (240 km) north,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup> past the site of the present-day New York State <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_U.S._state_capitals" title="List of U.S. state capitals">capital city</a> of <a href="/wiki/Albany,_New_York" title="Albany, New York">Albany</a>, in the belief that it might be an oceanic <a href="/wiki/Tributary" title="Tributary">tributary</a> before the river became too shallow to continue.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hudsonnni_50-1"><a href="#cite_note-hudsonnni-50">[50]</a></sup> He made a ten-day exploration of the area and claimed the region for the Dutch East India Company. In 1614, the area between <a href="/wiki/Cape_Cod" title="Cape Cod">Cape Cod</a> and <a href="/wiki/Delaware_Bay" title="Delaware Bay">Delaware Bay</a> was claimed by the Netherlands and called <span title="Dutch-language text"><i lang="nl">Nieuw-Nederland</i></span> ('<a href="/wiki/New_Netherland" title="New Netherland">New Netherland</a>').
</p><p>The first non–Native American inhabitant of what would eventually become New York City was <a href="/wiki/Juan_(Jan)_Rodriguez" title="Juan (Jan) Rodriguez">Juan Rodriguez</a> (<a href="/wiki/Transliteration" title="Transliteration">transliterated</a> to Dutch as <i>Jan Rodrigues</i>), a merchant from <a href="/wiki/Captaincy_General_of_Santo_Domingo" title="Captaincy General of Santo Domingo">Santo Domingo</a>. Born in Santo Domingo of <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_people" title="Portuguese people">Portuguese</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_of_Africa" title="Ethnic groups of Africa">African</a> descent, he arrived in Manhattan during the winter of 1613–14, trapping for pelts and trading with the local population as a representative of the Dutch. <a href="/wiki/Broadway_(Manhattan)" title="Broadway (Manhattan)">Broadway</a>, from 159th Street to 218th Street in <a href="/wiki/Upper_Manhattan" title="Upper Manhattan">Upper Manhattan</a>, is named Juan Rodriguez Way in his honor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Dutch_rule">Dutch rule</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:GezichtOpNieuwAmsterdam.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4964" data-file-width="7276" decoding="async" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/GezichtOpNieuwAmsterdam.jpg/220px-GezichtOpNieuwAmsterdam.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/GezichtOpNieuwAmsterdam.jpg/330px-GezichtOpNieuwAmsterdam.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/GezichtOpNieuwAmsterdam.jpg/440px-GezichtOpNieuwAmsterdam.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:GezichtOpNieuwAmsterdam.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/New_Amsterdam" title="New Amsterdam">New Amsterdam</a>, centered in the eventual <a href="/wiki/Lower_Manhattan" title="Lower Manhattan">Lower Manhattan</a>, in 1664, the year England took control and renamed it "New York"</div></div></div>
<p>A permanent European presence near <a href="/wiki/New_York_Harbor" title="New York Harbor">New York Harbor</a> was established in 1624—making New York the 12th <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_North_American_cities_by_year_of_foundation" title="List of North American cities by year of foundation">oldest continuously occupied</a> European-established settlement in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Continental_United_States" title="Continental United States">continental United States</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup>—with the founding of a Dutch <a href="/wiki/Fur_trade" title="Fur trade">fur trading</a> settlement on <a href="/wiki/Governors_Island" title="Governors Island">Governors Island</a>. In 1625, construction was started on a <a href="/wiki/Citadel" title="Citadel">citadel</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fort_Amsterdam_(New_Amsterdam)" title="Fort Amsterdam (New Amsterdam)">Fort Amsterdam</a>, later called <i>Nieuw Amsterdam</i> (New Amsterdam), on present-day <a href="/wiki/Manhattan" title="Manhattan">Manhattan Island</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tolerance_56-0"><a href="#cite_note-Tolerance-56">[56]</a></sup> The colony of New Amsterdam was centered on what would ultimately be known as <a href="/wiki/Lower_Manhattan" title="Lower Manhattan">Lower Manhattan</a>. It extended from the southern tip of Manhattan to modern day <a href="/wiki/Wall_Street" title="Wall Street">Wall Street</a>, where a 12-foot wooden <a href="/wiki/Stockade" title="Stockade">stockade</a> was built in 1653 to protect against Native American and British raids.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup> In 1626, the Dutch colonial Director-General <a href="/wiki/Peter_Minuit" title="Peter Minuit">Peter Minuit</a>, acting as charged by the <a href="/wiki/Dutch_West_India_Company" title="Dutch West India Company">Dutch West India Company</a>, purchased the island of Manhattan from the <i>Canarsie</i>, a small Lenape band,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup> for "the value of 60 <a href="/wiki/Dutch_guilder" title="Dutch guilder">guilders</a>"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup> (about $900 in 2018).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup> A disproved legend claims that Manhattan was purchased for $24 worth of glass beads.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following the purchase, New Amsterdam grew slowly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-npsnetherland_20-1"><a href="#cite_note-npsnetherland-20">[20]</a></sup> To attract settlers, the Dutch instituted the <a href="/wiki/Patroon" title="Patroon">patroon system</a> in 1628, whereby wealthy Dutchmen (<i>patroons</i>, or patrons) who brought 50 colonists to New Netherland would be awarded swaths of land, along with local political autonomy and rights to participate in the lucrative fur trade. This program had little success.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-locnetherland_63-0"><a href="#cite_note-locnetherland-63">[63]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since 1621, the Dutch West India Company had operated as a <a href="/wiki/Monopoly" title="Monopoly">monopoly</a> in New Netherland, on authority granted by the <a href="/wiki/States_General_of_the_Netherlands" title="States General of the Netherlands">Dutch States General</a>. In 1639–1640, in an effort to bolster economic growth, the Dutch West India Company relinquished its monopoly over the fur trade, leading to growth in the production and trade of food, timber, tobacco, and slaves (particularly with the <a href="/wiki/Netherlands_Antilles" title="Netherlands Antilles">Dutch West Indies</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-npsnetherland_20-2"><a href="#cite_note-npsnetherland-20">[20]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nahcnetherland_64-0"><a href="#cite_note-nahcnetherland-64">[64]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1647, <a href="/wiki/Peter_Stuyvesant" title="Peter Stuyvesant">Peter Stuyvesant</a> began his tenure as the last <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Director-General_of_New_Amsterdam" title="Director-General of New Amsterdam">Director-General</a> of New Netherland. During his tenure, the population of New Netherland grew from 2,000 to 8,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup> Stuyvesant has been credited with improving law and order in the colony; however, he also earned a reputation as a <a href="/wiki/Despotism" title="Despotism">despotic</a> leader. He instituted regulations on liquor sales, attempted to assert control over the <a href="/wiki/Dutch_Reformed_Church" title="Dutch Reformed Church">Dutch Reformed Church</a>, and blocked other religious groups (including <a href="/wiki/Quakers" title="Quakers">Quakers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jews" title="Jews">Jews</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Lutheranism" title="Lutheranism">Lutherans</a>) from establishing houses of worship.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nyhsstuyvesant_67-0"><a href="#cite_note-nyhsstuyvesant-67">[67]</a></sup> The Dutch West India Company would eventually attempt to ease tensions between Stuyvesant and residents of New Amsterdam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nnistuyvesant_68-0"><a href="#cite_note-nnistuyvesant-68">[68]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="English_rule">English rule</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:A_view_of_Fort_George_with_the_city_of_New_York,_from_the_SW.jpg"><img alt="A painting of a ship firing its cannons in a harbor." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="467" data-file-width="709" decoding="async" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/A_view_of_Fort_George_with_the_city_of_New_York%2C_from_the_SW.jpg/220px-A_view_of_Fort_George_with_the_city_of_New_York%2C_from_the_SW.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/A_view_of_Fort_George_with_the_city_of_New_York%2C_from_the_SW.jpg/330px-A_view_of_Fort_George_with_the_city_of_New_York%2C_from_the_SW.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/A_view_of_Fort_George_with_the_city_of_New_York%2C_from_the_SW.jpg/440px-A_view_of_Fort_George_with_the_city_of_New_York%2C_from_the_SW.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:A_view_of_Fort_George_with_the_city_of_New_York,_from_the_SW.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Fort_Amsterdam" title="Fort Amsterdam">Fort George</a> and the City of New York c. 1731. <a href="/wiki/Royal_Navy" title="Royal Navy">Royal Navy</a> <a href="/wiki/Ship_of_the_line" title="Ship of the line">ships of the line</a> are seen guarding what would become <a href="/wiki/New_York_Harbor" title="New York Harbor">New York Harbor</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>In 1664, unable to summon any significant resistance, Stuyvesant surrendered New Amsterdam to English troops, led by Colonel <a href="/wiki/Richard_Nicolls" title="Richard Nicolls">Richard Nicolls</a>, without bloodshed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nyhsstuyvesant_67-1"><a href="#cite_note-nyhsstuyvesant-67">[67]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nnistuyvesant_68-1"><a href="#cite_note-nnistuyvesant-68">[68]</a></sup> The terms of the surrender permitted Dutch residents to remain in the colony and allowed for religious freedom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lehrmanstuyvesant_69-0"><a href="#cite_note-lehrmanstuyvesant-69">[69]</a></sup> In 1667, during negotiations leading to the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Breda_(1667)" title="Treaty of Breda (1667)">Treaty of Breda</a> after the <a href="/wiki/Second_Anglo-Dutch_War" title="Second Anglo-Dutch War">Second Anglo-Dutch War</a>, the Dutch decided to keep the nascent plantation colony of what is now <a href="/wiki/Suriname" title="Suriname">Suriname</a> (on the northern <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South American</a> coast) they had gained from the English; and in return, the English kept <a href="/wiki/New_Amsterdam" title="New Amsterdam">New Amsterdam</a>. The fledgling settlement was promptly renamed "New York" after the <a href="/wiki/James_II_of_England" title="James II of England">Duke of York</a> (the future King James II and VII), who would eventually be deposed in the <a href="/wiki/Glorious_Revolution" title="Glorious Revolution">Glorious Revolution</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup> After the founding, the duke gave part of the colony to proprietors <a href="/wiki/George_Carteret" title="George Carteret">George Carteret</a> and <a href="/wiki/John_Berkeley,_1st_Baron_Berkeley_of_Stratton" title="John Berkeley, 1st Baron Berkeley of Stratton">John Berkeley</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fort_Orange" title="Fort Orange">Fort Orange</a>, 150 miles (240 km) north on the <a href="/wiki/Hudson_River" title="Hudson River">Hudson River</a>, was renamed <a href="/wiki/Albany,_New_York" title="Albany, New York">Albany</a> after James's Scottish title.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup> The transfer was confirmed in 1667 by the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Breda_(1667)" title="Treaty of Breda (1667)">Treaty of Breda</a>, which concluded the <a href="/wiki/Second_Anglo-Dutch_War" title="Second Anglo-Dutch War">Second Anglo-Dutch War</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup>
</p><p>On August 24, 1673, during the <a href="/wiki/Third_Anglo-Dutch_War" title="Third Anglo-Dutch War">Third Anglo-Dutch War</a>, Dutch captain <a href="/wiki/Anthony_Colve" title="Anthony Colve">Anthony Colve</a> seized the colony of New York from the English at the behest of <a href="/wiki/Cornelis_Evertsen_the_Youngest" title="Cornelis Evertsen the Youngest">Cornelis Evertsen the Youngest</a> and rechristened it "New Orange" after <a href="/wiki/William_III_of_England" title="William III of England">William III</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Prince_of_Orange" title="Prince of Orange">Prince of Orange</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Roper2017_73-0"><a href="#cite_note-Roper2017-73">[73]</a></sup> The Dutch would soon return the island to England under the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Westminster_(1674)" title="Treaty of Westminster (1674)">Treaty of Westminster</a> of November 1674.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup>
</p><p>Several intertribal wars among the Native Americans and some <a href="/wiki/Epidemic" title="Epidemic">epidemics</a> brought on by contact with the Europeans caused sizeable population losses for the Lenape between the years 1660 and 1670.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76"><a href="#cite_note-76">[76]</a></sup> By 1700, the Lenape population had diminished to 200.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup> New York experienced several <a href="/wiki/Yellow_fever" title="Yellow fever">yellow fever</a> epidemics in the 18th century, losing ten percent of its population to the disease in 1702 alone.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Province_of_New_York_and_slavery">Province of New York and slavery</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Columbia1790.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="275" data-file-width="500" decoding="async" height="121" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Columbia1790.jpg/220px-Columbia1790.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Columbia1790.jpg/330px-Columbia1790.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Columbia1790.jpg/440px-Columbia1790.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Columbia1790.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Columbia_University" title="Columbia University">Columbia University</a> was founded by royal charter in 1754 under the name of <a href="/wiki/Columbia_College_(New_York)" title="Columbia College (New York)">King's College</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>In the early 18th century, New York grew in importance as a <a href="/wiki/Port" title="Port">trading port</a> while as a part of the <a href="/wiki/Province_of_New_York" title="Province of New York">colony of New York</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Foote2004_80-0"><a href="#cite_note-Foote2004-80">[80]</a></sup> It also became a center of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Slavery_in_the_colonial_United_States" title="Slavery in the colonial United States">slavery</a>, with 42% of households enslaving Africans by 1730, the highest percentage outside <a href="/wiki/Charleston,_South_Carolina" title="Charleston, South Carolina">Charleston</a>, <a href="/wiki/Province_of_South_Carolina" title="Province of South Carolina">South Carolina</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup> Most cases were that of <a href="/wiki/House_slave" title="House slave">domestic slavery</a>, as a New York household then commonly enslaved few or several people. Others were hired out to work at labor. Slavery became integrally tied to New York's economy through the labor of slaves throughout the port, and the banking and shipping industries trading with the <a href="/wiki/Southern_United_States" title="Southern United States">American South</a>. During construction in <a href="/wiki/Foley_Square" title="Foley Square">Foley Square</a> in the 1990s, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/African_Burying_Ground" title="African Burying Ground">African Burying Ground</a> was discovered; the cemetery included 10,000 to 20,000 of graves of colonial-era Africans, some enslaved and some free.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AsanteMazama2005_82-0"><a href="#cite_note-AsanteMazama2005-82">[82]</a></sup>
</p><p>The 1735 trial and acquittal in Manhattan of <a href="/wiki/John_Peter_Zenger" title="John Peter Zenger">John Peter Zenger</a>, who had been accused of <a href="/wiki/Seditious_libel" title="Seditious libel">seditious libel</a> after criticizing colonial governor <a href="/wiki/William_Cosby" title="William Cosby">William Cosby</a>, helped to establish the <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_the_press" title="Freedom of the press">freedom of the press</a> in North America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-zenger_83-0"><a href="#cite_note-zenger-83">[83]</a></sup> In 1754, <a href="/wiki/Columbia_University" title="Columbia University">Columbia University</a> was founded under charter by <a href="/wiki/George_II_of_Great_Britain" title="George II of Great Britain">King George II</a> as King's College in Lower Manhattan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="American_Revolution">American Revolution</span></h3>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Stamp_Act_Congress" title="Stamp Act Congress">Stamp Act Congress</a> met in New York in October 1765, as the <a href="/wiki/Sons_of_Liberty" title="Sons of Liberty">Sons of Liberty</a>, organized in the city, skirmished over the next ten years with British troops stationed there.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BoyerClark2009_85-0"><a href="#cite_note-BoyerClark2009-85">[85]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Long_Island" title="Battle of Long Island">Battle of Long Island</a>, the largest battle of the <a href="/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War" title="American Revolutionary War">American Revolutionary War</a>, was fought in August 1776 within the modern-day borough of Brooklyn.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Reno2008_86-0"><a href="#cite_note-Reno2008-86">[86]</a></sup> After the battle, in which the Americans were defeated, the British made the city their military and political base of operations in North America. The city was a haven for <a href="/wiki/Loyalist_(American_Revolution)" title="Loyalist (American Revolution)">Loyalist</a> refugees and escaped slaves who joined the British lines for freedom newly promised by the Crown for all fighters. As many as 10,000 escaped slaves crowded into the city during the British occupation. When the British forces <a href="/wiki/Evacuation_Day_(New_York)" title="Evacuation Day (New York)">evacuated</a> at the close of the war in 1783, they transported 3,000 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Freedmen" title="Freedmen">freedmen</a> for resettlement in <a href="/wiki/Nova_Scotia" title="Nova Scotia">Nova Scotia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hinks2007_87-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hinks2007-87">[87]</a></sup> They resettled other <a href="/wiki/Freedman" title="Freedman">freedmen</a> in England and the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean" title="Caribbean">Caribbean</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:BattleofLongisland.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2576" data-file-width="3918" decoding="async" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/BattleofLongisland.jpg/220px-BattleofLongisland.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/BattleofLongisland.jpg/330px-BattleofLongisland.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/BattleofLongisland.jpg/440px-BattleofLongisland.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:BattleofLongisland.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Long_Island" title="Battle of Long Island">Battle of Long Island</a>, the largest battle of the <a href="/wiki/American_Revolution" title="American Revolution">American Revolution</a>, took place in <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn" title="Brooklyn">Brooklyn</a> in 1776.</div></div></div>
<p>The only attempt at a peaceful solution to the war took place at the <a href="/wiki/Conference_House" title="Conference House">Conference House</a> on Staten Island between American delegates, including <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Franklin" title="Benjamin Franklin">Benjamin Franklin</a>, and British general <a href="/wiki/Richard_Howe,_1st_Earl_Howe" title="Richard Howe, 1st Earl Howe">Lord Howe</a> on September 11, 1776. Shortly after the British occupation began, the <a href="/wiki/Great_Fire_of_New_York_(1776)" title="Great Fire of New York (1776)">Great Fire of New York</a> occurred, a large conflagration on the <a href="/wiki/West_Side_(Manhattan)" title="West Side (Manhattan)">West Side</a> of Lower Manhattan, which destroyed about a quarter of the buildings in the city, including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trinity_Church_(New_York_City)" title="Trinity Church (New York City)">Trinity Church</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1785, the assembly of the <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_the_Confederation" title="Congress of the Confederation">Congress of the Confederation</a> made New York City the national capital shortly after the war. New York was the last capital of the U.S. under the <a href="/wiki/Articles_of_Confederation" title="Articles of Confederation">Articles of Confederation</a> and the first capital under the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States_Constitution" title="United States Constitution">Constitution of the United States</a>. New York City as the U.S. capital hosted several events of national scope in 1789—the first President of the United States, <a href="/wiki/George_Washington" title="George Washington">George Washington</a>, was inaugurated; the first <a href="/wiki/United_States_Congress" title="United States Congress">United States Congress</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States" title="Supreme Court of the United States">Supreme Court of the United States</a> each assembled for the first time; and the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Bill_of_Rights" title="United States Bill of Rights">United States Bill of Rights</a> was drafted, all at <a href="/wiki/Federal_Hall" title="Federal Hall">Federal Hall</a> on Wall Street.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup> By 1790, New York had surpassed <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia" title="Philadelphia">Philadelphia</a> to become the largest city in the United States, but by the end of that year, pursuant to the <a href="/wiki/Residence_Act" title="Residence Act">Residence Act</a>, the national capital was moved to Philadelphia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-residence_act_90-0"><a href="#cite_note-residence_act-90">[90]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Nineteenth_century">Nineteenth century</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hippolyte_Sebron_-_Rue_De_New-York_En_1840.jpg"><img alt="A painting of a snowy city street with horse-drawn sleds and a 19th-century fire truck under blue sky" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="505" data-file-width="742" decoding="async" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Hippolyte_Sebron_-_Rue_De_New-York_En_1840.jpg/220px-Hippolyte_Sebron_-_Rue_De_New-York_En_1840.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Hippolyte_Sebron_-_Rue_De_New-York_En_1840.jpg/330px-Hippolyte_Sebron_-_Rue_De_New-York_En_1840.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Hippolyte_Sebron_-_Rue_De_New-York_En_1840.jpg/440px-Hippolyte_Sebron_-_Rue_De_New-York_En_1840.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hippolyte_Sebron_-_Rue_De_New-York_En_1840.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Broadway_(Manhattan)" title="Broadway (Manhattan)">Broadway</a> follows the Native American <a href="/wiki/Wecquaesgeek" title="Wecquaesgeek">Wecquaesgeek</a> Trail through Manhattan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup></div></div></div><p>Over the course of the nineteenth century, New York City's population grew from 60,000 to 3.43 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup> Under New York State's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abolition_of_slavery_in_the_United_States" title="Abolition of slavery in the United States">abolition</a> act of 1799, children of slave mothers were to be eventually liberated but to be held in <a href="/wiki/Indentured_servitude" title="Indentured servitude">indentured servitude</a> until their mid-to-late twenties.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup> Together with slaves freed by their masters after the Revolutionary War and escaped slaves, a significant free-Black population gradually developed in Manhattan. Under such influential <a href="/wiki/Founding_Fathers_of_the_United_States" title="Founding Fathers of the United States">United States founders</a> as <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Hamilton" title="Alexander Hamilton">Alexander Hamilton</a> and <a href="/wiki/John_Jay" title="John Jay">John Jay</a>, the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Manumission_Society" title="New York Manumission Society">New York Manumission Society</a> worked for abolition and established the <a href="/wiki/African_Free_School" title="African Free School">African Free School</a> to educate Black children.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Divided_96-0"><a href="#cite_note-Divided-96">[96]</a></sup> It was not until 1827 that slavery was completely abolished in the state, and free Blacks struggled afterward with discrimination. New York interracial abolitionist activism continued; among its leaders were graduates of the African Free School. New York city's population jumped from 123,706 in 1820 to 312,710 by 1840, 16,000 of whom were Black.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 19th century, the city was transformed by both commercial and residential development relating to its status as a national and <a href="/wiki/International_trade" title="International trade">international trading center</a>, as well as by European immigration, respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup> The city adopted the <a href="/wiki/Commissioners%27_Plan_of_1811" title="Commissioners' Plan of 1811">Commissioners' Plan of 1811</a>, which expanded the city <a href="/wiki/Grid_plan#Early_United_States" title="Grid plan">street grid</a> to encompass almost all of Manhattan. The 1825 completion of the <a href="/wiki/Erie_Canal" title="Erie Canal">Erie Canal</a> through <a href="/wiki/Central_New_York" title="Central New York">central New York</a> connected the Atlantic port to the agricultural markets and commodities of the North American interior via the <a href="/wiki/Hudson_River" title="Hudson River">Hudson River</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Great_Lakes" title="Great Lakes">Great Lakes</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup> Local politics became dominated by <a href="/wiki/Tammany_Hall" title="Tammany Hall">Tammany Hall</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Political_machine" title="Political machine">political machine</a> supported by <a href="/wiki/Irish_diaspora" title="Irish diaspora">Irish</a> and <a href="/wiki/German_diaspora" title="German diaspora">German immigrants</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:5_boros_of_NYC_in_1814.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2305" data-file-width="2689" decoding="async" height="189" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/5_boros_of_NYC_in_1814.jpg/220px-5_boros_of_NYC_in_1814.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/5_boros_of_NYC_in_1814.jpg/330px-5_boros_of_NYC_in_1814.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/5_boros_of_NYC_in_1814.jpg/440px-5_boros_of_NYC_in_1814.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:5_boros_of_NYC_in_1814.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The current five boroughs of Greater New York as they appeared in 1814. <a href="/wiki/The_Bronx" title="The Bronx">The Bronx</a> was in Westchester County, Queens County included modern <a href="/wiki/Nassau_County,_New_York" title="Nassau County, New York">Nassau County</a>, Kings County had six towns, one of which was <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn" title="Brooklyn">Brooklyn</a>, and New York City is shown by hatching in southern New York County on the island of <a href="/wiki/Manhattan" title="Manhattan">Manhattan</a>, and Richmond County on <a href="/wiki/Staten_Island" title="Staten Island">Staten Island</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Several prominent American <a href="/wiki/Writer" title="Writer">literary figures</a> lived in New York during the 1830s and 1840s, including <a href="/wiki/William_Cullen_Bryant" title="William Cullen Bryant">William Cullen Bryant</a>, <a href="/wiki/Washington_Irving" title="Washington Irving">Washington Irving</a>, <a href="/wiki/Herman_Melville" title="Herman Melville">Herman Melville</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rufus_Wilmot_Griswold" title="Rufus Wilmot Griswold">Rufus Wilmot Griswold</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Keese" title="John Keese">John Keese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nathaniel_Parker_Willis" title="Nathaniel Parker Willis">Nathaniel Parker Willis</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Edgar_Allan_Poe" title="Edgar Allan Poe">Edgar Allan Poe</a>. Public-minded members of the contemporaneous business elite lobbied for the establishment of <a href="/wiki/Central_Park" title="Central Park">Central Park</a>, which in 1857 became the first <a href="/wiki/Landscape_design" title="Landscape design">landscaped park</a> in an American city.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Great_Famine_(Ireland)" title="Great Famine (Ireland)">Great Irish Famine</a> brought a large influx of Irish immigrants; more than 200,000 were living in New York by 1860, upwards of a quarter of the city's population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup> There was also extensive immigration from the German provinces, where revolutions had disrupted societies, and Germans comprised another 25% of New York's population by 1860.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Harris_103-0"><a href="#cite_note-Harris-103">[103]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)" title="Democratic Party (United States)">Democratic Party</a> candidates were consistently elected to local office, increasing the city's ties to the South and its dominant party. In 1861, Mayor <a href="/wiki/Fernando_Wood" title="Fernando Wood">Fernando Wood</a> called upon the <a href="/wiki/Alderman" title="Alderman">aldermen</a> to declare independence from Albany and the United States after the South seceded, but his proposal was not acted on.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Divided_96-1"><a href="#cite_note-Divided-96">[96]</a></sup> Anger at new <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Military_conscription" title="Military conscription">military conscription</a> laws during the <a href="/wiki/American_Civil_War" title="American Civil War">American Civil War</a> (1861–1865), which spared wealthier men who could afford to pay a $300 (equivalent to $6,602 in 2021) commutation fee to hire a substitute,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup> led to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_York_Draft_Riots" title="New York Draft Riots">Draft Riots of 1863</a>, whose most visible participants were ethnic Irish working class.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Divided_96-2"><a href="#cite_note-Divided-96">[96]</a></sup>
</p><p>The draft riots deteriorated into attacks on New York's elite, followed by attacks on Black New Yorkers and their property after fierce competition for a decade between Irish immigrants and Black people for work. Rioters burned the Colored Orphan Asylum to the ground, with more than 200 children escaping harm due to efforts of the <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Police_Department" title="New York City Police Department">New York Police Department</a>, which was mainly made up of Irish immigrants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Harris_103-1"><a href="#cite_note-Harris-103">[103]</a></sup> At least 120 people were killed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McPherson_105-0"><a href="#cite_note-McPherson-105">[105]</a></sup> Eleven Black men were lynched over five days, and the riots forced hundreds of Blacks to flee the city for <a href="/wiki/Williamsburg,_Brooklyn" title="Williamsburg, Brooklyn">Williamsburg</a>, Brooklyn, and New Jersey. The Black population in Manhattan fell below 10,000 by 1865, which it had last been in 1820. The White working class had established dominance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Harris_103-2"><a href="#cite_note-Harris-103">[103]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McPherson_105-1"><a href="#cite_note-McPherson-105">[105]</a></sup> Violence by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Longshoremen" title="Longshoremen">longshoremen</a> against Black men was especially fierce in the docks area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Harris_103-3"><a href="#cite_note-Harris-103">[103]</a></sup> It was one of the worst incidents of <a href="/wiki/List_of_incidents_of_civil_unrest_in_the_United_States" title="List of incidents of civil unrest in the United States">civil unrest in American history</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Modern_history">Modern history</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Old_timer_structural_worker2.jpg"><img alt="A man working on a steel girder high about a city skyline." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2401" data-file-width="3000" decoding="async" height="176" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Old_timer_structural_worker2.jpg/220px-Old_timer_structural_worker2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Old_timer_structural_worker2.jpg/330px-Old_timer_structural_worker2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Old_timer_structural_worker2.jpg/440px-Old_timer_structural_worker2.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Old_timer_structural_worker2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <a href="/wiki/Construction_worker" title="Construction worker">construction worker</a> atop the <a href="/wiki/Empire_State_Building" title="Empire State Building">Empire State Building</a> as it was being built in 1930. The <a href="/wiki/Chrysler_Building" title="Chrysler Building">Chrysler Building</a> can be seen behind him.</div></div></div>
<p>In 1898, the modern City of New York was formed with the <a href="/wiki/City_of_Greater_New_York" title="City of Greater New York">consolidation</a> of Brooklyn (until then a separate city), the County of New York (which then included parts of the Bronx), the County of Richmond, and the western portion of the County of Queens.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup> The opening of the <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Subway" title="New York City Subway">subway</a> in 1904, first built as separate private systems, helped bind the new city together.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cudahy2004_108-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cudahy2004-108">[108]</a></sup> Throughout the first half of the 20th century, the city became a world center for industry, commerce, and communication.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Blake2009_109-0"><a href="#cite_note-Blake2009-109">[109]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1904, the <a href="/wiki/Steamship" title="Steamship">steamship</a> <i><a href="/wiki/PS_General_Slocum" title="PS General Slocum">General Slocum</a></i> caught fire in the <a href="/wiki/East_River" title="East River">East River</a>, killing 1,021 people on board.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sheard1998_110-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sheard1998-110">[110]</a></sup> In 1911, the <a href="/wiki/Triangle_Shirtwaist_Factory_fire" title="Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire">Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire</a>, the city's worst industrial disaster, took the lives of 146 garment workers and spurred the growth of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_Ladies%27_Garment_Workers%27_Union" title="International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union">International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union</a> and major improvements in factory safety standards.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cornell1_111-0"><a href="#cite_note-cornell1-111">[111]</a></sup>
</p><p>New York's non-White population was 36,620 in 1890.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup> New York City was a prime destination in the early twentieth century for African Americans during the <a href="/wiki/Great_Migration_(African_American)" title="Great Migration (African American)">Great Migration</a> from the American South, and by 1916, New York City had become home to the largest urban <a href="/wiki/African_diaspora" title="African diaspora">African diaspora</a> in North America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GatesHigginbotham2009_113-0"><a href="#cite_note-GatesHigginbotham2009-113">[113]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Harlem_Renaissance" title="Harlem Renaissance">Harlem Renaissance</a> of literary and <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_New_York_City" title="Culture of New York City">cultural life</a> flourished during the era of <a href="/wiki/Prohibition_in_the_United_States" title="Prohibition in the United States">Prohibition</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Roche2015_114-0"><a href="#cite_note-Roche2015-114">[114]</a></sup> The larger economic boom generated construction of skyscrapers competing in height and creating an identifiable <a href="/wiki/Skyline" title="Skyline">skyline</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mulberry_Street_NYC_c1900_LOC_3g04637u_edit.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2067" data-file-width="2800" decoding="async" height="162" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Mulberry_Street_NYC_c1900_LOC_3g04637u_edit.jpg/220px-Mulberry_Street_NYC_c1900_LOC_3g04637u_edit.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Mulberry_Street_NYC_c1900_LOC_3g04637u_edit.jpg/330px-Mulberry_Street_NYC_c1900_LOC_3g04637u_edit.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Mulberry_Street_NYC_c1900_LOC_3g04637u_edit.jpg/440px-Mulberry_Street_NYC_c1900_LOC_3g04637u_edit.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mulberry_Street_NYC_c1900_LOC_3g04637u_edit.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Manhattan's <a href="/wiki/Little_Italy,_Manhattan" title="Little Italy, Manhattan">Little Italy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lower_East_Side" title="Lower East Side">Lower East Side</a>, circa 1900</div></div></div>
<p>New York became the most populous <a href="/wiki/Urban_area#United_States" title="Urban area">urbanized area</a> in the world in the early 1920s, overtaking <a href="/wiki/London" title="London">London</a>. The metropolitan area surpassed the 10 million mark in the early 1930s, becoming the first <a href="/wiki/Megacity" title="Megacity">megacity</a> in human history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup> The difficult years of the <a href="/wiki/Great_Depression" title="Great Depression">Great Depression</a> saw the election of reformer <a href="/wiki/Fiorello_La_Guardia" title="Fiorello La Guardia">Fiorello La Guardia</a> as mayor and the fall of <a href="/wiki/Tammany_Hall" title="Tammany Hall">Tammany Hall</a> after eighty years of political dominance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup>
</p><p>Returning <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a> veterans created a post-war <a href="/wiki/Business_cycle" title="Business cycle">economic boom</a> and the development of large <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Housing_tract" title="Housing tract">housing tracts</a> in eastern Queens and <a href="/wiki/Nassau_County,_New_York" title="Nassau County, New York">Nassau County</a> as well as similar suburban areas in New Jersey. New York emerged from the war unscathed as the leading city of the world, with <a href="/wiki/Wall_Street" title="Wall Street">Wall Street</a> leading America's place as the world's dominant economic power. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_Nations_Headquarters" title="United Nations Headquarters">United Nations Headquarters</a> was completed in 1952, solidifying New York's global <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Geopolitical" title="Geopolitical">geopolitical</a> influence, and the rise of <a href="/wiki/Abstract_expressionism" title="Abstract expressionism">abstract expressionism</a> in the city precipitated New York's displacement of Paris as the center of the art world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Stonewall_Inn_5_pride_weekend_2016.jpg"><img alt="A two-story building with brick on the first floor, with two arched doorways, and gray stucco on the second floor off of which hang numerous rainbow flags." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="4608" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Stonewall_Inn_5_pride_weekend_2016.jpg/220px-Stonewall_Inn_5_pride_weekend_2016.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Stonewall_Inn_5_pride_weekend_2016.jpg/330px-Stonewall_Inn_5_pride_weekend_2016.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Stonewall_Inn_5_pride_weekend_2016.jpg/440px-Stonewall_Inn_5_pride_weekend_2016.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Stonewall_Inn_5_pride_weekend_2016.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Stonewall_Inn" title="Stonewall Inn">Stonewall Inn</a> in <a href="/wiki/Greenwich_Village" title="Greenwich Village">Greenwich Village</a>, a designated U.S. <a href="/wiki/National_Historic_Landmark" title="National Historic Landmark">National Historic Landmark</a> and <a href="/wiki/Stonewall_National_Monument" title="Stonewall National Monument">National Monument</a>, was the site of the June 1969 <a href="/wiki/Stonewall_riots" title="Stonewall riots">Stonewall riots</a> and the cradle of the modern <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gay_rights" title="Gay rights">LGBT+ rights</a> movement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GayGreenwichVillage1_118-0"><a href="#cite_note-GayGreenwichVillage1-118">[118]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Stonewall_riots" title="Stonewall riots">Stonewall riots</a> were a series of spontaneous, violent protests by members of the <a href="/wiki/LGBT_community" title="LGBT community">gay community</a> against a <a href="/wiki/Police_raid" title="Police raid">police raid</a> that took place in the early morning hours of June 28, 1969, at the <a href="/wiki/Stonewall_Inn" title="Stonewall Inn">Stonewall Inn</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Greenwich_Village" title="Greenwich Village">Greenwich Village</a> neighborhood of Lower Manhattan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Murphy2013_121-0"><a href="#cite_note-Murphy2013-121">[121]</a></sup> They are widely considered to constitute the single most important event leading to the <a href="/wiki/Gay_liberation" title="Gay liberation">gay liberation</a> movement<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GayGreenwichVillage1_118-1"><a href="#cite_note-GayGreenwichVillage1-118">[118]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KentuckyStonewall_122-0"><a href="#cite_note-KentuckyStonewall-122">[122]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PinkNewsStonewall_123-0"><a href="#cite_note-PinkNewsStonewall-123">[123]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EncycloStonewall_124-0"><a href="#cite_note-EncycloStonewall-124">[124]</a></sup> and the modern fight for <a href="/wiki/LGBT_rights_by_country_or_territory" title="LGBT rights by country or territory">LGBT rights</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NPSStonewall_125-0"><a href="#cite_note-NPSStonewall-125">[125]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ObamaStonewall_126-0"><a href="#cite_note-ObamaStonewall-126">[126]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Wayne_R._Dynes" title="Wayne R. Dynes">Wayne R. Dynes</a>, author of the <a href="/wiki/Encyclopedia_of_Homosexuality" title="Encyclopedia of Homosexuality">Encyclopedia of Homosexuality</a>, wrote that <a href="/wiki/Drag_queen" title="Drag queen">drag queens</a> were the only "transgender folks around" during the June 1969 Stonewall riots. The <a href="/wiki/Transgender" title="Transgender">transgender</a> community in New York City played a significant role in fighting for <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/LGBT_equality" title="LGBT equality">LGBT equality</a> during the period of the Stonewall riots and thereafter.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TransEqualityNYC_127-0"><a href="#cite_note-TransEqualityNYC-127">[127]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 1970s, job losses due to <a href="/wiki/Deindustrialization" title="Deindustrialization">industrial restructuring</a> caused New York City to suffer from economic problems and rising crime rates.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup> While a resurgence in the financial industry greatly improved the city's economic health in the 1980s, New York's crime rate continued to increase through that decade and into the beginning of the 1990s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129">[129]</a></sup> By the mid 1990s, crime rates started to drop dramatically due to revised police strategies, improving economic opportunities, <a href="/wiki/Gentrification" title="Gentrification">gentrification</a>, and new residents, both American transplants and new immigrants from Asia and Latin America. Important new sectors, such as <a href="/wiki/Silicon_Alley" title="Silicon Alley">Silicon Alley</a>, emerged in the city's economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Waller2013_130-0"><a href="#cite_note-Waller2013-130">[130]</a></sup> New York's population reached all-time highs in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2000_United_States_Census" title="2000 United States Census">2000 census</a> and then again in the 2010 census.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:UA_Flight_175_hits_WTC_south_tower_9-11_edit.jpeg"><img alt="Two tall, gray, rectangular buildings spewing black smoke and flames, particularly from the left of the two." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="926" data-file-width="1062" decoding="async" height="192" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/UA_Flight_175_hits_WTC_south_tower_9-11_edit.jpeg/220px-UA_Flight_175_hits_WTC_south_tower_9-11_edit.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/UA_Flight_175_hits_WTC_south_tower_9-11_edit.jpeg/330px-UA_Flight_175_hits_WTC_south_tower_9-11_edit.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/UA_Flight_175_hits_WTC_south_tower_9-11_edit.jpeg/440px-UA_Flight_175_hits_WTC_south_tower_9-11_edit.jpeg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:UA_Flight_175_hits_WTC_south_tower_9-11_edit.jpeg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/United_Airlines_Flight_175" title="United Airlines Flight 175">United Airlines Flight 175</a> hits the South Tower of the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Center_(1973%E2%80%932001)" title="World Trade Center (1973–2001)">World Trade Center</a> on <a href="/wiki/September_11_attacks" title="September 11 attacks">September 11, 2001</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>New York City suffered the bulk of the economic damage and largest loss of human life in the aftermath of the <a href="/wiki/September_11_attacks" title="September 11 attacks">September 11, 2001, attacks</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dieterle2017_131-0"><a href="#cite_note-Dieterle2017-131">[131]</a></sup> Two of the four airliners hijacked that day were flown into the twin towers of the World Trade Center, destroying the towers and killing 2,192 civilians, 343 firefighters, and 71 law enforcement officers. The North Tower became the tallest building ever to be destroyed anywhere then or subsequently.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Center_site#Planning_for_the_new_World_Trade_Center" title="World Trade Center site">The area was rebuilt</a> with a new <a href="/wiki/One_World_Trade_Center" title="One World Trade Center">One World Trade Center</a>, a <a href="/wiki/National_September_11_Memorial_%26_Museum" title="National September 11 Memorial &amp; Museum">9/11 memorial and museum</a>, and other new buildings and infrastructure.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Greenspan2013_133-0"><a href="#cite_note-Greenspan2013-133">[133]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World_Trade_Center_(PATH_station)" title="World Trade Center (PATH station)">World Trade Center PATH station</a>, which had opened on July 19, 1909, as the Hudson Terminal, was also destroyed in the attacks. A temporary station was built and opened on November 23, 2003. An 800,000-square-foot (74,000 m<sup>2</sup>) permanent rail station designed by <a href="/wiki/Santiago_Calatrava" title="Santiago Calatrava">Santiago Calatrava</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World_Trade_Center_Transportation_Hub" title="World Trade Center Transportation Hub">World Trade Center Transportation Hub</a>, the city's third-largest hub, was completed in 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup> The new One World Trade Center is the tallest skyscraper in the Western Hemisphere<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OneWTCtallest_135-0"><a href="#cite_note-OneWTCtallest-135">[135]</a></sup> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_in_the_world" title="List of tallest buildings in the world">seventh-tallest building in the world</a> by <a href="/wiki/Pinnacle" title="Pinnacle">pinnacle</a> height, with its <a href="/wiki/Spire" title="Spire">spire</a> reaching a symbolic 1,776 feet (541.3 m) in reference to the year of <a href="/wiki/United_States_Declaration_of_Independence" title="United States Declaration of Independence">U.S. independence</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137">[137]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138"><a href="#cite_note-138">[138]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139">[139]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Occupy_Wall_Street" title="Occupy Wall Street">Occupy Wall Street</a> protests in <a href="/wiki/Zuccotti_Park" title="Zuccotti Park">Zuccotti Park</a> in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Financial_District_(Manhattan)" title="Financial District (Manhattan)">Financial District</a> of Lower Manhattan began on September 17, 2011, receiving global attention and popularizing the <a href="/wiki/Occupy_movement" title="Occupy movement">Occupy movement</a> against <a href="/wiki/Social_inequality" title="Social inequality">social</a> and <a href="/wiki/Economic_inequality" title="Economic inequality">economic inequality</a> worldwide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[140]</a></sup>
</p><p>In March 2020, the first case of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Coronavirus_disease_2019" title="Coronavirus disease 2019">COVID-19</a> in the city was confirmed in Manhattan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141"><a href="#cite_note-141">[141]</a></sup> The city rapidly replaced <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wuhan,_China" title="Wuhan, China">Wuhan, China</a> to become the global epicenter of the <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic" title="COVID-19 pandemic">pandemic</a> during the early phase, before the infection became widespread across the world and the rest of the nation. As of March 2021, New York City had recorded <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_New_York_City" title="COVID-19 pandemic in New York City">over 30,000 deaths</a> from COVID-19-related complications. In 2022, the <a href="/wiki/LGBT_culture_in_New_York_City" title="LGBT culture in New York City">LGBT community in New York City</a> became the epicenter of the <a href="/wiki/Monkeypox" title="Monkeypox">monkeypox</a> outbreak in the <a href="/wiki/Western_Hemisphere" title="Western Hemisphere">Western Hemisphere</a>, prompting <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_York_Governor" title="New York Governor">New York Governor</a> <a href="/wiki/Kathy_Hochul" title="Kathy Hochul">Kathy Hochul</a> and New York City Mayor <a href="/wiki/Eric_Adams" title="Eric Adams">Eric Adams</a> declared corresponding <a href="/wiki/Public_health_emergency_(United_States)" title="Public health emergency (United States)">public health emergencies</a> in the state and city, respectively, in July 2022.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_New_York_City" title="Geography of New York City">Geography of New York City</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Geography_of_New_York%E2%80%93New_Jersey_Harbor_Estuary" title="Geography of New York–New Jersey Harbor Estuary">Geography of New York–New Jersey Harbor Estuary</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Core_of_New_York_City_by_Sentinel-2.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4317" data-file-width="3525" decoding="async" height="269" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Core_of_New_York_City_by_Sentinel-2.jpg/220px-Core_of_New_York_City_by_Sentinel-2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Core_of_New_York_City_by_Sentinel-2.jpg/330px-Core_of_New_York_City_by_Sentinel-2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Core_of_New_York_City_by_Sentinel-2.jpg/439px-Core_of_New_York_City_by_Sentinel-2.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Core_of_New_York_City_by_Sentinel-2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The core of the <a href="/wiki/New_York_metropolitan_area" title="New York metropolitan area">New York City metropolitan area</a>, with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Manhattan_Island" title="Manhattan Island">Manhattan Island</a> at its center</div></div></div>
<p>During the <a href="/wiki/Wisconsin_glaciation" title="Wisconsin glaciation">Wisconsin glaciation</a>, 75,000 to 11,000 years ago, the New York City area was situated at the edge of a large <a href="/wiki/Ice_sheet" title="Ice sheet">ice sheet</a> over 2,000 feet (610 m) in depth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JacksonKeller2010a_143-0"><a href="#cite_note-JacksonKeller2010a-143">[143]</a></sup> The erosive forward movement of the ice (and its subsequent retreat) contributed to the separation of what is now <a href="/wiki/Long_Island" title="Long Island">Long Island</a> and <a href="/wiki/Staten_Island" title="Staten Island">Staten Island</a>. That action also left <a href="/wiki/Bedrock" title="Bedrock">bedrock</a> at a relatively shallow depth, providing a solid <a href="/wiki/Foundation_(engineering)" title="Foundation (engineering)">foundation</a> for most of Manhattan's skyscrapers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144">[144]</a></sup>
</p><p>New York City is situated in the <a href="/wiki/Northeastern_United_States" title="Northeastern United States">northeastern United States</a>, in southeastern New York State, approximately halfway between <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a> and <a href="/wiki/Boston" title="Boston">Boston</a>. The location at the mouth of the <a href="/wiki/Hudson_River" title="Hudson River">Hudson River</a>, which feeds into a naturally sheltered harbor and then into the Atlantic Ocean, has helped the city grow in significance as a trading port. Most of New York City is built on the three islands of <a href="/wiki/Long_Island" title="Long Island">Long Island</a>, Manhattan, and Staten Island.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Hudson_River" title="Hudson River">Hudson River</a> flows through the <a href="/wiki/Hudson_Valley" title="Hudson Valley">Hudson Valley</a> into <a href="/wiki/New_York_Bay" title="New York Bay">New York Bay</a>. Between New York City and <a href="/wiki/Troy,_New_York" title="Troy, New York">Troy, New York</a>, the river is an <a href="/wiki/Estuary" title="Estuary">estuary</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup> The Hudson River separates the city from the U.S. state of <a href="/wiki/New_Jersey" title="New Jersey">New Jersey</a>. The <a href="/wiki/East_River" title="East River">East River</a>—a <a href="/wiki/Tidal_strait" title="Tidal strait">tidal strait</a>—flows from <a href="/wiki/Long_Island_Sound" title="Long Island Sound">Long Island Sound</a> and separates the Bronx and Manhattan from Long Island. The <a href="/wiki/Harlem_River" title="Harlem River">Harlem River</a>, another tidal strait between the East and Hudson rivers, separates most of Manhattan from the Bronx. The <a href="/wiki/Bronx_River" title="Bronx River">Bronx River</a>, which flows through the Bronx and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Westchester_County" title="Westchester County">Westchester County</a>, is the only entirely <a href="/wiki/Fresh_water" title="Fresh water">freshwater</a> river in the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nytimes_146-0"><a href="#cite_note-nytimes-146">[146]</a></sup>
</p><p>The city's land has been altered substantially by human intervention, with considerable <a href="/wiki/Land_reclamation" title="Land reclamation">land reclamation</a> along the waterfronts since Dutch colonial times; reclamation is most prominent in <a href="/wiki/Lower_Manhattan" title="Lower Manhattan">Lower Manhattan</a>, with developments such as <a href="/wiki/Battery_Park_City" title="Battery Park City">Battery Park City</a> in the 1970s and 1980s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gillespie-p71_147-0"><a href="#cite_note-gillespie-p71-147">[147]</a></sup> Some of the natural relief in topography has been evened out, especially in Manhattan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148"><a href="#cite_note-148">[148]</a></sup>
</p><p>The city's total area is 468.484 square miles (1,213.37 km<sup>2</sup>); 302.643 sq mi (783.84 km<sup>2</sup>) of the city is land and 165.841 sq mi (429.53 km<sup>2</sup>) of this is water.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CensusGazetteer_149-0"><a href="#cite_note-CensusGazetteer-149">[149]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT_Land_Estimate_150-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYT_Land_Estimate-150">[150]</a></sup> The highest point in the city is <a href="/wiki/Todt_Hill" title="Todt Hill">Todt Hill</a> on Staten Island, which, at 409.8 feet (124.9 m) <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Above_mean_sea_level" title="Above mean sea level">above sea level</a>, is the highest point on the eastern seaboard south of <a href="/wiki/Maine" title="Maine">Maine</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup> The summit of the ridge is mostly covered in <a href="/wiki/Woodland" title="Woodland">woodlands</a> as part of the <a href="/wiki/Staten_Island_Greenbelt" title="Staten Island Greenbelt">Staten Island Greenbelt</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152"><a href="#cite_note-152">[152]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Boroughs">Boroughs</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Boroughs_of_New_York_City" title="Boroughs of New York City">Boroughs of New York City</a> and <a href="/wiki/Neighborhoods_in_New_York_City" title="Neighborhoods in New York City">Neighborhoods in New York City</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:5_Boroughs_Labels_New_York_City_Map.svg"><img alt="A map showing five boroughs in different colors." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1978" data-file-width="2000" decoding="async" height="218" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/5_Boroughs_Labels_New_York_City_Map.svg/220px-5_Boroughs_Labels_New_York_City_Map.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/5_Boroughs_Labels_New_York_City_Map.svg/330px-5_Boroughs_Labels_New_York_City_Map.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/5_Boroughs_Labels_New_York_City_Map.svg/440px-5_Boroughs_Labels_New_York_City_Map.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:5_Boroughs_Labels_New_York_City_Map.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r981673959">.mw-parser-output .legend{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .legend-color{display:inline-block;min-width:1.25em;height:1.25em;line-height:1.25;margin:1px 0;text-align:center;border:1px solid black;background-color:transparent;color:black}.mw-parser-output .legend-text{}</style><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#4DAF4A; color:black;"> </span> 1. Manhattan</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#FFFF33; color:black;"> </span> 2. Brooklyn</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#FF7F00; color:black;"> </span> 3. Queens</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#E41A1C; color:white;"> </span> 4. The Bronx</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#984EA3; color:white;"> </span> 5. Staten Island</div></div></div></div>
<table border="1" class="wikitable sortable" style="float:center; text-align:right; font-size:85%; margin:1em;">

<th colspan="9" style="background-color:tan;"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1045256916">.mw-parser-output .navbar-header{text-align:center;position:relative;white-space:nowrap}.mw-parser-output .navbar-header .navbar{position:absolute;right:0;top:0;margin:0 5px}</style><div class="navbar-header">New York City's <a href="/wiki/Boroughs_of_New_York_City" title="Boroughs of New York City">five boroughs</a><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:NYC_boroughs" title="Template:NYC boroughs"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:NYC_boroughs" title="Template talk:NYC boroughs"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:NYC_boroughs&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></div>
