<tr class="sortbottom">
<td align="center" colspan="9">† <b>GDP</b> = <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">Gross Domestic Product</a>    <i><b>Sources</b>:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153"><a href="#cite_note-153">[153]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154"><a href="#cite_note-154">[154]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155"><a href="#cite_note-155">[155]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156"><a href="#cite_note-156">[156]</a></sup> and see individual borough articles.</i>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><span class="nowrap">New York City</span> is sometimes referred to collectively as the <i>Five Boroughs</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[157]</a></sup> Each borough is coextensive with a respective <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_New_York_(state)#County" title="Administrative divisions of New York (state)">county</a> of <a href="/wiki/New_York_(state)" title="New York (state)">New York State</a>, making New York City one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_U.S._municipalities_in_multiple_counties" title="List of U.S. municipalities in multiple counties">U.S. municipalities in multiple counties</a>. There are <a href="/wiki/Category:Neighborhoods_in_New_York_City" title="Category:Neighborhoods in New York City">hundreds of distinct neighborhoods</a> throughout the boroughs, many with a definable history and character.
</p><p>If the boroughs were each independent cities, four of the boroughs (Brooklyn, Queens, Manhattan, and the Bronx) would be among the ten most populous cities in the United States (Staten Island would be ranked 37th as of 2020); these same boroughs are coterminous with the four most densely populated counties in the United States: New York (Manhattan), Kings (Brooklyn), Bronx, and Queens.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Manhattan">Manhattan</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:New_York,_New_York,_August_24,_2017.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="772" data-file-width="2500" decoding="async" height="68" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/New_York%2C_New_York%2C_August_24%2C_2017.jpg/220px-New_York%2C_New_York%2C_August_24%2C_2017.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/New_York%2C_New_York%2C_August_24%2C_2017.jpg/330px-New_York%2C_New_York%2C_August_24%2C_2017.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/New_York%2C_New_York%2C_August_24%2C_2017.jpg/440px-New_York%2C_New_York%2C_August_24%2C_2017.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:New_York,_New_York,_August_24,_2017.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Lower_Manhattan" title="Lower Manhattan">Lower</a> and <a href="/wiki/Midtown_Manhattan" title="Midtown Manhattan">Midtown Manhattan</a>, as seen by a <a href="/wiki/SkySat" title="SkySat">SkySat</a> satellite in 2017</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Manhattan" title="Manhattan">Manhattan</a> (New York County) is the geographically smallest and most densely populated borough. It is home to <a href="/wiki/Central_Park" title="Central Park">Central Park</a> and most of the city's <a href="/wiki/Skyscraper" title="Skyscraper">skyscrapers</a>, and is sometimes locally known as <i>The City</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ManhattanTheCity_158-0"><a href="#cite_note-ManhattanTheCity-158">[158]</a></sup> Manhattan's population density of 72,033 people per square mile (27,812/km<sup>2</sup>) in 2015 makes it the <a href="/wiki/County_statistics_of_the_United_States#Population_density" title="County statistics of the United States">highest of any county in the United States</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_United_States_cities_by_population_density#New_York_City_boroughs" title="List of United States cities by population density">higher than the density of any individual American city</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159"><a href="#cite_note-159">[159]</a></sup>
</p><p>Manhattan is the cultural, administrative, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Financial_center" title="Financial center">financial center</a> of New York City and contains the <a href="/wiki/Headquarters" title="Headquarters">headquarters</a> of many major <a href="/wiki/Multinational_corporation" title="Multinational corporation">multinational corporations</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Headquarters_of_the_United_Nations" title="Headquarters of the United Nations">United Nations Headquarters</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wall_Street" title="Wall Street">Wall Street</a>, and a number of important universities. The borough of Manhattan is often described as the financial and cultural center of the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160"><a href="#cite_note-160">[160]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161"><a href="#cite_note-161">[161]</a></sup>
</p><p>Most of the borough is situated on <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Manhattan_Island" title="Manhattan Island">Manhattan Island</a>, at the mouth of the <a href="/wiki/Hudson_River" title="Hudson River">Hudson River</a> and the <a href="/wiki/East_River" title="East River">East River</a>, and its southern tip, at the confluence of the two rivers, represents the birthplace of New York City itself. Several small islands also compose part of the borough of Manhattan, including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Randall%27s_Island" title="Randall's Island">Randall's Island</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wards_Island" title="Wards Island">Wards Island</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Roosevelt_Island" title="Roosevelt Island">Roosevelt Island</a> in the East River, and <a href="/wiki/Governors_Island" title="Governors Island">Governors Island</a> and <a href="/wiki/Liberty_Island" title="Liberty Island">Liberty Island</a> to the south in <a href="/wiki/New_York_Harbor" title="New York Harbor">New York Harbor</a>.
</p><p>Manhattan Island is loosely divided into the <a href="/wiki/Lower_Manhattan" title="Lower Manhattan">Lower</a>, <a href="/wiki/Midtown_Manhattan" title="Midtown Manhattan">Midtown</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Upper_Manhattan" title="Upper Manhattan">Uptown</a> regions. Uptown Manhattan is divided by Central Park into the <a href="/wiki/Upper_East_Side" title="Upper East Side">Upper East Side</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Upper_West_Side" title="Upper West Side">Upper West Side</a>, and above the park is <a href="/wiki/Harlem" title="Harlem">Harlem</a>, bordering the Bronx (Bronx County).
</p><p>Harlem was predominantly occupied by Jewish and Italian Americans in the 19th century until the <a href="/wiki/Great_Migration_(African_American)" title="Great Migration (African American)">Great Migration</a>. It was the center of the <a href="/wiki/Harlem_Renaissance" title="Harlem Renaissance">Harlem Renaissance</a>.
</p><p>
The borough of Manhattan also includes a small neighborhood on the mainland, called <a href="/wiki/Marble_Hill,_Manhattan" title="Marble Hill, Manhattan">Marble Hill</a>, which is contiguous with the Bronx. New York City's remaining four boroughs are collectively referred to as the <i>Outer Boroughs</i>.</p><div class="thumb tnone" style="margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto;overflow:hidden;width:auto;max-width:1408px"><div class="thumbinner"><div class="noresize" style="overflow:auto"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:10_mile_panorama_of_NYC,_Feb.,_2018.jpg" title="Ten mile (16km) Manhattan skyline panorama from 120th Street to the Battery, taken in February 2018 from across the Hudson River in Weehawken, New Jersey # Empire State Building # Manhattan West # a: 55 Hudson Yards, 14b: 35 Hudson Yards, 14c: 10 Hudson Yards, 14d: 15 Hudson Yards # 56 Leonard Street # 8 Spruce Street # Woolworth Building # 70 Pine Street # Four Seasons Downtown # 40 Wall Street # 3 World Trade Center # 4 World Trade Center # One World Trade Center"><img alt="" data-file-height="972" data-file-width="8582" decoding="async" height="159" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/10_mile_panorama_of_NYC%2C_Feb.%2C_2018.jpg/1400px-10_mile_panorama_of_NYC%2C_Feb.%2C_2018.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/10_mile_panorama_of_NYC%2C_Feb.%2C_2018.jpg/2100px-10_mile_panorama_of_NYC%2C_Feb.%2C_2018.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/10_mile_panorama_of_NYC%2C_Feb.%2C_2018.jpg/2800px-10_mile_panorama_of_NYC%2C_Feb.%2C_2018.jpg 2x" width="1400"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="text-align:center"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:10_mile_panorama_of_NYC,_Feb.,_2018.jpg" title="File:10 mile panorama of NYC, Feb., 2018.jpg"> </a></div>Ten mile (16km) <a href="/wiki/Manhattan" title="Manhattan">Manhattan</a> skyline panorama from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/120th_Street_(Manhattan)" title="120th Street (Manhattan)">120th Street</a> to <a href="/wiki/The_Battery_(Manhattan)" title="The Battery (Manhattan)">the Battery</a>, taken in February 2018 from across the <a href="/wiki/Hudson_River" title="Hudson River">Hudson River</a> in <a href="/wiki/Weehawken,_New_Jersey" title="Weehawken, New Jersey">Weehawken, New Jersey</a>

<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Brooklyn">Brooklyn</span></h4>
<p><a href="/wiki/Brooklyn" title="Brooklyn">Brooklyn</a> (Kings County), on the western tip of <a href="/wiki/Long_Island" title="Long Island">Long Island</a>, is the city's most populous borough. Brooklyn is known for its cultural, social, and ethnic diversity, an independent art scene, <a href="/wiki/List_of_Brooklyn_neighborhoods" title="List of Brooklyn neighborhoods">distinct neighborhoods</a>, and a distinctive architectural heritage. <a href="/wiki/Downtown_Brooklyn" title="Downtown Brooklyn">Downtown Brooklyn</a> is the largest central core neighborhood in the Outer Boroughs. The borough has a long beachfront shoreline including <a href="/wiki/Coney_Island" title="Coney Island">Coney Island</a>, established in the 1870s as one of the earliest amusement grounds in the U.S.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162"><a href="#cite_note-162">[162]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Marine_Park_(Brooklyn_park)" title="Marine Park (Brooklyn park)">Marine Park</a> and <a href="/wiki/Prospect_Park_(Brooklyn)" title="Prospect Park (Brooklyn)">Prospect Park</a> are the two largest parks in Brooklyn.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163"><a href="#cite_note-163">[163]</a></sup> Since 2010, Brooklyn has evolved into a thriving hub of <a href="/wiki/Entrepreneurship" title="Entrepreneurship">entrepreneurship</a> and <a href="/wiki/High_tech" title="High tech">high technology</a> <a href="/wiki/Startup_company" title="Startup company">startup firms</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164"><a href="#cite_note-164">[164]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BrooklynDesignHub_165-0"><a href="#cite_note-BrooklynDesignHub-165">[165]</a></sup> and of <a href="/wiki/Postmodern_art" title="Postmodern art">postmodern art</a> and design.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BrooklynDesignHub_165-1"><a href="#cite_note-BrooklynDesignHub-165">[165]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BrooklynArt1_166-0"><a href="#cite_note-BrooklynArt1-166">[166]</a></sup></p><div class="thumb tnone" style="margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto;overflow:hidden;width:auto;max-width:1408px"><div class="thumbinner"><div class="noresize" style="overflow:auto"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Brooklyn_from_Governors_Island_September_2016_panorama.jpg" title="Downtown Brooklyn skyline from Governors Island in September 2016"><img alt="" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="21000" decoding="async" height="200" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Brooklyn_from_Governors_Island_September_2016_panorama.jpg/1400px-Brooklyn_from_Governors_Island_September_2016_panorama.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Brooklyn_from_Governors_Island_September_2016_panorama.jpg/2100px-Brooklyn_from_Governors_Island_September_2016_panorama.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Brooklyn_from_Governors_Island_September_2016_panorama.jpg/2800px-Brooklyn_from_Governors_Island_September_2016_panorama.jpg 2x" width="1400"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Brooklyn_from_Governors_Island_September_2016_panorama.jpg" title="File:Brooklyn from Governors Island September 2016 panorama.jpg"> </a></div><a href="/wiki/Downtown_Brooklyn" title="Downtown Brooklyn">Downtown Brooklyn</a> skyline from <a href="/wiki/Governors_Island" title="Governors Island">Governors Island</a> in September 2016</div></div></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Queens">Queens</span></h4>
<p><a href="/wiki/Queens" title="Queens">Queens</a> (Queens County), on Long Island north and east of Brooklyn, is geographically the largest borough, the most <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethnic_diversity" title="Ethnic diversity">ethnically diverse</a> county in the United States,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-queensdiverse_167-0"><a href="#cite_note-queensdiverse-167">[167]</a></sup> and the most ethnically diverse urban area in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-QueensMostDiverseWorld1_168-0"><a href="#cite_note-QueensMostDiverseWorld1-168">[168]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-QueensMostDiverseWorld2_169-0"><a href="#cite_note-QueensMostDiverseWorld2-169">[169]</a></sup> Historically a collection of small towns and villages founded by the Dutch, the borough has since developed both commercial and residential prominence. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Downtown_Flushing" title="Downtown Flushing">Downtown Flushing</a> has become one of the busiest central core neighborhoods in the outer boroughs. Queens is the site of <a href="/wiki/Citi_Field" title="Citi Field">Citi Field</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baseball_stadium" title="Baseball stadium">baseball stadium</a> of the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Mets" title="New York Mets">New York Mets</a>, and hosts the annual <a href="/wiki/US_Open_(tennis)" title="US Open (tennis)">U.S. Open tennis tournament</a> at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Flushing_Meadows-Corona_Park" title="Flushing Meadows-Corona Park">Flushing Meadows-Corona Park</a>. Additionally, two of the three busiest airports serving the New York metropolitan area, <a href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_International_Airport" title="John F. Kennedy International Airport">John F. Kennedy International Airport</a> and <a href="/wiki/LaGuardia_Airport" title="LaGuardia Airport">LaGuardia Airport</a>, are located in Queens. The third is <a href="/wiki/Newark_Liberty_International_Airport" title="Newark Liberty International Airport">Newark Liberty International Airport</a> in <a href="/wiki/Newark,_New_Jersey" title="Newark, New Jersey">Newark</a>, New Jersey.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="The_Bronx">The Bronx</span></h4>
<p><a href="/wiki/The_Bronx" title="The Bronx">The Bronx</a> (Bronx County) is both New York City's northernmost borough, and the only one that is mostly on the mainland. It is the location of <a href="/wiki/Yankee_Stadium" title="Yankee Stadium">Yankee Stadium</a>, the baseball park of the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Yankees" title="New York Yankees">New York Yankees</a>, and home to the largest <a href="/wiki/Housing_cooperative" title="Housing cooperative">cooperatively-owned housing</a> complex in the United States, <a href="/wiki/Co-op_City,_Bronx" title="Co-op City, Bronx">Co-op City</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170"><a href="#cite_note-170">[170]</a></sup> It is also home to the <a href="/wiki/Bronx_Zoo" title="Bronx Zoo">Bronx Zoo</a>, the world's largest metropolitan zoo,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BronxZoo_171-0"><a href="#cite_note-BronxZoo-171">[171]</a></sup> which spans 265 acres (1.07 km<sup>2</sup>) and houses more than 6,000 animals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172"><a href="#cite_note-172">[172]</a></sup> The Bronx is also the birthplace of <a href="/wiki/Hip_hop_music" title="Hip hop music">hip hop music</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hip_hop_culture" title="Hip hop culture">culture</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_173-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto-173">[173]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Pelham_Bay_Park" title="Pelham Bay Park">Pelham Bay Park</a> is the largest park in New York City, at 2,772 acres (1,122 ha).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nyt20130601_174-0"><a href="#cite_note-nyt20130601-174">[174]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Staten_Island">Staten Island</span></h4>
<p><a href="/wiki/Staten_Island" title="Staten Island">Staten Island</a> (Richmond County) is the most suburban in character of the five boroughs. Staten Island is connected to Brooklyn by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Verrazano-Narrows_Bridge" title="Verrazano-Narrows Bridge">Verrazano-Narrows Bridge</a>, and to Manhattan by way of the free <a href="/wiki/Staten_Island_Ferry" title="Staten Island Ferry">Staten Island Ferry</a>, a daily <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Commuter" title="Commuter">commuter</a> ferry which provides unobstructed views of the <a href="/wiki/Statue_of_Liberty" title="Statue of Liberty">Statue of Liberty</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ellis_Island" title="Ellis Island">Ellis Island</a>, and Lower Manhattan. In central Staten Island, the <a href="/wiki/Staten_Island_Greenbelt" title="Staten Island Greenbelt">Staten Island Greenbelt</a> spans approximately 2,500 acres (10 km<sup>2</sup>), including 28 miles (45 km) of walking trails and one of the last undisturbed forests in the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[175]</a></sup> Designated in 1984 to protect the island's natural lands, the Greenbelt comprises seven city parks.
</p>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional center">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 340px"><div style="width: 340px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 335px;"><div style="margin:15px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Long_Island_City_from_One_World_Observatory_2017.jpg" title="The growing skyline of Long Island City, Queens (background),[176] facing the East River and Manhattan in May 2017"><img alt="The growing skyline of Long Island City, Queens (background),[176] facing the East River and Manhattan in May 2017" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="4608" decoding="async" height="200" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Long_Island_City_from_One_World_Observatory_2017.jpg/267px-Long_Island_City_from_One_World_Observatory_2017.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Long_Island_City_from_One_World_Observatory_2017.jpg/400px-Long_Island_City_from_One_World_Observatory_2017.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Long_Island_City_from_One_World_Observatory_2017.jpg/533px-Long_Island_City_from_One_World_Observatory_2017.jpg 2x" width="267"/></a></div></div>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_New_York_City" title="Architecture of New York City">Architecture of New York City</a>; <a href="/wiki/List_of_buildings,_sites,_and_monuments_in_New_York_City" title="List of buildings, sites, and monuments in New York City">List of buildings, sites, and monuments in New York City</a>; <a href="/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_in_New_York_City" title="List of tallest buildings in New York City">List of tallest buildings in New York City</a>; and <a href="/wiki/List_of_hotels_in_New_York_City" title="List of hotels in New York City">List of hotels in New York City</a></div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:362px;max-width:362px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:179px;max-width:179px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:160px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Empire_State_Building_(HDR).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="3874" data-file-width="2617" decoding="async" height="262" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Empire_State_Building_%28HDR%29.jpg/177px-Empire_State_Building_%28HDR%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Empire_State_Building_%28HDR%29.jpg/266px-Empire_State_Building_%28HDR%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Empire_State_Building_%28HDR%29.jpg/354px-Empire_State_Building_%28HDR%29.jpg 2x" width="177"/></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:179px;max-width:179px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:160px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Chrysler_Building_spire,_Manhattan,_by_Carol_Highsmith_(LOC_highsm.04444).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="4284" data-file-width="2344" decoding="async" height="323" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Chrysler_Building_spire%2C_Manhattan%2C_by_Carol_Highsmith_%28LOC_highsm.04444%29.jpg/177px-Chrysler_Building_spire%2C_Manhattan%2C_by_Carol_Highsmith_%28LOC_highsm.04444%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Chrysler_Building_spire%2C_Manhattan%2C_by_Carol_Highsmith_%28LOC_highsm.04444%29.jpg/266px-Chrysler_Building_spire%2C_Manhattan%2C_by_Carol_Highsmith_%28LOC_highsm.04444%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Chrysler_Building_spire%2C_Manhattan%2C_by_Carol_Highsmith_%28LOC_highsm.04444%29.jpg/354px-Chrysler_Building_spire%2C_Manhattan%2C_by_Carol_Highsmith_%28LOC_highsm.04444%29.jpg 2x" width="177"/></a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:179px;max-width:179px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:128px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Greenpoint_Houses.JPG"><img alt="" data-file-height="1704" data-file-width="2272" decoding="async" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Greenpoint_Houses.JPG/177px-Greenpoint_Houses.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Greenpoint_Houses.JPG/266px-Greenpoint_Houses.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Greenpoint_Houses.JPG/354px-Greenpoint_Houses.JPG 2x" width="177"/></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:179px;max-width:179px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:128px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Antiguo_vs_Moderno_(4432379954).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="3264" data-file-width="2448" decoding="async" height="236" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Antiguo_vs_Moderno_%284432379954%29.jpg/177px-Antiguo_vs_Moderno_%284432379954%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Antiguo_vs_Moderno_%284432379954%29.jpg/266px-Antiguo_vs_Moderno_%284432379954%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Antiguo_vs_Moderno_%284432379954%29.jpg/354px-Antiguo_vs_Moderno_%284432379954%29.jpg 2x" width="177"/></a></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flex"><div class="thumbcaption">Clockwise, from upper left: the <a href="/wiki/Empire_State_Building" title="Empire State Building">Empire State Building</a> as a solitary icon of New York, defined by its <a href="/wiki/Setback_(architecture)" title="Setback (architecture)">setbacks</a>, Art Deco details, and spire as the <a href="/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_and_structures" title="List of tallest buildings and structures">world's tallest building</a> from 1931 to 1970; the <a href="/wiki/Chrysler_Building" title="Chrysler Building">Chrysler Building</a>, built in 1930, also a Manhattan icon in the <a href="/wiki/Art_Deco" title="Art Deco">Art Deco</a> style, with ornamental <a href="/wiki/Hubcap" title="Hubcap">hubcaps</a> and its spire; <a href="/wiki/Modern_architecture" title="Modern architecture">modernist architecture</a> juxtaposed with <a href="/wiki/Gothic_Revival_architecture" title="Gothic Revival architecture">Gothic Revival architecture</a> in <a href="/wiki/Midtown_Manhattan" title="Midtown Manhattan">Midtown Manhattan</a>; and landmark 19th-century <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rowhouse" title="Rowhouse">rowhouses</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Brownstone" title="Brownstone">brownstones</a>, on tree-lined Kent Street in the <a href="/wiki/Greenpoint,_Brooklyn" title="Greenpoint, Brooklyn">Greenpoint Historic District</a>, Brooklyn</div></div></div></div>
<p>New York has architecturally noteworthy buildings in a wide range of styles and from distinct time periods, from the Dutch Colonial <a href="/wiki/Wyckoff_House" title="Wyckoff House">Pieter Claesen Wyckoff House</a> in Brooklyn, the oldest section of which dates to 1656, to the modern <a href="/wiki/One_World_Trade_Center" title="One World Trade Center">One World Trade Center</a>, the skyscraper at <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Center_site" title="World Trade Center site">Ground Zero</a> in <a href="/wiki/Lower_Manhattan" title="Lower Manhattan">Lower Manhattan</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_most_expensive_buildings_in_the_world" title="List of most expensive buildings in the world">most expensive office tower</a> in the world by construction cost.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177">[177]</a></sup>
</p><p>Manhattan's <a href="/wiki/Skyline" title="Skyline">skyline</a>, with its many skyscrapers, is universally recognized, and the city has been home to several of the <a href="/wiki/Skyscraper#History_of_the_tallest_skyscrapers" title="Skyscraper">tallest buildings in the world</a>. As of 2019<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=New_York_City&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, New York City had 6,455 high-rise buildings, the third most in the world after Hong Kong and <a href="/wiki/Seoul" title="Seoul">Seoul</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178">[178]</a></sup> Of these, as of 2011<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=New_York_City&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, 550 completed structures were at least 330 feet (100 m) high, with more than fifty completed <a href="/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_in_New_York_City" title="List of tallest buildings in New York City">skyscrapers taller than 656 feet (200 m)</a>. These include the <a href="/wiki/Woolworth_Building" title="Woolworth Building">Woolworth Building</a>, an early example of <a href="/wiki/Gothic_Revival_architecture" title="Gothic Revival architecture">Gothic Revival architecture</a> in skyscraper design, built with massively scaled Gothic detailing; completed in 1913, for 17 years it was the world's tallest building.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[179]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/1916_Zoning_Resolution" title="1916 Zoning Resolution">1916 Zoning Resolution</a> required <a href="/wiki/Setback_(architecture)" title="Setback (architecture)">setbacks</a> in new buildings and restricted towers to a percentage of the <a href="/wiki/Land_lot" title="Land lot">lot size</a>, to allow sunlight to reach the streets below.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[180]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Art_Deco" title="Art Deco">Art Deco</a> style of the <a href="/wiki/Chrysler_Building" title="Chrysler Building">Chrysler Building</a> (1930) and <a href="/wiki/Empire_State_Building" title="Empire State Building">Empire State Building</a> (1931), with their tapered tops and steel <a href="/wiki/Spire" title="Spire">spires</a>, reflected the zoning requirements. The buildings have distinctive ornamentation, such as the eagles at the corners of the 61st floor on the Chrysler Building, and are considered some of the finest examples of the <a href="/wiki/Art_Deco" title="Art Deco">Art Deco</a> style.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181"><a href="#cite_note-181">[181]</a></sup> A highly influential example of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_style_(architecture)" title="International style (architecture)">international style</a> in the United States is the <a href="/wiki/Seagram_Building" title="Seagram Building">Seagram Building</a> (1957), distinctive for its façade using visible bronze-toned <a href="/wiki/I-beam" title="I-beam">I-beams</a> to evoke the building's structure. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cond%C3%A9_Nast_Building" title="Condé Nast Building">Condé Nast Building</a> (2000) is a prominent example of <a href="/wiki/Sustainable_design" title="Sustainable design">green design</a> in American skyscrapers<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-greenbuilding_182-0"><a href="#cite_note-greenbuilding-182">[182]</a></sup> and has received an award from the <a href="/wiki/American_Institute_of_Architects" title="American Institute of Architects">American Institute of Architects</a> and AIA New York State for its design.
</p><p>The character of New York's large residential districts is often defined by the elegant <a href="/wiki/Brownstone" title="Brownstone">brownstone</a> <a href="/wiki/Terraced_house" title="Terraced house">rowhouses</a> and <a href="/wiki/Townhouse" title="Townhouse">townhouses</a> and shabby <a href="/wiki/Tenement" title="Tenement">tenements</a> that were built during a period of rapid expansion from 1870 to 1930.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[183]</a></sup> In contrast, New York City also has neighborhoods that are less densely populated and feature free-standing dwellings. In neighborhoods such as <a href="/wiki/Riverdale,_Bronx" title="Riverdale, Bronx">Riverdale</a> (in the Bronx), <a href="/wiki/Ditmas_Park,_Brooklyn" title="Ditmas Park, Brooklyn">Ditmas Park</a> (in Brooklyn), and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Douglaston,_Queens" title="Douglaston, Queens">Douglaston</a> (in Queens), large single-family homes are common in various architectural styles such as <a href="/wiki/Tudor_Revival_architecture" title="Tudor Revival architecture">Tudor Revival</a> and <a href="/wiki/Victorian_architecture" title="Victorian architecture">Victorian</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184"><a href="#cite_note-184">[184]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185"><a href="#cite_note-185">[185]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186"><a href="#cite_note-186">[186]</a></sup>
</p><p>Stone and brick became the city's building materials of choice after the construction of wood-frame houses was limited in the aftermath of the <a href="/wiki/Great_Fire_of_New_York" title="Great Fire of New York">Great Fire of 1835</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lankevich-p82_187-0"><a href="#cite_note-lankevich-p82-187">[187]</a></sup> A distinctive feature of many of the city's buildings is the roof-mounted wooden <a href="/wiki/Water_tower" title="Water tower">water tower</a>. In the 1800s, the city required their installation on buildings higher than six stories to prevent the need for excessively high water pressures at lower elevations, which could break municipal water pipes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188"><a href="#cite_note-188">[188]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Garden_city_movement" title="Garden city movement">Garden apartments</a> became popular during the 1920s in outlying areas, such as <a href="/wiki/Jackson_Heights,_Queens" title="Jackson Heights, Queens">Jackson Heights</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189"><a href="#cite_note-189">[189]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Geological_Survey" title="United States Geological Survey">United States Geological Survey</a>, an updated analysis of <a href="/wiki/Seismic_hazard" title="Seismic hazard">seismic hazard</a> in July 2014 revealed a "slightly lower hazard for tall buildings" in New York City than previously assessed. Scientists estimated this lessened risk based upon a lower likelihood than previously thought of slow shaking near the city, which would be more likely to cause damage to taller structures from an earthquake in the vicinity of the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190"><a href="#cite_note-190">[190]</a></sup> Manhattan contained over 500 million square feet of office space as of 2022; the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Covid-19_pandemic" title="Covid-19 pandemic">Covid-19 pandemic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Remote_work" title="Remote work">hybrid work</a> model have prompted consideration of commercial-to-residential conversion within <a href="/wiki/Midtown_Manhattan" title="Midtown Manhattan">Midtown Manhattan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191"><a href="#cite_note-191">[191]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_New_York_City" title="Climate of New York City">Climate of New York City</a></div>

<td><div style="width:1.5em;height:17em;position:relative;padding:0;margin:0">

<td><div style="width:1.5em;height:17em;position:relative;padding:0;margin:0">

<div style="color:blue;position:absolute;bottom:.5em;left:0;width:1.6em;height:1.5em;text-align:center"><span style="font-size:70%">91</span></div>

<div style="overflow:hidden;background:#e44;-webkit-print-color-adjust:exact;color-adjust:exact;position:absolute;left:.2em;width:1.2em;bottom:9.1066666666667em;height:1.3333333333333em;"> </div>

</div></td>
<td><div style="width:1.5em;height:17em;position:relative;padding:0;margin:0">
<div style="height:0em;bottom:2em;width:1.6em;position:absolute;left:0;border-bottom:dotted 1px #abc;padding:0;margin:0"> </div>
<div style="background:#ace;-webkit-print-color-adjust:exact;color-adjust:exact;position:absolute;bottom:2em;left:.2em;width:1.2em;height:2.2352em;overflow:hidden"> </div>
<div style="color:blue;position:absolute;bottom:.5em;left:0;width:1.6em;height:1.5em;text-align:center"><span style="font-size:70%">112</span></div>
<div style="height:0em;bottom:8em;width:1.6em;position:absolute;left:0;border-bottom:dotted 1px #cba;padding:0;margin:0"> </div>
<div style="overflow:hidden;background:#e44;-webkit-print-color-adjust:exact;color-adjust:exact;position:absolute;left:.2em;width:1.2em;bottom:8.2177777777778em;height:1.1111111111111em;"> </div>
<div style="color:red;position:absolute;bottom:9.3288888888889em; left:-.4em;width:1.6em;height:1.5em;text-align:right"><span style="font-size:80%">7</span></div>
<div style="color:red;position:absolute;bottom:6.7177777777778em; left:-.4em;width:1.6em;height:1.5em;text-align:right"><span style="font-size:80%">1</span></div>
</div></td>
</tr>
<tr><td colspan="12" style="padding: 2px; text-align: left; line-height: 1.5em; color: red">Average max. and min. temperatures in °C</td></tr>
<tr><td colspan="12" style="padding: 2px; text-align: left; line-height: 1.5em; color: blue">Precipitation totals in mm</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Under the <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen climate classification</a>, using the 0 °C (32 °F) isotherm, New York City features a <a href="/wiki/Humid_subtropical_climate" title="Humid subtropical climate">humid subtropical climate</a> (Cfa), and is thus the northernmost major city on the North American continent with this categorization. The suburbs to the immediate north and west lie in the transitional zone between humid subtropical and <a href="/wiki/Humid_continental_climate" title="Humid continental climate">humid continental climates</a> (Dfa).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Peel,_M._C.;_Finlayson,_B._L.;_McMahon,_T._A_192-0"><a href="#cite_note-Peel,_M._C.;_Finlayson,_B._L.;_McMahon,_T._A-192">[192]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-newyorkpolonia.com_193-0"><a href="#cite_note-newyorkpolonia.com-193">[193]</a></sup> By the <a href="/wiki/Trewartha_climate_classification" title="Trewartha climate classification">Trewartha classification</a>, the city is defined as having an oceanic climate (Do).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[194]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[195]</a></sup> Annually, the city averages 234 days with at least some sunshine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-noaasun_196-0"><a href="#cite_note-noaasun-196">[196]</a></sup> The city lies in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/USDA" title="USDA">USDA</a> <a href="/wiki/Hardiness_zone" title="Hardiness zone">7b plant hardiness zone</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197"><a href="#cite_note-197">[197]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Photo_10--Central_Park_in_winter.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="523" data-file-width="672" decoding="async" height="171" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Photo_10--Central_Park_in_winter.jpg/220px-Photo_10--Central_Park_in_winter.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Photo_10--Central_Park_in_winter.jpg/330px-Photo_10--Central_Park_in_winter.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Photo_10--Central_Park_in_winter.jpg/440px-Photo_10--Central_Park_in_winter.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Photo_10--Central_Park_in_winter.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a href="/wiki/Central_Park" title="Central Park">Central Park</a> in Winter</i> by Raymond Speers, in <i><a href="/wiki/Munsey%27s_Magazine" title="Munsey's Magazine">Munsey's Magazine</a></i>, February 1900</div></div></div>
<p>Winters are chilly and damp, and prevailing wind patterns that blow <a href="/wiki/Sea_breeze" title="Sea breeze">sea breezes</a> offshore temper the moderating effects of the Atlantic Ocean; yet the Atlantic and the partial shielding from colder air by the <a href="/wiki/Appalachian_Mountains" title="Appalachian Mountains">Appalachian Mountains</a> keep the city warmer in the winter than inland North American cities at similar or lesser latitudes such as <a href="/wiki/Pittsburgh" title="Pittsburgh">Pittsburgh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cincinnati" title="Cincinnati">Cincinnati</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Indianapolis" title="Indianapolis">Indianapolis</a>. The daily mean temperature in January, the area's coldest month, is 33.3 °F (0.7 °C).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NOAA_txt_198-0"><a href="#cite_note-NOAA_txt-198">[198]</a></sup> Temperatures usually drop to 10 °F (−12 °C) several times per winter,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYC_climate_199-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYC_climate-199">[199]</a></sup> yet can also reach 60 °F (16 °C) for several days even in the coldest winter month. Spring and autumn are unpredictable and can range from cool to warm, although they are usually mild with low humidity. Summers are typically hot and humid, with a daily mean temperature of 77.5 °F (25.3 °C) in July.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NOAA_txt_198-1"><a href="#cite_note-NOAA_txt-198">[198]</a></sup>
</p><p>Nighttime temperatures are often enhanced due to the <a href="/wiki/Urban_heat_island" title="Urban heat island">urban heat island</a> effect. Daytime temperatures exceed 90 °F (32 °C) on average of 17 days each summer and in some years exceed 100 °F (38 °C), although this is a rare achievement, last occurring on July 18, 2012.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-New_York_City_Weatherbox_NOAA_200-0"><a href="#cite_note-New_York_City_Weatherbox_NOAA-200">[200]</a></sup> Similarly, readings of 0 °F (−18 °C) are also extremely rare, last occurring on February 14, 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[201]</a></sup> Extreme temperatures have ranged from −15 °F (−26 °C), recorded on February 9, 1934, up to 106 °F (41 °C) on July 9, 1936;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NOAA_txt_198-2"><a href="#cite_note-NOAA_txt-198">[198]</a></sup> the coldest recorded wind chill was −37 °F (−38 °C) on the same day as the all-time record low.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202"><a href="#cite_note-202">[202]</a></sup> The record cold daily maximum was 2 °F (−17 °C) on December 30, 1917, while, conversely, the record warm daily minimum was 87 °F (31 °C), on July 2, 1903.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-New_York_City_Weatherbox_NOAA_200-1"><a href="#cite_note-New_York_City_Weatherbox_NOAA-200">[200]</a></sup> The average water temperature of the nearby Atlantic Ocean ranges from 39.7 °F (4.3 °C) in February to 74.1 °F (23.4 °C) in August.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[203]</a></sup>
</p><p>The city receives 49.5 inches (1,260 mm) of precipitation annually, which is relatively evenly spread throughout the year. Average winter snowfall between 1991 and 2020 has been 29.8 inches (76 cm); this varies considerably between years. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hurricane" title="Hurricane">Hurricanes</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tropical_storm" title="Tropical storm">tropical storms</a> are rare in the New York area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204"><a href="#cite_note-204">[204]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Sandy" title="Hurricane Sandy">Hurricane Sandy</a> brought a destructive <a href="/wiki/Storm_surge" title="Storm surge">storm surge</a> to New York City on the evening of October 29, 2012, flooding numerous streets, tunnels, and subway lines in Lower Manhattan and other areas of the city and cutting off electricity in many parts of the city and its suburbs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205"><a href="#cite_note-205">[205]</a></sup> The storm and its profound impacts have prompted the discussion of constructing <a href="/wiki/Seawall" title="Seawall">seawalls</a> and other coastal barriers around the shorelines of the city and the metropolitan area to minimize the risk of destructive consequences from another such event in the future.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206"><a href="#cite_note-206">[206]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[207]</a></sup>
</p><p>The coldest month on record is January 1857, with a mean temperature of 19.6 °F (−6.9 °C) whereas the warmest months on record are July 1825 and July 1999, both with a mean temperature of 81.4 °F (27.4 °C).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Temperaturmonatsmittel_208-0"><a href="#cite_note-Temperaturmonatsmittel-208">[208]</a></sup> The warmest years on record are 2012 and 2020, both with mean temperatures of 57.1 °F (13.9 °C). The coldest year is 1836, with a mean temperature of 47.3 °F (8.5 °C).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Temperaturmonatsmittel_208-1"><a href="#cite_note-Temperaturmonatsmittel-208">[208]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209"><a href="#cite_note-209">[209]</a></sup> The driest month on record is June 1949, with 0.02 inches (0.51 mm) of rainfall. The wettest month was August 2011, with 18.95 inches (481 mm) of rainfall. The driest year on record is 1965, with 26.09 inches (663 mm) of rainfall. The wettest year was 1983, with 80.56 inches (2,046 mm) of rainfall.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210"><a href="#cite_note-210">[210]</a></sup> The snowiest month on record is February 2010, with 36.9 inches (94 cm) of snowfall. The snowiest season <i>(Jul–Jun)</i> on record is 1995–1996, with 75.6 inches (192 cm) of snowfall. The least snowy season was 1972–1973, with 2.3 inches (5.8 cm) of snowfall.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[211]</a></sup> The earliest seasonal trace of snowfall occurred on October 10, in both 1979 and 1925. The latest seasonal trace of snowfall occurred on May 9, in both 2020 and 1977.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212"><a href="#cite_note-212">[212]</a></sup>
</p>
<div>

</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Parks">Parks</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/List_of_New_York_City_parks" title="List of New York City parks">List of New York City parks</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:New_York_World%27s_Fair_August_1964.jpeg"><img alt="A spherical sculpture and several attractions line a park during a World's Fair." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2048" data-file-width="3139" decoding="async" height="144" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/New_York_World%27s_Fair_August_1964.jpeg/220px-New_York_World%27s_Fair_August_1964.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/New_York_World%27s_Fair_August_1964.jpeg/330px-New_York_World%27s_Fair_August_1964.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/New_York_World%27s_Fair_August_1964.jpeg/440px-New_York_World%27s_Fair_August_1964.jpeg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:New_York_World%27s_Fair_August_1964.jpeg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Flushing_Meadows%E2%80%93Corona_Park" title="Flushing Meadows–Corona Park">Flushing Meadows–Corona Park</a> was used in both the <a href="/wiki/1939_New_York_World%27s_Fair" title="1939 New York World's Fair">1939</a> and <a href="/wiki/1964_New_York_World%27s_Fair" title="1964 New York World's Fair">1964 New York World's Fair</a>, with the <a href="/wiki/Unisphere" title="Unisphere">Unisphere</a> as the centerpiece of the latter and which remains today.</div></div></div>
<p>The city of New York has a complex park system, with various lands operated by the <a href="/wiki/National_Park_Service" title="National Park Service">National Park Service</a>, the <a href="/wiki/New_York_State_Office_of_Parks,_Recreation_and_Historic_Preservation" title="New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation">New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Department_of_Parks_and_Recreation" title="New York City Department of Parks and Recreation">New York City Department of Parks and Recreation</a>. In its 2018 ParkScore ranking, <a href="/wiki/The_Trust_for_Public_Land" title="The Trust for Public Land">The Trust for Public Land</a> reported that the park system in New York City was the ninth-best park system among the fifty most populous U.S. cities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[217]</a></sup> ParkScore ranks urban park systems by a formula that analyzes median park size, park acres as percent of city area, the percent of city residents within a half-mile of a park, spending of park services per resident, and the number of playgrounds per 10,000 residents. In 2021, the New York City Council banned the use of synthetic pesticides by city agencies and instead required <a href="/wiki/Organic_lawn_management" title="Organic lawn management">organic lawn management</a>. The effort was started by teacher Paula Rogovin's kindergarten class at P.S. 290.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[218]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="National_parks">National parks</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/National_Park_Service" title="National Park Service">National Park Service</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Statue_of_Liberty,_NY.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2668" data-file-width="3558" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Statue_of_Liberty%2C_NY.jpg/220px-Statue_of_Liberty%2C_NY.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Statue_of_Liberty%2C_NY.jpg/330px-Statue_of_Liberty%2C_NY.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Statue_of_Liberty%2C_NY.jpg/440px-Statue_of_Liberty%2C_NY.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Statue_of_Liberty,_NY.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Statue_of_Liberty" title="Statue of Liberty">Statue of Liberty</a> on <a href="/wiki/Liberty_Island" title="Liberty Island">Liberty Island</a> in <a href="/wiki/New_York_Harbor" title="New York Harbor">New York Harbor</a> is a symbol of the United States and its ideals of freedom, democracy, and opportunity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Statue_of_Liberty_UNESCO_22-1"><a href="#cite_note-Statue_of_Liberty_UNESCO-22">[22]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Gateway_National_Recreation_Area" title="Gateway National Recreation Area">Gateway National Recreation Area</a> contains over 26,000 acres (110 km<sup>2</sup>) in total, most of it surrounded by New York City,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[219]</a></sup> including the <a href="/wiki/Jamaica_Bay_Wildlife_Refuge" title="Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge">Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge</a>. In Brooklyn and Queens, the park contains over 9,000 acres (36 km<sup>2</sup>) of <a href="/wiki/Salt_marsh" title="Salt marsh">salt marsh</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wetlands" title="Wetlands">wetlands</a>, islands, and water, including most of <a href="/wiki/Jamaica_Bay" title="Jamaica Bay">Jamaica Bay</a>. Also in Queens, the park includes a significant portion of the western <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rockaway_Peninsula" title="Rockaway Peninsula">Rockaway Peninsula</a>, most notably <a href="/wiki/Jacob_Riis_Park" title="Jacob Riis Park">Jacob Riis Park</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fort_Tilden" title="Fort Tilden">Fort Tilden</a>. In Staten Island, Gateway National Recreation Area includes <a href="/wiki/Fort_Wadsworth" title="Fort Wadsworth">Fort Wadsworth</a>, with historic pre-Civil War era <a href="/wiki/Battery_Weed" title="Battery Weed">Battery Weed</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fort_Tompkins_Quadrangle" title="Fort Tompkins Quadrangle">Fort Tompkins</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Great_Kills_Park" title="Great Kills Park">Great Kills Park</a>, with beaches, trails, and a <a href="/wiki/Marina" title="Marina">marina</a>.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Statue_of_Liberty_National_Monument" title="Statue of Liberty National Monument">Statue of Liberty National Monument and Ellis Island Immigration Museum</a> are managed by the National Park Service and are in both the states of New York and <a href="/wiki/New_Jersey" title="New Jersey">New Jersey</a>. They are joined in the harbor by <a href="/wiki/Governors_Island_National_Monument" title="Governors Island National Monument">Governors Island National Monument</a>, in New York. Historic sites under federal management on Manhattan Island include <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Castle_Clinton_National_Monument" title="Castle Clinton National Monument">Castle Clinton National Monument</a>; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Federal_Hall_National_Memorial" title="Federal Hall National Memorial">Federal Hall National Memorial</a>; <a href="/wiki/Theodore_Roosevelt_Birthplace_National_Historic_Site" title="Theodore Roosevelt Birthplace National Historic Site">Theodore Roosevelt Birthplace National Historic Site</a>; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/General_Grant_National_Memorial" title="General Grant National Memorial">General Grant National Memorial</a> ("Grant's Tomb"); <a href="/wiki/African_Burial_Ground_National_Monument" title="African Burial Ground National Monument">African Burial Ground National Monument</a>; and <a href="/wiki/Hamilton_Grange_National_Memorial" title="Hamilton Grange National Memorial">Hamilton Grange National Memorial</a>. Hundreds of private properties are listed on the <a href="/wiki/National_Register_of_Historic_Places" title="National Register of Historic Places">National Register of Historic Places</a> or as a <a href="/wiki/National_Historic_Landmark" title="National Historic Landmark">National Historic Landmark</a> such as, for example, the <a href="/wiki/Stonewall_Inn" title="Stonewall Inn">Stonewall Inn</a>, part of the <a href="/wiki/Stonewall_National_Monument" title="Stonewall National Monument">Stonewall National Monument</a> in <a href="/wiki/Greenwich_Village" title="Greenwich Village">Greenwich Village</a>, as the catalyst of the modern <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gay_rights_movement" title="Gay rights movement">gay rights movement</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KentuckyStonewall_122-1"><a href="#cite_note-KentuckyStonewall-122">[122]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PinkNewsStonewall_123-1"><a href="#cite_note-PinkNewsStonewall-123">[123]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EncycloStonewall_124-1"><a href="#cite_note-EncycloStonewall-124">[124]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NPSStonewall_125-1"><a href="#cite_note-NPSStonewall-125">[125]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ObamaStonewall_126-1"><a href="#cite_note-ObamaStonewall-126">[126]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="State_parks">State parks</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_York_State_Parks" title="New York State Parks">New York State Parks</a></div>
<p>There are seven state parks within the confines of New York City. Some of them include:
</p>
<ul><li>The <a href="/wiki/Clay_Pit_Ponds_State_Park_Preserve" title="Clay Pit Ponds State Park Preserve">Clay Pit Ponds State Park Preserve</a> is a natural area that includes extensive <a href="/wiki/Trail_riding" title="Trail riding">riding trails</a>.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Riverbank_State_Park" title="Riverbank State Park">Riverbank State Park</a> is a 28-acre (11 ha) facility that rises 69 feet (21 m) over the Hudson River.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222">[220]</a></sup></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/East_River_State_Park" title="East River State Park">Marsha P. Johnson State Park</a> is a state park in Brooklyn and Manhattan that borders the East River that was renamed in honor of Marsha P. Johnson.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223"><a href="#cite_note-223">[221]</a></sup></li></ul>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="City_parks">City parks</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Parks_and_recreation_in_New_York_City" title="Parks and recreation in New York City">Parks and recreation in New York City</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Central_Park_-_The_Pond_(48377220157).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3536" data-file-width="4547" decoding="async" height="171" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Central_Park_-_The_Pond_%2848377220157%29.jpg/220px-Central_Park_-_The_Pond_%2848377220157%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Central_Park_-_The_Pond_%2848377220157%29.jpg/330px-Central_Park_-_The_Pond_%2848377220157%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Central_Park_-_The_Pond_%2848377220157%29.jpg/440px-Central_Park_-_The_Pond_%2848377220157%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Central_Park_-_The_Pond_(48377220157).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>View of <a href="/wiki/The_Pond_and_Hallett_Nature_Sanctuary" title="The Pond and Hallett Nature Sanctuary">The Pond</a> and <a href="/wiki/Midtown_Manhattan" title="Midtown Manhattan">Midtown Manhattan</a> from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gapstow_Bridge" title="Gapstow Bridge">Gapstow Bridge</a> in <a href="/wiki/Central_Park" title="Central Park">Central Park</a>, one of the world's most visited tourist attractions, in 2019</div></div></div>
<p>New York City has over 28,000 acres (110 km<sup>2</sup>) of <a href="/wiki/Urban_park" title="Urban park">municipal parkland</a> and 14 miles (23 km) of public beaches.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224">[222]</a></sup> The largest municipal park in the city is <a href="/wiki/Pelham_Bay_Park" title="Pelham Bay Park">Pelham Bay Park</a> in the Bronx, with 2,772 acres (1,122 ha).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nyt20130601_174-1"><a href="#cite_note-nyt20130601-174">[174]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[223]</a></sup>
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Central_Park" title="Central Park">Central Park</a>, an 843-acre (3.41 km<sup>2</sup>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nyt20130601_174-2"><a href="#cite_note-nyt20130601-174">[174]</a></sup> park in middle-upper Manhattan, is the most visited urban park in the United States and one of the most filmed locations in the world, with 40 million visitors in 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226"><a href="#cite_note-226">[224]</a></sup> The park has a wide range of attractions; there are several lakes and ponds, two <a href="/wiki/Ice_rink" title="Ice rink">ice-skating rinks</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Central_Park_Zoo" title="Central Park Zoo">Central Park Zoo</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Central_Park_Conservatory_Garden" title="Central Park Conservatory Garden">Central Park Conservatory Garden</a>, and the 106-acre (0.43 km<sup>2</sup>) <a href="/wiki/Jacqueline_Kennedy_Onassis_Reservoir" title="Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis Reservoir">Jackie Onassis Reservoir</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[225]</a></sup> Indoor attractions include <a href="/wiki/Belvedere_Castle" title="Belvedere Castle">Belvedere Castle</a> with its nature center, the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theater, and the historic Carousel. On October 23, 2012, <a href="/wiki/Hedge_fund" title="Hedge fund">hedge fund</a> manager <a href="/wiki/John_Paulson" title="John Paulson">John A. Paulson</a> announced a $100 million gift to the <a href="/wiki/Central_Park_Conservancy" title="Central Park Conservancy">Central Park Conservancy</a>, the largest ever monetary donation to New York City's park system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228"><a href="#cite_note-228">[226]</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Washington_Square_Park" title="Washington Square Park">Washington Square Park</a> is a prominent landmark in the <a href="/wiki/Greenwich_Village" title="Greenwich Village">Greenwich Village</a> neighborhood of Lower Manhattan. The <a href="/wiki/Washington_Square_Arch" title="Washington Square Arch">Washington Square Arch</a> at the northern gateway to the park is an iconic symbol of both <a href="/wiki/New_York_University" title="New York University">New York University</a> and Greenwich Village.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Prospect_Park_(Brooklyn)" title="Prospect Park (Brooklyn)">Prospect Park</a> in Brooklyn has a 90-acre (36 ha) meadow, a lake, and extensive <a href="/wiki/Woodland" title="Woodland">woodlands</a>. Within the park is the historic Battle Pass, prominent in the Battle of Long Island.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[227]</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Flushing_Meadows%E2%80%93Corona_Park" title="Flushing Meadows–Corona Park">Flushing Meadows–Corona Park</a> in Queens, with its 897 acres (363 ha) making it the city's fourth largest park,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230"><a href="#cite_note-230">[228]</a></sup> was the setting for the <a href="/wiki/1939_New_York_World%27s_Fair" title="1939 New York World's Fair">1939 World's Fair</a> and the <a href="/wiki/1964_New_York_World%27s_Fair" title="1964 New York World's Fair">1964 World's Fair</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[229]</a></sup> and is host to the <a href="/wiki/USTA_Billie_Jean_King_National_Tennis_Center" title="USTA Billie Jean King National Tennis Center">USTA Billie Jean King National Tennis Center</a> and the annual <a href="/wiki/US_Open_(tennis)" title="US Open (tennis)">U.S. Open Tennis Championships</a> tournament.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232"><a href="#cite_note-232">[230]</a></sup></li>
<li>Over a fifth of the Bronx's area, 7,000 acres (28 km<sup>2</sup>), is dedicated to open space and parks, including Pelham Bay Park, <a href="/wiki/Van_Cortlandt_Park" title="Van Cortlandt Park">Van Cortlandt Park</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Bronx_Zoo" title="Bronx Zoo">Bronx Zoo</a>, and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_York_Botanical_Gardens" title="New York Botanical Gardens">New York Botanical Gardens</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233"><a href="#cite_note-233">[231]</a></sup></li>
<li>In Staten Island, the <a href="/wiki/Conference_House_Park" title="Conference House Park">Conference House Park</a> contains the historic <a href="/wiki/Conference_House" title="Conference House">Conference House</a>, site of the only attempt of a peaceful resolution to the American Revolution which was conducted in September 1775, attended by <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Franklin" title="Benjamin Franklin">Benjamin Franklin</a> representing the Americans and <a href="/wiki/Richard_Howe,_1st_Earl_Howe" title="Richard Howe, 1st Earl Howe">Lord Howe</a> representing the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_Crown" title="British Crown">British Crown</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234"><a href="#cite_note-234">[232]</a></sup> The historic <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Burial_Ridge" title="Burial Ridge">Burial Ridge</a>, the largest Native American burial ground within New York City, is within the park.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235"><a href="#cite_note-235">[233]</a></sup></li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military_installations">Military installations</span></h3>
<p>Brooklyn is home to <a href="/wiki/Fort_Hamilton" title="Fort Hamilton">Fort Hamilton</a>, the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces" title="United States Armed Forces">U.S. military's</a> only active duty installation within New York City,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236"><a href="#cite_note-236">[234]</a></sup> aside from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._Coast_Guard" title="U.S. Coast Guard">Coast Guard</a> operations. The facility was established in 1825 on the site of a small <a href="/wiki/Artillery_battery" title="Artillery battery">battery</a> utilized during the <a href="/wiki/American_Revolution" title="American Revolution">American Revolution</a>, and it is one of America's longest serving military forts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237"><a href="#cite_note-237">[235]</a></sup> Today, Fort Hamilton serves as the headquarters of the <a href="/wiki/North_Atlantic_Division" title="North Atlantic Division">North Atlantic Division</a> of the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Army_Corps_of_Engineers" title="United States Army Corps of Engineers">United States Army Corps of Engineers</a> and for the New York City Recruiting Battalion. It also houses the 1179th Transportation Brigade, the 722nd Aeromedical Staging Squadron, and a military entrance processing station. Other formerly active military reservations still utilized for <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States_National_Guard" title="United States National Guard">National Guard</a> and military training or reserve operations in the city include <a href="/wiki/Fort_Wadsworth" title="Fort Wadsworth">Fort Wadsworth</a> in Staten Island and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fort_Totten_(New_York)" title="Fort Totten (New York)">Fort Totten</a> in Queens.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<table class="toccolours" style="width:15em;border-top-width:0;border-spacing: 0;float:right;clear:right;margin:0.5em 0 1em 0.5em;"><caption style="border-top:1px #aaa solid;border-left:1px #aaa solid #bbbbbb">4,766,883</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">+38.7%</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">1920</th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">5,620,048</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+17.9%</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">1930</th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">6,930,446</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+23.3%</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">1940</th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">7,454,995</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+7.6%</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">1950</th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">7,891,957</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+5.9%</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">1960</th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">7,781,984</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">−1.4%</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">1970</th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">7,894,862</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+1.5%</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">1980</th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">7,071,639</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">−10.4%</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">1990</th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">7,322,564</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+3.5%</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">2000</th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">8,008,278</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+9.4%</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">2010</th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">8,175,133</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">+2.1%</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">2020</th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">8,804,190</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+7.7%</td></tr><tr><td colspan="3" style="border-top:1px solid black;font-size:85%;text-align:left"><span class="nowrap">Note: Census figures (1790–2010) cover</span> the present area of all five boroughs, before and after the 1898 consolidation. For New York City itself before annexing part of the Bronx in 1874, see <a href="/wiki/Manhattan#Demographics" title="Manhattan">Manhattan#Demographics</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EncNYC_238-0"><a href="#cite_note-EncNYC-238">[236]</a></sup><br/>Source: U.S. Decennial Census;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DecennialCensus_239-0"><a href="#cite_note-DecennialCensus-239">[237]</a></sup><br/>1698–1771<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240">[238]</a></sup> 1790–1890<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EncNYC_238-1"><a href="#cite_note-EncNYC-238">[236]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[239]</a></sup><br/>1900–1990<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242"><a href="#cite_note-242">[240]</a></sup> 2000–2010<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243"><a href="#cite_note-243">[241]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244">[242]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sam_Roberts_245-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sam_Roberts-245">[243]</a></sup><br/>2010–2020<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2020Census_246-0"><a href="#cite_note-2020Census-246">[244]</a></sup></td></tr></tbody></table>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_New_York_City" title="Demographics of New York City">Demographics of New York City</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_ethnic_enclaves" title="New York City ethnic enclaves">New York City ethnic enclaves</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Demographic_profile_of_New_York_City" title="Demographic profile of New York City">Demographic profile of New York City</a></div>
