<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Wall_Street" title="Wall Street">Wall Street</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Manhattan_in_the_distance_(Unsplash).jpg"><img alt="see caption" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3718" data-file-width="5577" decoding="async" height="200" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Manhattan_in_the_distance_%28Unsplash%29.jpg/300px-Manhattan_in_the_distance_%28Unsplash%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Manhattan_in_the_distance_%28Unsplash%29.jpg/450px-Manhattan_in_the_distance_%28Unsplash%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Manhattan_in_the_distance_%28Unsplash%29.jpg/600px-Manhattan_in_the_distance_%28Unsplash%29.jpg 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Manhattan_in_the_distance_(Unsplash).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/FiDi_(Manhattan)" title="FiDi (Manhattan)">Financial District</a> of <a href="/wiki/Lower_Manhattan" title="Lower Manhattan">Lower Manhattan</a> including <a href="/wiki/Wall_Street" title="Wall Street">Wall Street</a>, the world's principal <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Financial_center" title="Financial center">financial center</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYCFinancialCapitalWorld_39-1"><a href="#cite_note-NYCFinancialCapitalWorld-39">[39]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-363"><a href="#cite_note-363">[361]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>New York City's most important <a href="/wiki/Economic_sector" title="Economic sector">economic sector</a> lies in its role as the headquarters for the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Financial_center" title="Financial center">U.S. financial industry</a>, metonymously known as <i>Wall Street</i>. The city's <a href="/wiki/Security_(finance)" title="Security (finance)">securities</a> industry continues to form the largest segment of the city's financial sector and is an important economic engine. Many large financial companies are headquartered in New York City, and the city is also home to a burgeoning number of financial <a href="/wiki/Startup_company" title="Startup company">startup companies</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Lower_Manhattan" title="Lower Manhattan">Lower Manhattan</a> is home to the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Stock_Exchange" title="New York Stock Exchange">New York Stock Exchange</a>, at <a href="/wiki/New_York_Stock_Exchange_Building" title="New York Stock Exchange Building">11 Wall Street</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Nasdaq" title="Nasdaq">Nasdaq</a>, at <a href="/wiki/One_Liberty_Plaza" title="One Liberty Plaza">165 Broadway</a>, representing the world's largest and second largest <a href="/wiki/Stock_exchange" title="Stock exchange">stock exchanges</a>, respectively, when measured both by overall average daily trading volume and by total <a href="/wiki/Market_capitalization" title="Market capitalization">market capitalization</a> of their listed companies in 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYSElargest_364-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYSElargest-364">[362]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYSEhighestcap_365-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYSEhighestcap-365">[363]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Investment_banking" title="Investment banking">Investment banking</a> fees on Wall Street totaled approximately $40 billion in 2012,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366"><a href="#cite_note-366">[364]</a></sup> while in 2013, senior New York City bank officers who manage <a href="/wiki/Risk_management" title="Risk management">risk and compliance</a> functions earned as much as $324,000 annually.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367"><a href="#cite_note-367">[365]</a></sup> In fiscal year 2013–14, Wall Street's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Securities_industry" title="Securities industry">securities industry</a> generated 19% of New York State's tax revenue.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[366]</a></sup>
</p><p>New York City remains the largest global center for trading in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Public_equity" title="Public equity">public equity</a> and <a href="/wiki/Security_(finance)" title="Security (finance)">debt</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Capital_markets" title="Capital markets">capital markets</a>, driven in part by the size and <a href="/wiki/Financial_Development_Index" title="Financial Development Index">financial development</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._economy" title="U.S. economy">U.S. economy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CNY2007_369-0"><a href="#cite_note-CNY2007-369">[367]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 31–32">: 31–32 </span></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[368]</a></sup> New York also leads in <a href="/wiki/Hedge_fund" title="Hedge fund">hedge fund</a> management; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_private_equity_firms" title="List of private equity firms">private equity</a>; and the monetary volume of <a href="/wiki/Mergers_and_acquisitions" title="Mergers and acquisitions">mergers and acquisitions</a>. Several <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Investment_Banking" title="Investment Banking">investment banks</a> and <a href="/wiki/Investment_management" title="Investment management">investment managers</a> headquartered in Manhattan are important participants in other global financial centers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CNY2007_369-1"><a href="#cite_note-CNY2007-369">[367]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 34–35">: 34–35 </span></sup> New York is also the principal <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Commercial_banking" title="Commercial banking">commercial banking</a> center of the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371">[369]</a></sup>
</p><p>Many of the world's largest <a href="/wiki/Media_conglomerate" title="Media conglomerate">media conglomerates</a> are also based in the city. Manhattan contained over 500 million square feet (46.5 million m<sup>2</sup>) of office space in 2018,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ManhattanOfficeSpace_372-0"><a href="#cite_note-ManhattanOfficeSpace-372">[370]</a></sup> making it the largest office market in the United States,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373"><a href="#cite_note-373">[371]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Midtown_Manhattan" title="Midtown Manhattan">Midtown Manhattan</a>, with 400 million square feet (37.2 million m<sup>2</sup>) in 2018,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ManhattanOfficeSpace_372-1"><a href="#cite_note-ManhattanOfficeSpace-372">[370]</a></sup> is the largest central business district in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-374"><a href="#cite_note-374">[372]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tech_and_biotech">Tech and biotech</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Tech:NYC" title="Tech:NYC">Tech:NYC</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tech_companies_in_New_York_City" title="Tech companies in New York City">Tech companies in New York City</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Biotech_companies_in_New_York_City" title="Biotech companies in New York City">Biotech companies in New York City</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Silicon_Alley" title="Silicon Alley">Silicon Alley</a></div>
<p>Silicon Alley, centered in New York, has evolved into a <a href="/wiki/Metonymy" title="Metonymy">metonym</a> for the sphere encompassing the metropolitan region's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/High_technology" title="High technology">high technology</a> industries<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-375"><a href="#cite_note-375">[373]</a></sup> involving the <a href="/wiki/Internet" title="Internet">internet</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_media" title="New media">new media</a>, <a href="/wiki/Financial_technology" title="Financial technology">financial technology</a> (<i>fintech</i>) and <a href="/wiki/Cryptocurrency" title="Cryptocurrency">cryptocurrency</a>, <a href="/wiki/Telecommunications" title="Telecommunications">telecommunications</a>, <a href="/wiki/Digital_media" title="Digital media">digital media</a>, <a href="/wiki/Software_development" title="Software development">software development</a>, <a href="/wiki/Biotechnology" title="Biotechnology">biotechnology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Game_design" title="Game design">game design</a>, and other fields within <a href="/wiki/Information_technology" title="Information technology">information technology</a> that are supported by its <a href="/wiki/Entrepreneurship_ecosystem" title="Entrepreneurship ecosystem">entrepreneurship ecosystem</a> and <a href="/wiki/Venture_capital" title="Venture capital">venture capital</a> investments.
</p><p>High technology <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Startup_companies" title="Startup companies">startup companies</a> and employment are growing in New York City and the region. The technology sector has been claiming a greater share of New York City's economy since 2010.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TechNYC1_376-0"><a href="#cite_note-TechNYC1-376">[374]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tech:NYC" title="Tech:NYC">Tech:NYC</a>, founded in 2016, is a non-profit organization which represents New York City's technology industry with government, civic institutions, in business, and in the media, and whose primary goals are to further augment New York's substantial tech talent base and to advocate for policies that will nurture tech companies to grow in the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-377"><a href="#cite_note-377">[375]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Biotech_and_pharmaceutical_companies_in_the_New_Jersey/New_York_metropolitan_region" title="Biotech and pharmaceutical companies in the New Jersey/New York metropolitan region">biotechnology</a> sector is also growing in New York City, based upon the city's strength in academic <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scientific_research" title="Scientific research">scientific research</a> and public and commercial financial support. On December 19, 2011, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced his choice of <a href="/wiki/Cornell_University" title="Cornell University">Cornell University</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Technion-Israel_Institute_of_Technology" title="Technion-Israel Institute of Technology">Technion-Israel Institute of Technology</a> to build a $2 billion <a href="/wiki/Graduate_school" title="Graduate school">graduate school</a> of <a href="/wiki/Applied_science" title="Applied science">applied sciences</a> called <a href="/wiki/Cornell_Tech" title="Cornell Tech">Cornell Tech</a> on <a href="/wiki/Roosevelt_Island" title="Roosevelt Island">Roosevelt Island</a> with the goal of transforming New York City into the world's premier technology capital.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-378"><a href="#cite_note-378">[376]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-379"><a href="#cite_note-379">[377]</a></sup> By mid-2014, Accelerator, a biotech investment firm, had raised more than $30 million from investors, including <a href="/wiki/Eli_Lilly_and_Company" title="Eli Lilly and Company">Eli Lilly and Company</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pfizer" title="Pfizer">Pfizer</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Johnson_%26_Johnson" title="Johnson &amp; Johnson">Johnson &amp; Johnson</a>, for initial funding to create biotechnology <a href="/wiki/Startup_company" title="Startup company">startups</a> at the Alexandria Center for Life Science, which encompasses more than 700,000 square feet (65,000 m<sup>2</sup>) on <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/29th_Street_(Manhattan)" title="29th Street (Manhattan)">East 29th Street</a> and promotes collaboration among scientists and entrepreneurs at the center and with nearby academic, medical, and research institutions. The <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Economic_Development_Corporation" title="New York City Economic Development Corporation">New York City Economic Development Corporation</a>'s Early Stage Life Sciences Funding Initiative and venture capital partners, including <a href="/wiki/Celgene" title="Celgene">Celgene</a>, <a href="/wiki/General_Electric" title="General Electric">General Electric</a> Ventures, and Eli Lilly, committed a minimum of $100 million to help launch 15 to 20 ventures in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Life_sciences" title="Life sciences">life sciences</a> and biotechnology.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-380"><a href="#cite_note-380">[378]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Real_estate">Real estate</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Time_Warner_Center_May_2010.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4000" data-file-width="3000" decoding="async" height="293" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Time_Warner_Center_May_2010.JPG/220px-Time_Warner_Center_May_2010.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Time_Warner_Center_May_2010.JPG/330px-Time_Warner_Center_May_2010.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Time_Warner_Center_May_2010.JPG/440px-Time_Warner_Center_May_2010.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Time_Warner_Center_May_2010.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Deutsche_Bank_Center" title="Deutsche Bank Center">Deutsche Bank Center</a> as viewed from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Central_Park_West" title="Central Park West">Central Park West</a></div></div></div>
<p>Real estate is a major force in the city's economy, as the total value of all New York City property was assessed at US$1.072 trillion for the 2017 <a href="/wiki/Fiscal_year" title="Fiscal year">fiscal year</a>, an increase of 10.6% from the previous year, with 89% of the increase coming from market effects.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYC_real_estate_381-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYC_real_estate-381">[379]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Deutsche_Bank_Center" title="Deutsche Bank Center">Deutsche Bank Center</a> is the property with the highest-listed market value in the city, at $1.1 billion in 2006.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYC_real_estate_381-1"><a href="#cite_note-NYC_real_estate-381">[379]</a></sup> New York City is home to some of the nation's—and the world's—most valuable real estate. 450 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Park_Avenue_(Manhattan)" title="Park Avenue (Manhattan)">Park Avenue</a> was sold on July 2, 2007, for $510 million, about $1,589 per square foot ($17,104/m<sup>2</sup>), breaking the barely month-old record for an American office building of $1,476 per square foot ($15,887/m<sup>2</sup>) set in the June 2007 sale of 660 Madison Avenue.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382"><a href="#cite_note-382">[380]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2014, Manhattan was home to six of the top ten <a href="/wiki/ZIP_Code" title="ZIP Code">ZIP codes</a> in the United States by median housing price.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383"><a href="#cite_note-383">[381]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Fifth_Avenue" title="Fifth Avenue">Fifth Avenue</a> in Midtown Manhattan commands the highest retail rents in the world, at $3,000 per square foot ($32,000/m<sup>2</sup>) in 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-384"><a href="#cite_note-384">[382]</a></sup> In 2019, the most expensive home sale ever in the United States achieved completion in Manhattan, at a selling price of $238 million, for a 24,000 square feet (2,200 m<sup>2</sup>) <a href="/wiki/Penthouse_apartment" title="Penthouse apartment">penthouse apartment</a> overlooking <a href="/wiki/Central_Park" title="Central Park">Central Park</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-385"><a href="#cite_note-385">[383]</a></sup> In 2022, one-bedroom apartments in Manhattan rented at a median monthly price of US$3,600.00, one of the world's highest.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_New_York_City" title="Tourism in New York City">Tourism in New York City</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:1_times_square_night_2013.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4912" data-file-width="7360" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/1_times_square_night_2013.jpg/220px-1_times_square_night_2013.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/1_times_square_night_2013.jpg/330px-1_times_square_night_2013.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/1_times_square_night_2013.jpg/440px-1_times_square_night_2013.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:1_times_square_night_2013.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Times_Square" title="Times Square">Times Square</a> is the hub of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Broadway_theater" title="Broadway theater">Broadway theater</a> <a href="/wiki/Theater_District,_Manhattan" title="Theater District, Manhattan">district</a> and a media center. It also has one of the highest annual attendance rates of any tourist attraction in the world, estimated at 50 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ann_Shields_29-2"><a href="#cite_note-Ann_Shields-29">[29]</a></sup></div></div></div><p>
Tourism is a vital industry for New York City, and <a href="/wiki/NYC_%26_Company" title="NYC &amp; Company">NYC &amp; Company</a> represents the city's official bureau of tourism. New York has witnessed a growing combined volume of international and domestic tourists, reflecting over 60 million visitors to the city per year, the world's busiest tourist destination. Approximately 12 million visitors to New York City have been from outside the United States, with the highest numbers from the United Kingdom, Canada, Brazil, and China.</p><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:I_Love_New_York.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="279" data-file-width="300" decoding="async" height="205" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/I_Love_New_York.svg/220px-I_Love_New_York.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/I_Love_New_York.svg/330px-I_Love_New_York.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/I_Love_New_York.svg/440px-I_Love_New_York.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:I_Love_New_York.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <i><a href="/wiki/I_Love_New_York" title="I Love New York">I Love New York</a></i> logo, designed by <a href="/wiki/Milton_Glaser" title="Milton Glaser">Milton Glaser</a> in 1977</div></div></div><p><i><a href="/wiki/I_Love_New_York" title="I Love New York">I Love New York</a></i> (stylized I <span style="color:red;">❤</span> NY) is both a <a href="/wiki/Logo" title="Logo">logo</a> and a song that are the basis of an advertising campaign and have been used since 1977 to promote <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_New_York_City" title="Tourism in New York City">tourism in New York City</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-386"><a href="#cite_note-386">[384]</a></sup> and later to promote New York State as well. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trademarked" title="Trademarked">trademarked</a> logo, owned by <a href="/wiki/Empire_State_Development_Corporation" title="Empire State Development Corporation">New York State Empire State Development</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-387"><a href="#cite_note-387">[385]</a></sup> appears in souvenir shops and brochures throughout the city and state, some licensed, many not. The song is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_U.S._state_songs" title="List of U.S. state songs">state song</a> of New York.
</p><p>The majority of the most high-profile tourist destinations to the city are situated in Manhattan. These include <a href="/wiki/Times_Square" title="Times Square">Times Square</a>; <a href="/wiki/Broadway_theatre" title="Broadway theatre">Broadway theater</a> productions; the <a href="/wiki/Empire_State_Building" title="Empire State Building">Empire State Building</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Statue_of_Liberty" title="Statue of Liberty">Statue of Liberty</a>; <a href="/wiki/Ellis_Island" title="Ellis Island">Ellis Island</a>; the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_Nations_Headquarters" title="United Nations Headquarters">United Nations Headquarters</a>; the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Center_(2001%E2%80%93present)" title="World Trade Center (2001–present)">World Trade Center</a> (including the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_September_11_Museum" title="National September 11 Museum">National September 11 Museum</a> and <a href="/wiki/One_World_Trade_Center" title="One World Trade Center">One World Trade Center</a>); the art museums along <a href="/wiki/Fifth_Avenue#Museum_Mile" title="Fifth Avenue">Museum Mile</a>; green spaces such as <a href="/wiki/Central_Park" title="Central Park">Central Park</a>, <a href="/wiki/Washington_Square_Park" title="Washington Square Park">Washington Square Park</a>, the <a href="/wiki/High_Line" title="High Line">High Line</a>, and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Medieval_garden" title="Medieval garden">medieval gardens</a> of <a href="/wiki/The_Cloisters" title="The Cloisters">The Cloisters</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Stonewall_Inn" title="Stonewall Inn">Stonewall Inn</a>; <a href="/wiki/Rockefeller_Center" title="Rockefeller Center">Rockefeller Center</a>; ethnic enclaves including the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Manhattan_Chinatown" title="Manhattan Chinatown">Manhattan Chinatown</a>, <a href="/wiki/Koreatown,_Manhattan" title="Koreatown, Manhattan">Koreatown</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Curry_Hill" title="Curry Hill">Curry Hill</a>, <a href="/wiki/Harlem" title="Harlem">Harlem</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spanish_Harlem" title="Spanish Harlem">Spanish Harlem</a>, <a href="/wiki/Little_Italy" title="Little Italy">Little Italy</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Little_Australia,_Manhattan" title="Little Australia, Manhattan">Little Australia</a>; <a href="/wiki/Luxury_goods" title="Luxury goods">luxury</a> shopping along <a href="/wiki/Fifth_Avenue" title="Fifth Avenue">Fifth</a> and <a href="/wiki/Madison_Avenue" title="Madison Avenue">Madison Avenues</a>; and events such as the <a href="/wiki/New_York%27s_Village_Halloween_Parade" title="New York's Village Halloween Parade">Halloween Parade</a> in <a href="/wiki/Greenwich_Village" title="Greenwich Village">Greenwich Village</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn_Bridge" title="Brooklyn Bridge">Brooklyn Bridge</a> (shared with Brooklyn); the <a href="/wiki/Macy%27s_Thanksgiving_Day_Parade" title="Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade">Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade</a>; the lighting of the <a href="/wiki/Rockefeller_Center_Christmas_Tree" title="Rockefeller Center Christmas Tree">Rockefeller Center Christmas Tree</a>; the <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_St._Patrick%27s_Day_Parade" title="New York City St. Patrick's Day Parade">St. Patrick's Day Parade</a>; seasonal activities such as ice skating in Central Park in the wintertime; the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tribeca_Film_Festival" title="Tribeca Film Festival">Tribeca Film Festival</a>; and free performances in Central Park at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/SummerStage" title="SummerStage">SummerStage</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-388"><a href="#cite_note-388">[386]</a></sup>
</p><p>Points of interest have also developed in the city outside Manhattan and have made the outer boroughs tourist destinations in their own right. These include numerous ethnic enclaves; the <a href="/wiki/Unisphere" title="Unisphere">Unisphere</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Flushing_Meadows-Corona_Park" title="Flushing Meadows-Corona Park">Flushing Meadows-Corona Park</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Downtown_Flushing" title="Downtown Flushing">Downtown Flushing</a> in Queens; <a href="/wiki/Downtown_Brooklyn" title="Downtown Brooklyn">Downtown Brooklyn</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coney_Island" title="Coney Island">Coney Island</a>, <a href="/wiki/Williamsburg,_Brooklyn" title="Williamsburg, Brooklyn">Williamsburg</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Park_Slope,_Brooklyn" title="Park Slope, Brooklyn">Park Slope</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Prospect_Park_(Brooklyn)" title="Prospect Park (Brooklyn)">Prospect Park</a> in Brooklyn; the <a href="/wiki/Bronx_Zoo" title="Bronx Zoo">Bronx Zoo</a>, the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Botanical_Garden" title="New York Botanical Garden">New York Botanical Garden</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Concourse_(Bronx)" title="Grand Concourse (Bronx)">Grand Concourse</a> in the Bronx; and the <a href="/wiki/Staten_Island_Ferry" title="Staten Island Ferry">Staten Island Ferry</a> shuttling passengers between  Staten Island and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/South_Ferry_Terminal" title="South Ferry Terminal">South Ferry Terminal</a> bordering <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Battery_Park" title="Battery Park">Battery Park</a> in <a href="/wiki/Lower_Manhattan" title="Lower Manhattan">Lower Manhattan</a>, at the historical birthplace of New York City.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media_and_entertainment">Media and entertainment</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Media_in_New_York_City" title="Media in New York City">Media in New York City</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/New_Yorkers_in_journalism" title="New Yorkers in journalism">New Yorkers in journalism</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Rockefeller_Center_2_(New_York)_(44331718505).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2920" data-file-width="5184" decoding="async" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Rockefeller_Center_2_%28New_York%29_%2844331718505%29.jpg/220px-Rockefeller_Center_2_%28New_York%29_%2844331718505%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Rockefeller_Center_2_%28New_York%29_%2844331718505%29.jpg/330px-Rockefeller_Center_2_%28New_York%29_%2844331718505%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Rockefeller_Center_2_%28New_York%29_%2844331718505%29.jpg/440px-Rockefeller_Center_2_%28New_York%29_%2844331718505%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Rockefeller_Center_2_(New_York)_(44331718505).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Rockefeller_Center" title="Rockefeller Center">Rockefeller Center</a> is one of Manhattan's <a href="/wiki/Media_in_New_York_City" title="Media in New York City">media and entertainment hubs</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>New York City has been described as the <a href="/wiki/Digital_media" title="Digital media">digital media</a> capital of the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-389"><a href="#cite_note-389">[387]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-390"><a href="#cite_note-390">[388]</a></sup> The city is a prominent location for the American <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Entertainment_industry" title="Entertainment industry">entertainment industry</a>, with many films, television series, books, and other media being set there.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-391"><a href="#cite_note-391">[389]</a></sup> As of 2012<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=New_York_City&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, New York City was the second largest center for filmmaking and television production in the United States, producing about 200 feature films annually, employing 130,000 individuals. The filmed entertainment industry has been growing in New York, contributing nearly $9 billion to the New York City economy alone as of 2015.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392"><a href="#cite_note-392">[390]</a></sup> By volume, New York is the world leader in <a href="/wiki/Independent_film" title="Independent film">independent film</a> production—one-third of all American independent films are produced there.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-393"><a href="#cite_note-393">[391]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYC_Media_394-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYC_Media-394">[392]</a></sup> The Association of Independent Commercial Producers is also based in New York.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-395"><a href="#cite_note-395">[393]</a></sup> In the first five months of 2014 alone, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Location_filming" title="Location filming">location filming</a> for television pilots in New York City exceeded the record production levels for all of 2013,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-396"><a href="#cite_note-396">[394]</a></sup> with New York surpassing Los Angeles as the top North American city for the same distinction during the 2013–2014 cycle.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-397"><a href="#cite_note-397">[395]</a></sup>
</p><p>New York City is the center for the <a href="/wiki/Advertising" title="Advertising">advertising</a>, music, newspaper, digital media, and publishing industries and is also the largest media market in North America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-398"><a href="#cite_note-398">[396]</a></sup> Some of the city's <a href="/wiki/Media_conglomerate" title="Media conglomerate">media conglomerates</a> and institutions include <a href="/wiki/Warner_Bros._Discovery" title="Warner Bros. Discovery">Warner Bros. Discovery</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Thomson_Reuters_Corporation" title="Thomson Reuters Corporation">Thomson Reuters Corporation</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Associated_Press" title="Associated Press">Associated Press</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bloomberg_L.P." title="Bloomberg L.P.">Bloomberg L.P.</a>, the <a href="/wiki/News_Corp" title="News Corp">News Corp</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times_Company" title="The New York Times Company">The New York Times Company</a>, <a href="/wiki/NBCUniversal" title="NBCUniversal">NBCUniversal</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hearst_Corporation" title="Hearst Corporation">Hearst Corporation</a>, <a href="/wiki/AOL" title="AOL">AOL</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fox_Corporation" title="Fox Corporation">Fox Corporation</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Paramount_Global" title="Paramount Global">Paramount Global</a>. Seven of the world's top eight global <a href="/wiki/Advertising_agency" title="Advertising agency">advertising agency</a> networks have their headquarters in New York.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399"><a href="#cite_note-399">[397]</a></sup> Two of the top three <a href="/wiki/Music_industry" title="Music industry">record labels'</a> headquarters are in New York: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sony_Music_Entertainment" title="Sony Music Entertainment">Sony Music Entertainment</a> and <a href="/wiki/Warner_Music_Group" title="Warner Music Group">Warner Music Group</a>. <a href="/wiki/Universal_Music_Group" title="Universal Music Group">Universal Music Group</a> also has offices in New York. <a href="/wiki/New_media" title="New media">New media</a> enterprises are contributing an increasingly important component to the city's central role in the media sphere.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:177px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Times_Square_Studios_-_GMA_(48105884053).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="3456" decoding="async" height="175" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Times_Square_Studios_-_GMA_%2848105884053%29.jpg/175px-Times_Square_Studios_-_GMA_%2848105884053%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Times_Square_Studios_-_GMA_%2848105884053%29.jpg/263px-Times_Square_Studios_-_GMA_%2848105884053%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Times_Square_Studios_-_GMA_%2848105884053%29.jpg/350px-Times_Square_Studios_-_GMA_%2848105884053%29.jpg 2x" width="175"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Times_Square_Studios_-_GMA_(48105884053).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Times_Square_Studios" title="Times Square Studios">Times Square Studios</a> is situated at the <a href="/wiki/Times_Square" title="Times Square">"Crossroads of the World"</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>More than 200 newspapers and 350 consumer magazines have an office in the city,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYC_Media_394-1"><a href="#cite_note-NYC_Media-394">[392]</a></sup> and the publishing industry employs about 25,000 people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-400"><a href="#cite_note-400">[398]</a></sup> Two of the three national daily newspapers with the largest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Circulation_(newspaper)" title="Circulation (newspaper)">circulations</a> in the United States are published in New York: <i><a href="/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal" title="The Wall Street Journal">The Wall Street Journal</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i>, which has won the most <a href="/wiki/Pulitzer_Prize" title="Pulitzer Prize">Pulitzer Prizes</a> for <a href="/wiki/New_Yorkers_in_journalism" title="New Yorkers in journalism">journalism</a> and is considered the U.S. media's "newspaper of record".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYTNewspaperOfRecord_27-1"><a href="#cite_note-NYTNewspaperOfRecord-27">[27]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tabloid_(newspaper_format)" title="Tabloid (newspaper format)">Tabloid</a> newspapers in the city include <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Daily_News_(New_York)" title="Daily News (New York)">The New York Daily News</a></i>, which was founded in 1919 by <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Medill_Patterson" title="Joseph Medill Patterson">Joseph Medill Patterson</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-401"><a href="#cite_note-401">[399]</a></sup> and <i><a href="/wiki/New_York_Post" title="New York Post">The New York Post</a></i>, founded in 1801 by <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Hamilton" title="Alexander Hamilton">Alexander Hamilton</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-402"><a href="#cite_note-402">[400]</a></sup> The city also has a comprehensive ethnic press, with 270 newspapers and magazines published in more than 40 languages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-403"><a href="#cite_note-403">[401]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/El_Diario_La_Prensa" title="El Diario La Prensa">El Diario La Prensa</a></i> is New York's largest <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish-language</a> daily and the oldest in the nation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-404"><a href="#cite_note-404">[402]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/New_York_Amsterdam_News" title="New York Amsterdam News">The New York Amsterdam News</a></i>, published in Harlem, is a prominent African American newspaper. <i><a href="/wiki/The_Village_Voice" title="The Village Voice">The Village Voice</a></i>, historically the largest <a href="/wiki/Alternative_newspaper" title="Alternative newspaper">alternative newspaper</a> in the United States, announced in 2017 that it would cease publication of its print edition and convert to a fully digital venture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VillageVoiceDigital_405-0"><a href="#cite_note-VillageVoiceDigital-405">[403]</a></sup>
The television and radio industry developed in New York and is a significant employer in the city's economy. The three major American <a href="/wiki/Broadcast_network" title="Broadcast network">broadcast networks</a> are all headquartered in New York: <a href="/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company" title="American Broadcasting Company">ABC</a>, <a href="/wiki/CBS" title="CBS">CBS</a>, and <a href="/wiki/NBC" title="NBC">NBC</a>. Many cable networks are based in the city as well, including <a href="/wiki/CNN" title="CNN">CNN</a>, <a href="/wiki/MSNBC" title="MSNBC">MSNBC</a>, <a href="/wiki/MTV" title="MTV">MTV</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fox_News_Channel" title="Fox News Channel">Fox News</a>, <a href="/wiki/HBO" title="HBO">HBO</a>, <a href="/wiki/Showtime_(TV_network)" title="Showtime (TV network)">Showtime</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bravo_(U.S._TV_network)" title="Bravo (U.S. TV network)">Bravo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Food_Network" title="Food Network">Food Network</a>, <a href="/wiki/AMC_(TV_channel)" title="AMC (TV channel)">AMC</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Comedy_Central" title="Comedy Central">Comedy Central</a>. <a href="/wiki/News_12_Networks" title="News 12 Networks">News 12 Networks</a> operated News 12 The Bronx and News 12 Brooklyn. The City of New York operates a public broadcast service, <a href="/wiki/NYC_Media" title="NYC Media">NYC Media</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-406"><a href="#cite_note-406">[404]</a></sup> which has produced several original <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Emmy_Award" title="Emmy Award">Emmy Award</a>-winning shows covering music and culture in city neighborhoods and city government. <a href="/wiki/WBAI" title="WBAI">WBAI</a>, with news and information programming, is one of the few <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Socialist" title="Socialist">socialist</a> radio stations operating in the United States.
</p><p>New York is also a major center for <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Non-commercial_educational" title="Non-commercial educational">non-commercial educational</a> media. The oldest <a href="/wiki/Public-access_television" title="Public-access television">public-access television</a> channel in the United States is the <a href="/wiki/Manhattan_Neighborhood_Network" title="Manhattan Neighborhood Network">Manhattan Neighborhood Network</a>, founded in 1971.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-407"><a href="#cite_note-407">[405]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/WNET" title="WNET">WNET</a> is the city's major public television station and a primary source of national <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Public_Broadcasting_Service" title="Public Broadcasting Service">Public Broadcasting Service</a> (PBS) television programming. <a href="/wiki/WNYC" title="WNYC">WNYC</a>, a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Public_radio" title="Public radio">public radio</a> station owned by the city until 1997, has the largest public radio audience in the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-408"><a href="#cite_note-408">[406]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_New_York_City" title="Education in New York City">Education in New York City</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Primary_and_secondary_education">Primary and secondary education</span></h3>
<p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_York_City_Public_Schools" title="New York City Public Schools">New York City Public Schools</a> system, managed by the <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Department_of_Education" title="New York City Department of Education">New York City Department of Education</a>, is the largest public school system in the United States, serving about 1.1 million students in more than 1,700 separate primary and secondary schools.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-409"><a href="#cite_note-409">[407]</a></sup> The city's public school system includes nine <a href="/wiki/Specialized_high_schools_in_New_York_City" title="Specialized high schools in New York City">specialized high schools</a> to serve academically and artistically <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gifted_student" title="Gifted student">gifted students</a>. The city government pays the <a href="/wiki/Pelham_Public_Schools" title="Pelham Public Schools">Pelham Public Schools</a> to educate a very small, detached section of the Bronx.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gross19970506_410-0"><a href="#cite_note-gross19970506-410">[408]</a></sup>
</p><p>The New York City Charter School Center assists the setup of new <a href="/wiki/Charter_school" title="Charter school">charter schools</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-411"><a href="#cite_note-411">[409]</a></sup> There are approximately 900 additional privately run secular and religious schools in the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-412"><a href="#cite_note-412">[410]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Higher_education_and_research">Higher education and research</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Butler_Library_-_1000px_-_AC.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="660" data-file-width="993" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Butler_Library_-_1000px_-_AC.jpg/220px-Butler_Library_-_1000px_-_AC.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Butler_Library_-_1000px_-_AC.jpg/330px-Butler_Library_-_1000px_-_AC.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Butler_Library_-_1000px_-_AC.jpg/440px-Butler_Library_-_1000px_-_AC.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Butler_Library_-_1000px_-_AC.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Butler_Library" title="Butler Library">Butler Library</a> at <a href="/wiki/Columbia_University" title="Columbia University">Columbia University</a>, described as one of the most beautiful college libraries in the United States<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-413"><a href="#cite_note-413">[411]</a></sup></div></div></div> <div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:NYC_-_Washington_Square_Park_-_Arch.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4000" data-file-width="6000" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/NYC_-_Washington_Square_Park_-_Arch.jpg/220px-NYC_-_Washington_Square_Park_-_Arch.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/NYC_-_Washington_Square_Park_-_Arch.jpg/330px-NYC_-_Washington_Square_Park_-_Arch.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/NYC_-_Washington_Square_Park_-_Arch.jpg/440px-NYC_-_Washington_Square_Park_-_Arch.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:NYC_-_Washington_Square_Park_-_Arch.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Washington_Square_Arch" title="Washington Square Arch">Washington Square Arch</a>, an unofficial icon of both <a href="/wiki/New_York_University" title="New York University">New York University</a> (NYU) and its <a href="/wiki/Greenwich_Village" title="Greenwich Village">Greenwich Village</a> neighborhood</div></div></div>
<p>More than a million students, the highest number of any city in the United States,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-414"><a href="#cite_note-414">[412]</a></sup> are enrolled in New York City's more than 120 higher education institutions, with more than half a million in the <a href="/wiki/City_University_of_New_York" title="City University of New York">City University of New York</a> (CUNY) system alone as of 2020<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=New_York_City&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, including both degree and professional programs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-415"><a href="#cite_note-415">[413]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Academic_Ranking_of_World_Universities" title="Academic Ranking of World Universities">Academic Ranking of World Universities</a>, New York City has, on average, the best higher education institutions of any <a href="/wiki/Global_city" title="Global city">global city</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-416"><a href="#cite_note-416">[414]</a></sup>
</p><p>The public CUNY system is one of the largest universities in the nation, comprising 25 institutions across all five boroughs: senior colleges, <a href="/wiki/Community_college" title="Community college">community colleges</a>, and other graduate/professional schools. The public <a href="/wiki/State_University_of_New_York" title="State University of New York">State University of New York</a> (SUNY) system includes campuses in New York City, including: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/SUNY_Downstate_College_of_Medicine" title="SUNY Downstate College of Medicine">Downstate Health Sciences University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fashion_Institute_of_Technology" title="Fashion Institute of Technology">Fashion Institute of Technology</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/SUNY_Maritime_College" title="SUNY Maritime College">Maritime College</a>, and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/SUNY_College_of_Optometry" title="SUNY College of Optometry">College of Optometry</a>.
</p><p>New York City is home to such notable private universities as <a href="/wiki/Barnard_College" title="Barnard College">Barnard College</a>, <a href="/wiki/Columbia_University" title="Columbia University">Columbia University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cooper_Union" title="Cooper Union">Cooper Union</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fordham_University" title="Fordham University">Fordham University</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_York_University" title="New York University">New York University</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_York_Institute_of_Technology" title="New York Institute of Technology">New York Institute of Technology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rockefeller_University" title="Rockefeller University">Rockefeller University</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Yeshiva_University" title="Yeshiva University">Yeshiva University</a>; several of these universities are ranked among the top universities in the world,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ARWU_417-0"><a href="#cite_note-ARWU-417">[415]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CWUR_418-0"><a href="#cite_note-CWUR-418">[416]</a></sup> while some of the world's most prestigious instituions like <a href="/wiki/Princeton_University" title="Princeton University">Princeton University</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yale_University" title="Yale University">Yale University</a> remain in the <a href="/wiki/New_York_metropolitan_area" title="New York metropolitan area">New York metropolitan area</a>.
</p><p>The city also hosts other smaller private colleges and universities, including many religious and special-purpose institutions, such as: <a href="/wiki/Pace_University" title="Pace University">Pace University</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/St._John%27s_University_(Jamaica,_NY)" title="St. John's University (Jamaica, NY)">St. John's University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Juilliard_School" title="Juilliard School">The Juilliard School</a>, <a href="/wiki/Manhattan_College" title="Manhattan College">Manhattan College</a>, <a href="/wiki/Adelphi_University" title="Adelphi University">Adelphi University</a> - Manhattan, <a href="/wiki/Mercy_College_(New_York)" title="Mercy College (New York)">Mercy College (New York)</a>, <a href="/wiki/College_of_Mount_Saint_Vincent" title="College of Mount Saint Vincent">The College of Mount Saint Vincent</a>, <a href="/wiki/Parsons_School_of_Design" title="Parsons School of Design">Parsons School of Design</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_New_School" title="The New School">The New School</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pratt_Institute" title="Pratt Institute">Pratt Institute</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_York_Film_Academy" title="New York Film Academy">New York Film Academy</a>, <a href="/wiki/School_of_Visual_Arts" title="School of Visual Arts">The School of Visual Arts</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_King%27s_College_(New_York_City)" title="The King's College (New York City)">The King's College</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marymount_Manhattan_College" title="Marymount Manhattan College">Marymount Manhattan College</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Wagner_College" title="Wagner College">Wagner College</a>.
</p><p>Much of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scientific_research" title="Scientific research">scientific research</a> in the city is done in medicine and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Life_sciences" title="Life sciences">life sciences</a>. In 2019, the New York metropolitan area ranked first on the list of cities and metropolitan areas by share of published articles in life sciences.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-419"><a href="#cite_note-419">[417]</a></sup> New York City has the most postgraduate life sciences degrees awarded annually in the United States, with 127 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nobel_laureate" title="Nobel laureate">Nobel laureates</a> having roots in local institutions as of 2005<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=New_York_City&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYC_science_institutions_420-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYC_science_institutions-420">[418]</a></sup> while in 2012, 43,523 licensed physicians were practicing in New York City.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-421"><a href="#cite_note-421">[419]</a></sup>
</p><p>Major biomedical research institutions include <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Memorial_Sloan%E2%80%93Kettering_Cancer_Center" title="Memorial Sloan–Kettering Cancer Center">Memorial Sloan–Kettering Cancer Center</a>, Rockefeller University, <a href="/wiki/SUNY_Downstate_Medical_Center" title="SUNY Downstate Medical Center">SUNY Downstate Medical Center</a>, <a href="/wiki/Albert_Einstein_College_of_Medicine" title="Albert Einstein College of Medicine">Albert Einstein College of Medicine</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mount_Sinai_School_of_Medicine" title="Mount Sinai School of Medicine">Mount Sinai School of Medicine</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Weill_Cornell_Medical_College_of_Cornell_University" title="Weill Cornell Medical College of Cornell University">Weill Cornell Medical College</a>, being joined by the <a href="/wiki/Cornell_University" title="Cornell University">Cornell University</a>/<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Technion-Israel_Institute_of_Technology" title="Technion-Israel Institute of Technology">Technion-Israel Institute of Technology</a> venture on <a href="/wiki/Roosevelt_Island" title="Roosevelt Island">Roosevelt Island</a>. The graduates of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/SUNY_Maritime_College" title="SUNY Maritime College">SUNY Maritime College</a> in the Bronx earned the highest average annual salary of any university graduates in the United States, $144,000 as of 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SUNYMaritime_422-0"><a href="#cite_note-SUNYMaritime-422">[420]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Human_resources">Human resources</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Public_health">Public health</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_York_City_Health_and_Hospitals_Corporation" title="New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation">New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation</a> and <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Department_of_Health_and_Mental_Hygiene" title="New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene">New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:NewYorkPresbyterian-Cornell.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="587" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="161" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/NewYorkPresbyterian-Cornell.jpg/220px-NewYorkPresbyterian-Cornell.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/NewYorkPresbyterian-Cornell.jpg/330px-NewYorkPresbyterian-Cornell.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/NewYorkPresbyterian-Cornell.jpg/440px-NewYorkPresbyterian-Cornell.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:NewYorkPresbyterian-Cornell.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_York-Presbyterian_Hospital" title="New York-Presbyterian Hospital">New York-Presbyterian Hospital</a>, affiliated with <a href="/wiki/Columbia_University" title="Columbia University">Columbia University</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cornell_University" title="Cornell University">Cornell University</a>, the largest hospital and largest private employer in New York City and one of the world's busiest<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-423"><a href="#cite_note-423">[421]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation (HHC) operates the <a href="/wiki/Public_hospital#United_States" title="Public hospital">public hospitals</a> and clinics in New York City. A <a href="/wiki/New_York_state_public-benefit_corporations" title="New York state public-benefit corporations">public benefit corporation</a> with $6.7 billion in annual revenues, HHC is the largest municipal <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Healthcare" title="Healthcare">healthcare</a> system in the United States serving 1.4 million patients, including more than 475,000 uninsured city residents.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HHC1_424-0"><a href="#cite_note-HHC1-424">[422]</a></sup> HHC was created in 1969 by the <a href="/wiki/New_York_State_Legislature" title="New York State Legislature">New York State Legislature</a> as a public benefit corporation (Chapter 1016 of the Laws 1969).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-425"><a href="#cite_note-425">[423]</a></sup> HHC operates 11 <a href="/wiki/Acute_care" title="Acute care">acute care</a> hospitals, five nursing homes, six diagnostic and treatment centers, and more than 70 community-based <a href="/wiki/Primary_care" title="Primary care">primary care</a> sites, serving primarily the poor and working class. HHC's MetroPlus Health Plan is one of the New York area's largest providers of government-sponsored health insurance and is the plan of choice for nearly half a million New Yorkers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Metroplus_426-0"><a href="#cite_note-Metroplus-426">[424]</a></sup>
</p><p>HHC's facilities annually provide millions of New Yorkers services interpreted in more than 190 languages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HHC2_427-0"><a href="#cite_note-HHC2-427">[425]</a></sup> The most well-known hospital in the HHC system is <a href="/wiki/Bellevue_Hospital" title="Bellevue Hospital">Bellevue Hospital</a>, the oldest public hospital in the United States. Bellevue is the designated hospital for treatment of the President of the United States and other <a href="/wiki/List_of_current_heads_of_state_and_government" title="List of current heads of state and government">world leaders</a> if they become sick or injured while in New York City.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Funding_Universe_Web_Site_428-0"><a href="#cite_note-Funding_Universe_Web_Site-428">[426]</a></sup> The president of HHC is Ramanathan Raju, MD, a surgeon and former CEO of the Cook County health system in Illinois.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-429"><a href="#cite_note-429">[427]</a></sup> In August 2017, Mayor <a href="/wiki/Bill_de_Blasio" title="Bill de Blasio">Bill de Blasio</a> signed legislation outlawing pharmacies from selling cigarettes once their existing licenses to do so expired, beginning in 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-430"><a href="#cite_note-430">[428]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Public_safety">Public safety</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Police_and_law_enforcement">Police and law enforcement</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Police_Department" title="New York City Police Department">New York City Police Department</a> and <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_New_York_City" title="Law enforcement in New York City">Law enforcement in New York City</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Police_surveillance_in_New_York_City" title="Police surveillance in New York City">Police surveillance in New York City</a> and <a href="/wiki/Crime_in_New_York_City" title="Crime in New York City">Crime in New York City</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ford_NYPD.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1836" data-file-width="4683" decoding="async" height="86" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Ford_NYPD.jpg/220px-Ford_NYPD.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Ford_NYPD.jpg/330px-Ford_NYPD.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Ford_NYPD.jpg/440px-Ford_NYPD.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ford_NYPD.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Police_Department" title="New York City Police Department">New York Police Department</a> (NYPD) is the largest police force in the United States.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Police_Department" title="New York City Police Department">New York Police Department</a> (NYPD) has been the largest police force in the United States by a significant margin, with more than 35,000 sworn officers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-431"><a href="#cite_note-431">[429]</a></sup> Members of the NYPD are frequently referred to by politicians, the media, and their own police cars by the nickname, <i>New York's Finest</i>.
</p><p>Crime overall has trended downward in New York City since the 1990s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-432"><a href="#cite_note-432">[430]</a></sup> In 2012, the NYPD came under scrutiny for its use of a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_York_City_stop-and-frisk_program" title="New York City stop-and-frisk program">stop-and-frisk</a> program,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-433"><a href="#cite_note-433">[431]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-434"><a href="#cite_note-434">[432]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-435"><a href="#cite_note-435">[433]</a></sup> which has undergone several policy revisions since then. In 2014, New York City had the third lowest murder rate among the largest U.S. cities,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-436"><a href="#cite_note-436">[434]</a></sup> having become significantly safer after a spike in crime in the 1970s through 1990s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Prager_437-0"><a href="#cite_note-Prager-437">[435]</a></sup> Violent crime in New York City decreased more than 75% from 1993 to 2005, and continued decreasing during periods when the nation as a whole saw increases.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Law_438-0"><a href="#cite_note-Law-438">[436]</a></sup> By 2002, New York City was ranked 197th in crime among the 216 U.S. cities with populations greater than 100,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Law_438-1"><a href="#cite_note-Law-438">[436]</a></sup> In 1992, the city recorded 2,245 murders.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Walker2010_439-0"><a href="#cite_note-Walker2010-439">[437]</a></sup> In 2005, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_homicide_rate" title="List of countries by homicide rate">homicide rate</a> was at its lowest level since 1966,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-440"><a href="#cite_note-440">[438]</a></sup> and in 2009, the city recorded fewer than 461 <a href="/wiki/Homicide" title="Homicide">homicides</a> for the first time ever since crime statistics were first published in 1963.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Walker2010_439-1"><a href="#cite_note-Walker2010-439">[437]</a></sup> In 2017, 60.1% of violent crime suspects were Black, 29.6% Hispanic, 6.5% White, 3.6% Asian and 0.2% American Indian.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-441"><a href="#cite_note-441">[439]</a></sup> New York City experienced 292 homicides in 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-442"><a href="#cite_note-442">[440]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:My_picture_of_NYPD_officers.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3024" data-file-width="4032" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/My_picture_of_NYPD_officers.jpg/220px-My_picture_of_NYPD_officers.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/My_picture_of_NYPD_officers.jpg/330px-My_picture_of_NYPD_officers.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/My_picture_of_NYPD_officers.jpg/440px-My_picture_of_NYPD_officers.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:My_picture_of_NYPD_officers.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Police officers of New York Police Department (NYPD)</div></div></div>
<p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sociologist" title="Sociologist">Sociologists</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Criminologist" title="Criminologist">criminologists</a> have not reached consensus on the explanation for the dramatic long-term decrease in the city's crime rate. Some attribute the phenomenon to new tactics used by the NYPD,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-443"><a href="#cite_note-443">[441]</a></sup> including its use of <a href="/wiki/CompStat" title="CompStat">CompStat</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Broken_windows_theory" title="Broken windows theory">broken windows theory</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-444"><a href="#cite_note-444">[442]</a></sup> Others cite the end of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Crack_epidemic" title="Crack epidemic">crack epidemic</a> and demographic changes,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-445"><a href="#cite_note-445">[443]</a></sup> including from immigration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-446"><a href="#cite_note-446">[444]</a></sup> Another theory is that widespread exposure to lead pollution from automobile exhaust, which can lower intelligence and increase aggression levels, incited the initial crime wave in the mid-20th century, most acutely affecting heavily trafficked cities like New York. A strong correlation was found demonstrating that violent crime rates in New York and other big cities began to fall after lead was removed from American gasoline in the 1970s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-447"><a href="#cite_note-447">[445]</a></sup> Another theory cited to explain New York City's falling homicide rate is the inverse correlation between the number of murders and the increasingly wet climate in the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-448"><a href="#cite_note-448">[446]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Organized_crime" title="Organized crime">Organized crime</a> has long been associated with New York City, beginning with the <a href="/wiki/Forty_Thieves_(New_York_gang)" title="Forty Thieves (New York gang)">Forty Thieves</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Roach_Guards" title="Roach Guards">Roach Guards</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Five_Points,_Manhattan" title="Five Points, Manhattan">Five Points</a> neighborhood in the 1820s, followed by the <a href="/wiki/Tong_(organization)" title="Tong (organization)">Tongs</a> in the same neighborhood, which ultimately evolved into <a href="/wiki/Chinatown,_Manhattan" title="Chinatown, Manhattan">Chinatown, Manhattan</a>. The 20th century saw a rise in the <a href="/wiki/American_Mafia" title="American Mafia">Mafia</a>, dominated by the <a href="/wiki/Five_Families" title="Five Families">Five Families</a>, as well as in <a href="/wiki/Gang" title="Gang">gangs</a>, including the <a href="/wiki/Black_Spades" title="Black Spades">Black Spades</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-449"><a href="#cite_note-449">[447]</a></sup> The Mafia and gang presence has declined in the city in the 21st century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-450"><a href="#cite_note-450">[448]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-451"><a href="#cite_note-451">[449]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Firefighting">Firefighting</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Fire_Department" title="New York City Fire Department">New York City Fire Department</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:FDNY_Tower_Ladder_1_(897367891).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="851" data-file-width="1280" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/FDNY_Tower_Ladder_1_%28897367891%29.jpg/220px-FDNY_Tower_Ladder_1_%28897367891%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/FDNY_Tower_Ladder_1_%28897367891%29.jpg/330px-FDNY_Tower_Ladder_1_%28897367891%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/FDNY_Tower_Ladder_1_%28897367891%29.jpg/440px-FDNY_Tower_Ladder_1_%28897367891%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:FDNY_Tower_Ladder_1_(897367891).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Fire_Department" title="New York City Fire Department">Fire Department of New York</a> (FDNY) is the largest municipal fire department in the United States.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Fire_Department" title="New York City Fire Department">Fire Department of New York</a> (FDNY) provides <a href="/wiki/Fire_protection" title="Fire protection">fire protection</a>, technical rescue, primary response to biological, chemical, and radioactive hazards, and <a href="/wiki/Emergency_medical_services" title="Emergency medical services">emergency medical services</a> for the five boroughs of New York City. The FDNY is the largest municipal <a href="/wiki/Fire_department" title="Fire department">fire department</a> in the United States and the second largest in the world after the <a href="/wiki/Tokyo_Fire_Department" title="Tokyo Fire Department">Tokyo Fire Department</a>. The FDNY employs approximately 11,080 uniformed <a href="/wiki/Firefighter" title="Firefighter">firefighters</a> and more than 3,300 uniformed <a href="/wiki/Emergency_medical_technician" title="Emergency medical technician">EMTs</a> and <a href="/wiki/Paramedic" title="Paramedic">paramedics</a>. The FDNY's motto is <i>New York's Bravest</i>.
</p><p>The fire department faces multifaceted firefighting challenges in many ways unique to New York. In addition to responding to <a href="/wiki/List_of_building_types" title="List of building types">building types</a> that range from wood-frame single family homes to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/High-rise" title="High-rise">high-rise structures</a>, the FDNY also responds to fires that occur in the <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Subway" title="New York City Subway">New York City Subway</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-452"><a href="#cite_note-452">[450]</a></sup> Secluded bridges and tunnels, as well as large parks and wooded areas that can give rise to brush fires, also present challenges.
</p><p>The FDNY headquarters is located at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/9_MetroTech_Center" title="9 MetroTech Center">9 MetroTech Center</a> in <a href="/wiki/Downtown_Brooklyn" title="Downtown Brooklyn">Downtown Brooklyn</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-453"><a href="#cite_note-453">[451]</a></sup> and the FDNY Fire Academy is located on <a href="/wiki/Randalls_and_Wards_Islands" title="Randalls and Wards Islands">Randalls Island</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-454"><a href="#cite_note-454">[452]</a></sup> There are three Bureau of Fire Communications alarm offices which receive and dispatch alarms to appropriate units. One office, at 11 Metrotech Center in Brooklyn, houses Manhattan/Citywide, Brooklyn, and Staten Island Fire Communications; the Bronx and Queens offices are in separate buildings.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Public_library_system">Public library system</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Facade_of_the_New_York_Public_Library_Main_Branch_2.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3782" data-file-width="5917" decoding="async" height="141" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Facade_of_the_New_York_Public_Library_Main_Branch_2.jpg/220px-Facade_of_the_New_York_Public_Library_Main_Branch_2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Facade_of_the_New_York_Public_Library_Main_Branch_2.jpg/330px-Facade_of_the_New_York_Public_Library_Main_Branch_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Facade_of_the_New_York_Public_Library_Main_Branch_2.jpg/440px-Facade_of_the_New_York_Public_Library_Main_Branch_2.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Facade_of_the_New_York_Public_Library_Main_Branch_2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Stephen A. Schwarzman Headquarters Building of the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Public_Library" title="New York Public Library">New York Public Library</a>, at <a href="/wiki/Fifth_Avenue" title="Fifth Avenue">5th Avenue</a> and <a href="/wiki/42nd_Street_(Manhattan)" title="42nd Street (Manhattan)">42nd Street</a></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/New_York_Public_Library" title="New York Public Library">New York Public Library</a> (NYPL), which has the largest collection of any public library system in the United States, serves Manhattan, the Bronx, and Staten Island.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-libraryspot_455-0"><a href="#cite_note-libraryspot-455">[453]</a></sup> Queens is served by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Queens_Borough_Public_Library" title="Queens Borough Public Library">Queens Borough Public Library</a> (QPL), the nation's second largest public library system, while the <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn_Public_Library" title="Brooklyn Public Library">Brooklyn Public Library</a> (BPL) serves Brooklyn.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-libraryspot_455-1"><a href="#cite_note-libraryspot-455">[453]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2013, the New York Public Library and the Brooklyn Public Library announced that they would merge their technical services departments into a new department called BookOps. This proposed merger anticipated a savings of $2 million for the Brooklyn Public Library and $1.5 million for the New York Public Library. Although not currently part of the merger, it is expected that the Queens Public Library will eventually share some resources with the other city libraries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-456"><a href="#cite_note-456">[454]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-457"><a href="#cite_note-457">[455]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture_and_contemporary_life">Culture and contemporary life</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_New_York_City" title="Culture of New York City">Culture of New York City</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Broadway_theatre" title="Broadway theatre">Broadway theatre</a>, <a href="/wiki/LGBT_culture_in_New_York_City" title="LGBT culture in New York City">LGBT culture in New York City</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_museums_and_cultural_institutions_in_New_York_City" title="List of museums and cultural institutions in New York City">List of museums and cultural institutions in New York City</a>, <a href="/wiki/Music_of_New_York_City" title="Music of New York City">Music of New York City</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_nightclubs_in_New_York_City" title="List of nightclubs in New York City">List of nightclubs in New York City</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_LGBT_people_from_New_York_City" title="List of LGBT people from New York City">List of LGBT people from New York City</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_people_from_New_York_City" title="List of people from New York City">List of people from New York City</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_York_Fashion_Week" title="New York Fashion Week">New York Fashion Week</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Met_Gala" title="Met Gala">Met Gala</a></div>
<p>New York City has been described as the cultural capital of the world by Manhattan's <a href="/wiki/Baruch_College" title="Baruch College">Baruch College</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cultural4_458-0"><a href="#cite_note-cultural4-458">[456]</a></sup> A book containing a series of essays titled <i>New York, Culture Capital of the World, 1940–1965</i> has also been published as showcased by the <a href="/wiki/National_Library_of_Australia" title="National Library of Australia">National Library of Australia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cultural5_459-0"><a href="#cite_note-cultural5-459">[457]</a></sup> In describing New York, author <a href="/wiki/Tom_Wolfe" title="Tom Wolfe">Tom Wolfe</a> said, "Culture just seems to be in the air, like part of the weather."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-460"><a href="#cite_note-460">[458]</a></sup>
</p><p>Numerous major American cultural movements began in the city, such as the <a href="/wiki/Harlem_Renaissance" title="Harlem Renaissance">Harlem Renaissance</a>, which established the African-American literary canon in the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-461"><a href="#cite_note-461">[459]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-462"><a href="#cite_note-462">[460]</a></sup> The city became the center of <a href="/wiki/Stand-up_comedy" title="Stand-up comedy">stand-up comedy</a> in the early 20th century, <a href="/wiki/Jazz" title="Jazz">jazz</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jazzzz_463-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jazzzz-463">[461]</a></sup> in the 1940s, <a href="/wiki/Abstract_expressionism" title="Abstract expressionism">abstract expressionism</a> in the 1950s, and the birthplace of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hip_hop_culture" title="Hip hop culture">hip hop</a> in the 1970s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BPOHPINY_464-0"><a href="#cite_note-BPOHPINY-464">[462]</a></sup> The city's <a href="/wiki/Punk_subculture" title="Punk subculture">punk</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-465"><a href="#cite_note-465">[463]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Hardcore_punk" title="Hardcore punk">hardcore</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-466"><a href="#cite_note-466">[464]</a></sup> scenes were influential in the 1970s and 1980s. New York has long had a flourishing scene for <a href="/wiki/Jewish_American_literature" title="Jewish American literature">Jewish American literature</a>.
</p><p>The city is the birthplace of many cultural movements, including the <a href="/wiki/Harlem_Renaissance" title="Harlem Renaissance">Harlem Renaissance</a> in literature and visual art; <a href="/wiki/Abstract_expressionism" title="Abstract expressionism">abstract expressionism</a> (also known as the <a href="/wiki/New_York_School_(art)" title="New York School (art)">New York School</a>) in painting; and <a href="/wiki/Hip_hop_music" title="Hip hop music">hip hop</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_173-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto-173">[173]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Punk_rock" title="Punk rock">punk</a>, <a href="/wiki/Salsa_music" title="Salsa music">salsa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Freestyle_music" title="Freestyle music">freestyle</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tin_Pan_Alley" title="Tin Pan Alley">Tin Pan Alley</a>, certain forms of <a href="/wiki/Jazz" title="Jazz">jazz</a>, and (along with <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia" title="Philadelphia">Philadelphia</a>) <a href="/wiki/Disco" title="Disco">disco</a> in music. New York City has been considered the dance capital of the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-467"><a href="#cite_note-467">[465]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-468"><a href="#cite_note-468">[466]</a></sup> The city is also frequently the setting for novels, movies (see <a href="/wiki/List_of_films_set_in_New_York_City" title="List of films set in New York City">List of films set in New York City</a>), and television programs. <a href="/wiki/New_York_Fashion_Week" title="New York Fashion Week">New York Fashion Week</a> is one of the world's preeminent fashion events and is afforded extensive coverage by the media.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-469"><a href="#cite_note-469">[467]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-470"><a href="#cite_note-470">[468]</a></sup> New York has also frequently been ranked the top <a href="/wiki/Fashion_capital" title="Fashion capital">fashion capital</a> of the world on the annual list compiled by the <a href="/wiki/Global_Language_Monitor" title="Global Language Monitor">Global Language Monitor</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-471"><a href="#cite_note-471">[469]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pace">Pace</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Fast-Paced_Streets_of_New_York_City.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4272" data-file-width="2848" decoding="async" height="255" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Fast-Paced_Streets_of_New_York_City.jpg/170px-Fast-Paced_Streets_of_New_York_City.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Fast-Paced_Streets_of_New_York_City.jpg/255px-Fast-Paced_Streets_of_New_York_City.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Fast-Paced_Streets_of_New_York_City.jpg/340px-Fast-Paced_Streets_of_New_York_City.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Fast-Paced_Streets_of_New_York_City.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The fast-paced streets of New York City, January 2020</div></div></div>
