<p>One of the most common traits attributed to New York City is its fast pace,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FastPaceNYC1_472-0"><a href="#cite_note-FastPaceNYC1-472">[470]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FastPaceNYC2_473-0"><a href="#cite_note-FastPaceNYC2-473">[471]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FastPaceNYC3_474-0"><a href="#cite_note-FastPaceNYC3-474">[472]</a></sup> which spawned the term <i><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/New_York_minute" title="wiktionary:New York minute">New York minute</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NewYorkMinuteDefinition_475-0"><a href="#cite_note-NewYorkMinuteDefinition-475">[473]</a></sup> Journalist <a href="/wiki/Walt_Whitman" title="Walt Whitman">Walt Whitman</a> characterized New York's streets as being traversed by "hurrying, feverish, electric crowds".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FastPaceNYC3_474-1"><a href="#cite_note-FastPaceNYC3-474">[472]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Arts">Arts</span></h3>
<p>New York City has more than 2,000 arts and cultural organizations and more than 500 <a href="/wiki/Art_gallery" title="Art gallery">art galleries</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYC_arts_476-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYC_arts-476">[474]</a></sup> The city government funds the arts with a larger annual budget than the <a href="/wiki/National_Endowment_for_the_Arts" title="National Endowment for the Arts">National Endowment for the Arts</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYC_arts_476-1"><a href="#cite_note-NYC_arts-476">[474]</a></sup> Wealthy <a href="/wiki/Business_magnate" title="Business magnate">business magnates</a> in the 19th century built a network of major cultural institutions, such as <a href="/wiki/Carnegie_Hall" title="Carnegie Hall">Carnegie Hall</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Metropolitan_Museum_of_Art" title="The Metropolitan Museum of Art">Metropolitan Museum of Art</a>, which have become internationally renowned. The advent of electric lighting led to elaborate theater productions, and in the 1880s, New York City theaters on <a href="/wiki/Broadway_(Manhattan)" title="Broadway (Manhattan)">Broadway</a> and along 42nd Street began featuring a new stage form that became known as the <a href="/wiki/Musical_theatre" title="Musical theatre">Broadway musical</a>. Strongly influenced by the city's immigrants, productions such as those of <a href="/wiki/Edward_Harrigan" title="Edward Harrigan">Harrigan and Hart</a>, <a href="/wiki/George_M._Cohan" title="George M. Cohan">George M. Cohan</a>, and others used song in narratives that often reflected themes of hope and ambition. New York City itself is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_plays_and_musicals_set_in_New_York_City" title="List of plays and musicals set in New York City">subject or background</a> of many plays and musicals.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Performing_arts">Performing arts</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Broadway_theatre" title="Broadway theatre">Broadway theatre</a> and <a href="/wiki/Music_of_New_York_City" title="Music of New York City">Music of New York City</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lincoln_Center_Twilight.jpg"><img alt="The corner of a lit up plaza with a fountain in the center and the ends of two brightly lit buildings with tall arches on the square." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1501" data-file-width="2000" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Lincoln_Center_Twilight.jpg/220px-Lincoln_Center_Twilight.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Lincoln_Center_Twilight.jpg/330px-Lincoln_Center_Twilight.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Lincoln_Center_Twilight.jpg/440px-Lincoln_Center_Twilight.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lincoln_Center_Twilight.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lincoln_Center_for_the_Performing_Arts" title="Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts">Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts</a></div></div></div>
<p>Broadway theatre is one of the premier forms of English-language theatre in the world, named after <a href="/wiki/Broadway_(Manhattan)" title="Broadway (Manhattan)">Broadway</a>, the major thoroughfare that crosses <a href="/wiki/Times_Square" title="Times Square">Times Square</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-477"><a href="#cite_note-477">[475]</a></sup> also sometimes referred to as "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Great_White_Way" title="The Great White Way">The Great White Way</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-478"><a href="#cite_note-478">[476]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-479"><a href="#cite_note-479">[477]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-480"><a href="#cite_note-480">[478]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/List_of_Broadway_theaters" title="List of Broadway theaters">Forty-one venues</a> in Midtown Manhattan's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Theatre_District,_Manhattan" title="Theatre District, Manhattan">Theatre District</a>, each with at least 500 seats, are classified as Broadway theatres. According to <a href="/wiki/The_Broadway_League" title="The Broadway League">The Broadway League</a>, Broadway shows sold approximately $1.27 billion worth of tickets in the 2013–2014 season, an 11.4% increase from $1.139 billion in the 2012–2013 season. Attendance in 2013–2014 stood at 12.21 million, representing a 5.5% increase from the 2012–2013 season's 11.57 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-league_481-0"><a href="#cite_note-league-481">[479]</a></sup> Performance artists displaying diverse skills are ubiquitous on the streets of Manhattan.
</p><p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lincoln_Center_for_the_Performing_Arts" title="Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts">Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts</a>, anchoring <a href="/wiki/Lincoln_Square,_Manhattan" title="Lincoln Square, Manhattan">Lincoln Square</a> on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, is home to numerous influential arts organizations, including the <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_Opera" title="Metropolitan Opera">Metropolitan Opera</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Opera" title="New York City Opera">New York City Opera</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_York_Philharmonic" title="New York Philharmonic">New York Philharmonic</a>, and <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Ballet" title="New York City Ballet">New York City Ballet</a>, as well as the <a href="/wiki/Vivian_Beaumont_Theater" title="Vivian Beaumont Theater">Vivian Beaumont Theater</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Juilliard_School" title="Juilliard School">Juilliard School</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jazz_at_Lincoln_Center" title="Jazz at Lincoln Center">Jazz at Lincoln Center</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Alice_Tully_Hall" title="Alice Tully Hall">Alice Tully Hall</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Lee_Strasberg_Theatre_and_Film_Institute" title="Lee Strasberg Theatre and Film Institute">Lee Strasberg Theatre and Film Institute</a> is in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Union_Square_(New_York_City)" title="Union Square (New York City)">Union Square</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tisch_School_of_the_Arts" title="Tisch School of the Arts">Tisch School of the Arts</a> is based at New York University, while <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Central_Park_SummerStage" title="Central Park SummerStage">Central Park SummerStage</a> presents free music concerts in Central Park.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-482"><a href="#cite_note-482">[480]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Metropolitan_Museum_of_Art_(The_Met)_-_Central_Park,_NYC.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1488" data-file-width="2666" decoding="async" height="123" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Metropolitan_Museum_of_Art_%28The_Met%29_-_Central_Park%2C_NYC.jpg/220px-Metropolitan_Museum_of_Art_%28The_Met%29_-_Central_Park%2C_NYC.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Metropolitan_Museum_of_Art_%28The_Met%29_-_Central_Park%2C_NYC.jpg/330px-Metropolitan_Museum_of_Art_%28The_Met%29_-_Central_Park%2C_NYC.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Metropolitan_Museum_of_Art_%28The_Met%29_-_Central_Park%2C_NYC.jpg/440px-Metropolitan_Museum_of_Art_%28The_Met%29_-_Central_Park%2C_NYC.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Metropolitan_Museum_of_Art_(The_Met)_-_Central_Park,_NYC.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Metropolitan_Museum_of_Art" title="The Metropolitan Museum of Art">The Metropolitan Museum of Art</a>, part of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Museum_Mile,_New_York_City" title="Museum Mile, New York City">Museum Mile</a>, is one of the largest museums in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-483"><a href="#cite_note-483">[481]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Visual_arts">Visual arts</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/List_of_museums_and_cultural_institutions_in_New_York_City" title="List of museums and cultural institutions in New York City">List of museums and cultural institutions in New York City</a></div>
<p>New York City is home to hundreds of cultural institutions and historic sites. <a href="/wiki/Fifth_Avenue" title="Fifth Avenue">Museum Mile</a> is the name for a section of Fifth Avenue running from 82nd to 105th streets on the <a href="/wiki/Upper_East_Side" title="Upper East Side">Upper East Side</a> of Manhattan,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-festival_484-0"><a href="#cite_note-festival-484">[482]</a></sup> in an area sometimes called Upper <a href="/wiki/Carnegie_Hill" title="Carnegie Hill">Carnegie Hill</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-485"><a href="#cite_note-485">[483]</a></sup> The Mile, which contains one of the densest displays of culture in the world, is actually three blocks longer than one mile (1.6 km). Ten museums occupy the length of this section of Fifth Avenue.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mmilemus_486-0"><a href="#cite_note-mmilemus-486">[484]</a></sup> The tenth museum, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Museum_for_African_Art" title="Museum for African Art">Museum for African Art</a>, joined the ensemble in 2009, although its museum at <a href="/wiki/110th_Street_(Manhattan)" title="110th Street (Manhattan)">110th Street</a>, the first new museum constructed on the Mile since the <a href="/wiki/Solomon_R._Guggenheim_Museum" title="Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum">Guggenheim</a> in 1959,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mafr_487-0"><a href="#cite_note-mafr-487">[485]</a></sup> opened in late 2012. In addition to other programming, the museums collaborate for the annual Museum Mile Festival, held each year in June, to promote the museums and increase visitation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-drv_488-0"><a href="#cite_note-drv-488">[486]</a></sup> Many of the world's most lucrative <a href="/wiki/Art_auction" title="Art auction">art auctions</a> are held in New York City.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYCArtAuction1_489-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYCArtAuction1-489">[487]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYCArtAuction2_490-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYCArtAuction2-490">[488]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Cuisine_of_New_York_City" title="Cuisine of New York City">Cuisine of New York City</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_restaurants_in_New_York_City" title="List of restaurants in New York City">List of restaurants in New York City</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Smorgasburg_in_Dumbo.jpg"><img alt="People crowd around white tents in the foreground next to a red brick wall with arched windows. Above and to the left is a towering stone bridge." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1594" data-file-width="2400" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Smorgasburg_in_Dumbo.jpg/220px-Smorgasburg_in_Dumbo.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Smorgasburg_in_Dumbo.jpg/330px-Smorgasburg_in_Dumbo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Smorgasburg_in_Dumbo.jpg/440px-Smorgasburg_in_Dumbo.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Smorgasburg_in_Dumbo.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Smorgasburg" title="Smorgasburg">Smorgasburg</a> opened in 2011 as an open-air food market and is part of the <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn_Flea" title="Brooklyn Flea">Brooklyn Flea</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-491"><a href="#cite_note-491">[489]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>New York City's food culture includes an array of international cuisines influenced by the city's immigrant history. <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">Central</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_European" title="Eastern European">Eastern European</a> immigrants, especially <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jewish_Americans" title="Jewish Americans">Jewish</a> immigrants from those regions, brought <a href="/wiki/Bagel" title="Bagel">bagels</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cheesecake#North_America" title="Cheesecake">cheesecake</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hot_dog" title="Hot dog">hot dogs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Knish" title="Knish">knishes</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Delicatessens" title="Delicatessens">delicatessens</a> (or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Delis" title="Delis">delis</a>) to the city. <a href="/wiki/Italian_diaspora" title="Italian diaspora">Italian</a> immigrants brought <a href="/wiki/New_York-style_pizza" title="New York-style pizza">New York-style pizza</a> and <a href="/wiki/Italian_cuisine" title="Italian cuisine">Italian cuisine</a> into the city, while Jewish immigrants and <a href="/wiki/Irish_diaspora" title="Irish diaspora">Irish</a> immigrants brought <a href="/wiki/Pastrami" title="Pastrami">pastrami</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-492"><a href="#cite_note-492">[490]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Corned_beef" title="Corned beef">corned beef</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-493"><a href="#cite_note-493">[491]</a></sup> respectively. <a href="/wiki/Chinese_restaurant" title="Chinese restaurant">Chinese</a> and other Asian restaurants, sandwich joints, <a href="/wiki/Trattoria" title="Trattoria">trattorias</a>, <a href="/wiki/Diner" title="Diner">diners</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Coffeehouse" title="Coffeehouse">coffeehouses</a> are ubiquitous throughout the city. Some 4,000 mobile food vendors licensed by the city, many immigrant-owned, have made Middle Eastern foods such as <a href="/wiki/Falafel" title="Falafel">falafel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kebab" title="Kebab">kebabs</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-494"><a href="#cite_note-494">[492]</a></sup> examples of modern New York <a href="/wiki/Street_food" title="Street food">street food</a>. The city is home to "nearly one thousand of the finest and most diverse <a href="/wiki/Haute_cuisine" title="Haute cuisine">haute cuisine</a> restaurants in the world", according to <a href="/wiki/Michelin" title="Michelin">Michelin</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-495"><a href="#cite_note-495">[493]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Department_of_Health_and_Mental_Hygiene" title="New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene">New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene</a> assigns letter grades to the city's restaurants based upon their inspection results.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-496"><a href="#cite_note-496">[494]</a></sup> As of 2019, there were 27,043 restaurants in the city, up from 24,865 in 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-497"><a href="#cite_note-497">[495]</a></sup> The <i>Queens Night Market</i> in <a href="/wiki/Flushing_Meadows%E2%80%93Corona_Park" title="Flushing Meadows–Corona Park">Flushing Meadows–Corona Park</a> attracts more than ten thousand people nightly to sample food from more than 85 countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-QueensNightMarket_498-0"><a href="#cite_note-QueensNightMarket-498">[496]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Parades">Parades</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:362px;max-width:362px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:175px;max-width:175px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:115px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_famous_Macy%27s_Turkey_(3064244803).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2448" data-file-width="3264" decoding="async" height="130" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/The_famous_Macy%27s_Turkey_%283064244803%29.jpg/173px-The_famous_Macy%27s_Turkey_%283064244803%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/The_famous_Macy%27s_Turkey_%283064244803%29.jpg/260px-The_famous_Macy%27s_Turkey_%283064244803%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/The_famous_Macy%27s_Turkey_%283064244803%29.jpg/346px-The_famous_Macy%27s_Turkey_%283064244803%29.jpg 2x" width="173"/></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:183px;max-width:183px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:115px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Greenwich_Village_Halloween_Parade_(6451249051).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1063" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Greenwich_Village_Halloween_Parade_%286451249051%29.jpg/181px-Greenwich_Village_Halloween_Parade_%286451249051%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Greenwich_Village_Halloween_Parade_%286451249051%29.jpg/272px-Greenwich_Village_Halloween_Parade_%286451249051%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Greenwich_Village_Halloween_Parade_%286451249051%29.jpg/362px-Greenwich_Village_Halloween_Parade_%286451249051%29.jpg 2x" width="181"/></a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:175px;max-width:175px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:115px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Apollo_11_ticker_tape_parade_2.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="3895" data-file-width="5796" decoding="async" height="116" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Apollo_11_ticker_tape_parade_2.jpg/173px-Apollo_11_ticker_tape_parade_2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Apollo_11_ticker_tape_parade_2.jpg/260px-Apollo_11_ticker_tape_parade_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Apollo_11_ticker_tape_parade_2.jpg/346px-Apollo_11_ticker_tape_parade_2.jpg 2x" width="173"/></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:183px;max-width:183px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:115px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Pinoydayparade2.JPG"><img alt="" data-file-height="1944" data-file-width="2592" decoding="async" height="136" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Pinoydayparade2.JPG/181px-Pinoydayparade2.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Pinoydayparade2.JPG/272px-Pinoydayparade2.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Pinoydayparade2.JPG/362px-Pinoydayparade2.JPG 2x" width="181"/></a></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flex"><div class="thumbcaption">Clockwise, from upper left: the annual <a href="/wiki/Macy%27s_Thanksgiving_Day_Parade" title="Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade">Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade</a>, the world's largest parade;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYCThanksgivingParade_499-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYCThanksgivingParade-499">[497]</a></sup> the annual <a href="/wiki/New_York%27s_Village_Halloween_Parade" title="New York's Village Halloween Parade">Halloween Parade</a> in <a href="/wiki/Greenwich_Village" title="Greenwich Village">Greenwich Village</a>; the annual <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Independence_Day_Parade" title="Philippine Independence Day Parade">Philippine Independence Day Parade</a>; and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_ticker-tape_parades_in_New_York_City" title="List of ticker-tape parades in New York City">ticker-tape parade</a> for the <a href="/wiki/Apollo_11" title="Apollo 11">Apollo 11</a> <a href="/wiki/Astronaut" title="Astronaut">astronauts</a></div></div></div></div>
<p>New York City is well known for its street <a href="/wiki/Parade" title="Parade">parades</a>, which celebrate a broad array of themes, including holidays, nationalities, human rights, and major league sports team championship victories. The majority of parades are held in Manhattan. The primary orientation of the annual street parades is typically from north to south, marching along major avenues. The annual <a href="/wiki/Macy%27s_Thanksgiving_Day_Parade" title="Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade">Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade</a> is the world's largest parade,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYCThanksgivingParade_499-1"><a href="#cite_note-NYCThanksgivingParade-499">[497]</a></sup> beginning alongside <a href="/wiki/Central_Park" title="Central Park">Central Park</a> and processing southward to the flagship <a href="/wiki/Macy%27s_Herald_Square" title="Macy's Herald Square">Macy's Herald Square</a> store;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-500"><a href="#cite_note-500">[498]</a></sup> the parade is viewed on telecasts worldwide and draws millions of spectators in person.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYCThanksgivingParade_499-2"><a href="#cite_note-NYCThanksgivingParade-499">[497]</a></sup> Other notable parades including the annual <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_St._Patrick%27s_Day_Parade" title="New York City St. Patrick's Day Parade">New York City St. Patrick's Day Parade</a> in March, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/LGBT_Pride_March_(New_York_City)" title="LGBT Pride March (New York City)">LGBT Pride March</a> in June, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Greenwich_Village_Halloween_Parade" title="Greenwich Village Halloween Parade">Greenwich Village Halloween Parade</a> in October, and numerous parades commemorating the independence days of many nations. <a href="/wiki/List_of_ticker-tape_parades_in_New_York_City" title="List of ticker-tape parades in New York City">Ticker-tape parades</a> celebrating championships won by sports teams as well as other heroic accomplishments march northward along the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Canyon_of_Heroes" title="Canyon of Heroes">Canyon of Heroes</a> on <a href="/wiki/Broadway_(Manhattan)" title="Broadway (Manhattan)">Broadway</a> from <a href="/wiki/Bowling_Green_(New_York_City)" title="Bowling Green (New York City)">Bowling Green</a> to <a href="/wiki/City_Hall_Park" title="City Hall Park">City Hall Park</a> in Lower Manhattan.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Accent_and_dialect">Accent and dialect</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_English" title="New York City English">New York City English</a> and <a href="/wiki/New_York_accent" title="New York accent">New York accent</a></div>
<p>The New York area is home to a distinctive regional speech pattern called the <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_English" title="New York City English">New York dialect</a>, alternatively known as <i>Brooklynese</i> or <i>New Yorkese</i>. It has generally been considered one of the most recognizable accents within <a href="/wiki/American_English" title="American English">American English</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-501"><a href="#cite_note-501">[499]</a></sup>
</p><p>The traditional New York area accent is characterized as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rhotic_and_non-rhotic_accents" title="Rhotic and non-rhotic accents">non-rhotic</a>, so that the sound <span class="IPA" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[ɹ]</span> does not appear at the end of a <a href="/wiki/Syllable" title="Syllable">syllable</a> or immediately before a <a href="/wiki/Consonant" title="Consonant">consonant</a>; therefore the pronunciation of the city name as "New Yawk."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT19930214_502-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYT19930214-502">[500]</a></sup> There is no <span class="IPA" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[ɹ]</span> in words like <i>park</i> <span class="IPA" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[pɑək]</span> or <span class="IPA" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[pɒək]</span> (with vowel backed and <a href="/wiki/Vowel_breaking" title="Vowel breaking">diphthongized</a> due to the low-back chain shift), <i>butter</i> <span class="IPA" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[bʌɾə]</span>, or <i>here</i> <span class="IPA" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[hiə]</span>. In another feature called the low back chain shift, the <span class="IPA" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[ɔ]</span> vowel sound of words like <i>talk</i>, <i>law</i>, <i>cross</i>, <i>chocolate</i>, and <i>coffee</i> and the often <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Homophonous" title="Homophonous">homophonous</a> <span class="IPA" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[ɔr]</span> in <i>core</i> and <i>more</i> are tensed and usually raised more than in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/General_American" title="General American">General American</a> English. In the most old-fashioned and extreme versions of the New York dialect, the vowel sounds of words like "girl" and of words like "oil" became a diphthong <span class="IPA" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[ɜɪ]</span>. This is often misperceived by speakers of other accents as a reversal of the <i>er</i> and <i>oy</i> sounds, so that <i>girl</i> is pronounced "goil" and <i>oil</i> is pronounced "erl"; this leads to the caricature of New Yorkers saying things like "Joizey" (Jersey), "Toidy-Toid Street" (33rd St.) and "terlet" (toilet).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT19930214_502-1"><a href="#cite_note-NYT19930214-502">[500]</a></sup> The character <a href="/wiki/Archie_Bunker" title="Archie Bunker">Archie Bunker</a> from the 1970s <a href="/wiki/Sitcom" title="Sitcom">television sitcom</a> <i><a href="/wiki/All_in_the_Family" title="All in the Family">All in the Family</a></i> was an example of having used this pattern of speech.
</p><p>The classic version of the New York City dialect is generally centered on <a href="/wiki/Middle_class" title="Middle class">middle</a> and working-class New Yorkers. The influx of non-European immigrants in recent decades has led to changes in this distinctive dialect,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT19930214_502-2"><a href="#cite_note-NYT19930214-502">[500]</a></sup> and the traditional form of this speech pattern is no longer as prevalent among general New Yorkers as it has been in the past.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT19930214_502-3"><a href="#cite_note-NYT19930214-502">[500]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sports_in_the_New_York_metropolitan_area" title="Sports in the New York metropolitan area">Sports in the New York metropolitan area</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:229px;max-width:229px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:227px;max-width:227px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:New_York_City_Marathon_2014_(15082977714).jpg"><img alt="Three runners in a race down a street where onlookers are cheering behind barriers." data-file-height="1118" data-file-width="1680" decoding="async" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/New_York_City_Marathon_2014_%2815082977714%29.jpg/225px-New_York_City_Marathon_2014_%2815082977714%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/New_York_City_Marathon_2014_%2815082977714%29.jpg/338px-New_York_City_Marathon_2014_%2815082977714%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/New_York_City_Marathon_2014_%2815082977714%29.jpg/450px-New_York_City_Marathon_2014_%2815082977714%29.jpg 2x" width="225"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Marathon" title="New York City Marathon">New York Marathon</a> is the largest marathon in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYCMarathonWorld'sLargest_503-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYCMarathonWorld'sLargest-503">[501]</a></sup></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:227px;max-width:227px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Arthur_ashe_stadium_interior.jpg"><img alt="A tennis stadium pack with fans watching a grass court." data-file-height="960" data-file-width="1280" decoding="async" height="169" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Arthur_ashe_stadium_interior.jpg/225px-Arthur_ashe_stadium_interior.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Arthur_ashe_stadium_interior.jpg/338px-Arthur_ashe_stadium_interior.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Arthur_ashe_stadium_interior.jpg/450px-Arthur_ashe_stadium_interior.jpg 2x" width="225"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._Open_(tennis)" title="U.S. Open (tennis)">U.S. Open Tennis Championships</a> are held every August and September in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Flushing_Meadows-Corona_Park" title="Flushing Meadows-Corona Park">Flushing Meadows-Corona Park</a>, Queens.</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:227px;max-width:227px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Citi_Field_2011.JPG"><img alt="A baseball stadium from behind home plate in the evening." data-file-height="2647" data-file-width="3529" decoding="async" height="169" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Citi_Field_2011.JPG/225px-Citi_Field_2011.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Citi_Field_2011.JPG/338px-Citi_Field_2011.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Citi_Field_2011.JPG/450px-Citi_Field_2011.JPG 2x" width="225"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Citi_Field" title="Citi Field">Citi Field</a>, also in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, has been home to the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Mets" title="New York Mets">New York Mets</a> since 2009.</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:227px;max-width:227px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Madison_Square_Garden_(MSG)_-_Full_(48124330357).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="3044" data-file-width="5411" decoding="async" height="127" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Madison_Square_Garden_%28MSG%29_-_Full_%2848124330357%29.jpg/225px-Madison_Square_Garden_%28MSG%29_-_Full_%2848124330357%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Madison_Square_Garden_%28MSG%29_-_Full_%2848124330357%29.jpg/338px-Madison_Square_Garden_%28MSG%29_-_Full_%2848124330357%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Madison_Square_Garden_%28MSG%29_-_Full_%2848124330357%29.jpg/450px-Madison_Square_Garden_%28MSG%29_-_Full_%2848124330357%29.jpg 2x" width="225"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Madison_Square_Garden" title="Madison Square Garden">Madison Square Garden</a> in <a href="/wiki/Midtown_Manhattan" title="Midtown Manhattan">Midtown Manhattan</a> is home to the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Knicks" title="New York Knicks">New York Knicks</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_York_Rangers" title="New York Rangers">New York Rangers</a>, and <a href="/wiki/St._John%27s_Red_Storm_men%27s_basketball" title="St. John's Red Storm men's basketball">St. John's Red Storm</a>.</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>New York City is home to the headquarters of the <a href="/wiki/National_Football_League" title="National Football League">National Football League</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-504"><a href="#cite_note-504">[502]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Major_League_Baseball" title="Major League Baseball">Major League Baseball</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-505"><a href="#cite_note-505">[503]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/National_Basketball_Association" title="National Basketball Association">National Basketball Association</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-506"><a href="#cite_note-506">[504]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/National_Hockey_League" title="National Hockey League">National Hockey League</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-507"><a href="#cite_note-507">[505]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Major_League_Soccer" title="Major League Soccer">Major League Soccer</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-508"><a href="#cite_note-508">[506]</a></sup> The New York metropolitan area hosts the <a href="/wiki/List_of_American_and_Canadian_cities_by_number_of_major_professional_sports_franchises" title="List of American and Canadian cities by number of major professional sports franchises">most</a> sports teams in the four major North American professional sports leagues with nine, one more than Los Angeles, and has 11 top-level professional sports teams if Major League Soccer is included, also one more than Los Angeles. Participation in professional sports in the city predates all professional leagues.
</p><p>The city has played host to more than forty major professional teams in the five sports and their respective competing leagues. Four of the ten most expensive stadiums ever built worldwide (<a href="/wiki/MetLife_Stadium" title="MetLife Stadium">MetLife Stadium</a>, the new <a href="/wiki/Yankee_Stadium" title="Yankee Stadium">Yankee Stadium</a>, <a href="/wiki/Madison_Square_Garden" title="Madison Square Garden">Madison Square Garden</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Citi_Field" title="Citi Field">Citi Field</a>) are located in the New York metropolitan area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-509"><a href="#cite_note-509">[507]</a></sup> Madison Square Garden, <a href="/wiki/Madison_Square_Garden_(1925)" title="Madison Square Garden (1925)">its predecessor</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yankee_Stadium_(1923)" title="Yankee Stadium (1923)">the original Yankee Stadium</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ebbets_Field" title="Ebbets Field">Ebbets Field</a>, are sporting venues located in New York City, the latter two having been commemorated on <a href="/wiki/Postage_stamps_and_postal_history_of_the_United_States" title="Postage stamps and postal history of the United States">U.S. postage stamps</a>. New York was the first of eight American cities to have won titles in all four major leagues (MLB, NHL, NFL and NBA), having done so following the Knicks' <a href="/wiki/1970_NBA_Finals" title="1970 NBA Finals">1970 title</a>. In 1972, it became the first city to win titles in five sports when the Cosmos won the <a href="/wiki/NASL_Final_1972" title="NASL Final 1972">NASL final</a>.
</p><p>New York has been described as the "Capital of Baseball".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-510"><a href="#cite_note-510">[508]</a></sup> There have been 35 Major League Baseball <a href="/wiki/World_Series" title="World Series">World Series</a> and 73 <a href="/wiki/Pennant_(sports)#Pennants_as_trophies" title="Pennant (sports)">pennants</a> won by New York teams. It is one of only five metro areas (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_metropolitan_area" title="Los Angeles metropolitan area">Los Angeles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chicago_metropolitan_area" title="Chicago metropolitan area">Chicago</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baltimore%E2%80%93Washington_metropolitan_area" title="Baltimore–Washington metropolitan area">Baltimore–Washington</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Bay_Area" title="San Francisco Bay Area">San Francisco Bay Area</a> being the others) to have two baseball teams. Additionally, there have been 14 World Series in which two New York City teams played each other, known as a <a href="/wiki/Subway_Series" title="Subway Series">Subway Series</a> and occurring most recently in <a href="/wiki/2000_World_Series" title="2000 World Series">2000</a>. No other metropolitan area has had this happen more than once (Chicago in <a href="/wiki/1906_World_Series" title="1906 World Series">1906</a>, St. Louis in <a href="/wiki/1944_World_Series" title="1944 World Series">1944</a>, and the San Francisco Bay Area in <a href="/wiki/1989_World_Series" title="1989 World Series">1989</a>).
</p><p>The city's two Major League Baseball teams are the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Mets" title="New York Mets">New York Mets</a>, who play at <a href="/wiki/Citi_Field" title="Citi Field">Citi Field</a> in Queens,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-511"><a href="#cite_note-511">[509]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Yankees" title="New York Yankees">New York Yankees</a>, who play at <a href="/wiki/Yankee_Stadium" title="Yankee Stadium">Yankee Stadium</a> in the Bronx. These teams compete in six games of <a href="/wiki/Interleague_play" title="Interleague play">interleague play</a> every regular season that has also come to be called the <a href="/wiki/Subway_Series" title="Subway Series">Subway Series</a>. The Yankees have won a record 27 championships,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-512"><a href="#cite_note-512">[510]</a></sup> while the Mets have won the World Series twice.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-513"><a href="#cite_note-513">[511]</a></sup> The city also was once home to the Brooklyn Dodgers (now the <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Dodgers" title="Los Angeles Dodgers">Los Angeles Dodgers</a>), who won the World Series once,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-514"><a href="#cite_note-514">[512]</a></sup> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_York_Giants_(NL)" title="New York Giants (NL)">New York Giants</a> (now the <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Giants" title="San Francisco Giants">San Francisco Giants</a>), who won the World Series five times. Both teams moved to California in 1958.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-515"><a href="#cite_note-515">[513]</a></sup> There is also one <a href="/wiki/Minor_League_Baseball" title="Minor League Baseball">Minor League Baseball</a> team in the city, the Mets-affiliated <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn_Cyclones" title="Brooklyn Cyclones">Brooklyn Cyclones</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-516"><a href="#cite_note-516">[514]</a></sup> and the city will gain a club in the independent <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_League_of_Professional_Baseball" title="Atlantic League of Professional Baseball">Atlantic League</a> when the <a href="/wiki/Staten_Island_FerryHawks" title="Staten Island FerryHawks">Staten Island FerryHawks</a> begin play in 2022.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-517"><a href="#cite_note-517">[515]</a></sup>
</p><p>The city is represented in the National Football League by the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Giants" title="New York Giants">New York Giants</a> and the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Jets" title="New York Jets">New York Jets</a>, although both teams play their home games at MetLife Stadium in nearby <a href="/wiki/East_Rutherford,_New_Jersey" title="East Rutherford, New Jersey">East Rutherford, New Jersey</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-518"><a href="#cite_note-518">[516]</a></sup> which hosted <a href="/wiki/Super_Bowl_XLVIII" title="Super Bowl XLVIII">Super Bowl XLVIII</a> in 2014.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-519"><a href="#cite_note-519">[517]</a></sup>
</p><p>The metropolitan area is home to three National Hockey League teams. The <a href="/wiki/New_York_Rangers" title="New York Rangers">New York Rangers</a>, the traditional representative of the city itself and one of the league's <a href="/wiki/Original_Six" title="Original Six">Original Six</a>, play at <a href="/wiki/Madison_Square_Garden" title="Madison Square Garden">Madison Square Garden</a> in Manhattan. The <a href="/wiki/New_York_Islanders" title="New York Islanders">New York Islanders</a>, traditionally representing <a href="/wiki/Nassau_County,_New_York" title="Nassau County, New York">Nassau</a> and <a href="/wiki/Suffolk_County,_New_York" title="Suffolk County, New York">Suffolk</a> Counties of <a href="/wiki/Long_Island" title="Long Island">Long Island</a>, play in <a href="/wiki/UBS_Arena" title="UBS Arena">UBS Arena</a> in Elmont, New York, and played in Brooklyn's <a href="/wiki/Barclays_Center" title="Barclays Center">Barclays Center</a> from 2015 to 2020. The <a href="/wiki/New_Jersey_Devils" title="New Jersey Devils">New Jersey Devils</a> play at <a href="/wiki/Prudential_Center" title="Prudential Center">Prudential Center</a> in nearby <a href="/wiki/Newark,_New_Jersey" title="Newark, New Jersey">Newark, New Jersey</a> and traditionally represent the counties of neighboring <a href="/wiki/New_Jersey" title="New Jersey">New Jersey</a> which are coextensive with the boundaries of the New York metropolitan area and media market.
</p><p>The city's National Basketball Association teams are the <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn_Nets" title="Brooklyn Nets">Brooklyn Nets</a> (previously known as the New York Nets and New Jersey Nets as they moved around the metropolitan area) and the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Knicks" title="New York Knicks">New York Knicks</a>, while the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Liberty" title="New York Liberty">New York Liberty</a> is the city's <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_National_Basketball_Association" title="Women's National Basketball Association">Women's National Basketball Association</a> team. The first national college-level basketball championship, the <a href="/wiki/National_Invitation_Tournament" title="National Invitation Tournament">National Invitation Tournament</a>, was held in New York in 1938 and remains in the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-520"><a href="#cite_note-520">[518]</a></sup> The city is well known for its links to basketball, which is played in nearly every park in the city by local youth, many of whom have gone on to play for major college programs and in the NBA.
</p><p>In soccer, New York City is represented by <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_FC" title="New York City FC">New York City FC</a> of Major League Soccer, who play their home games at Yankee Stadium<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-521"><a href="#cite_note-521">[519]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Red_Bulls" title="New York Red Bulls">New York Red Bulls</a>, who play their home games at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Red_Bull_Arena_(Harrison)" title="Red Bull Arena (Harrison)">Red Bull Arena</a> in nearby <a href="/wiki/Harrison,_New_Jersey" title="Harrison, New Jersey">Harrison, New Jersey</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-522"><a href="#cite_note-522">[520]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/NJ/NY_Gotham_FC" title="NJ/NY Gotham FC">NJ/NY Gotham FC</a> also plays their home games in Red Bull Arena, representing the metropolitan area in the <a href="/wiki/National_Women%27s_Soccer_League" title="National Women's Soccer League">National Women's Soccer League</a>. Historically, the city is known for the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_York_Cosmos_(1970%E2%80%9385)" title="New York Cosmos (1970–85)">New York Cosmos</a>, the highly successful former professional soccer team which was the American home of <a href="/wiki/Pel%C3%A9" title="Pelé">Pelé</a>. A new version of the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Cosmos_(2010)" title="New York Cosmos (2010)">New York Cosmos</a> was formed in 2010, and most recently played in the third-division <a href="/wiki/National_Independent_Soccer_Association" title="National Independent Soccer Association">National Independent Soccer Association</a> before going on hiatus in January 2021. New York will be one of eleven US host cities for the <a href="/wiki/2026_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2026 FIFA World Cup">2026 FIFA World Cup</a>.
</p><p>The annual <a href="/wiki/US_Open_(tennis)" title="US Open (tennis)">United States Open Tennis Championships</a> is one of the world's four <a href="/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis)" title="Grand Slam (tennis)">Grand Slam</a> tennis tournaments and is held at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/USTA_National_Tennis_Center" title="USTA National Tennis Center">National Tennis Center</a> in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Flushing_Meadows-Corona_Park" title="Flushing Meadows-Corona Park">Flushing Meadows-Corona Park</a>, Queens.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-523"><a href="#cite_note-523">[521]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Marathon" title="New York City Marathon">New York City Marathon</a>, which courses through all five boroughs, is the world's largest running marathon,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYCMarathonWorld'sLargest_503-1"><a href="#cite_note-NYCMarathonWorld'sLargest-503">[501]</a></sup> with 51,394 finishers in 2016<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-524"><a href="#cite_note-524">[522]</a></sup> and 98,247 applicants for the 2017 race.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYCMarathonWorld'sLargest_503-2"><a href="#cite_note-NYCMarathonWorld'sLargest-503">[501]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Millrose_Games" title="Millrose Games">Millrose Games</a> is an annual <a href="/wiki/Track_and_field" title="Track and field">track and field</a> meet whose featured event is the <a href="/wiki/Wanamaker_Mile" title="Wanamaker Mile">Wanamaker Mile</a>. Boxing is also a prominent part of the city's sporting scene, with events like the Amateur Boxing Golden Gloves being held at <a href="/wiki/Madison_Square_Garden" title="Madison Square Garden">Madison Square Garden</a> each year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-525"><a href="#cite_note-525">[523]</a></sup> The city is also considered the host of the <a href="/wiki/Belmont_Stakes" title="Belmont Stakes">Belmont Stakes</a>, the last, longest and oldest of horse racing's <a href="/wiki/Triple_Crown_of_Thoroughbred_Racing_(United_States)" title="Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing (United States)">Triple Crown races</a>, held just over the city's border at <a href="/wiki/Belmont_Park" title="Belmont Park">Belmont Park</a> on the first or second Sunday of June. The city also hosted the <a href="/wiki/1932_U.S._Open_(golf)" title="1932 U.S. Open (golf)">1932 U.S. Open</a> golf tournament and the <a href="/wiki/1930_PGA_Championship" title="1930 PGA Championship">1930</a> and <a href="/wiki/1939_PGA_Championship" title="1939 PGA Championship">1939</a> PGA Championships, and has been host city for both events several times, most notably for nearby <a href="/wiki/Winged_Foot_Golf_Club" title="Winged Foot Golf Club">Winged Foot Golf Club</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Gaelic_games_in_North_America" title="Gaelic games in North America">Gaelic games</a> are played in <a href="/wiki/Riverdale,_Bronx" title="Riverdale, Bronx">Riverdale, Bronx</a> at <a href="/wiki/Gaelic_Park" title="Gaelic Park">Gaelic Park</a>, home to the <a href="/wiki/New_York_GAA" title="New York GAA">New York GAA</a>, the only North American team to compete at the senior <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gaelic_Athletic_Association_county" title="Gaelic Athletic Association county">inter-county</a> level.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Environment">Environment</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Environmental_issues_in_New_York_City" title="Environmental issues in New York City">Environmental issues in New York City</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:NYC_Hybrid_Taxi.JPG"><img alt="Two yellow taxis on a narrow street lined with shops." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/NYC_Hybrid_Taxi.JPG/220px-NYC_Hybrid_Taxi.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/NYC_Hybrid_Taxi.JPG/330px-NYC_Hybrid_Taxi.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/NYC_Hybrid_Taxi.JPG/440px-NYC_Hybrid_Taxi.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:NYC_Hybrid_Taxi.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>As of 2012<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=New_York_City&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the city had about 6,000 <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_taxi" title="Hybrid taxi">hybrid taxis</a> (shown) in service, the largest number of any city in North America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WSJ091912_526-0"><a href="#cite_note-WSJ091912-526">[524]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Environmental issues in New York City are affected by the city's size, density, <a href="/wiki/Transportation_in_New_York_City" title="Transportation in New York City">abundant public transportation infrastructure</a>, and location at the mouth of the <a href="/wiki/Hudson_River" title="Hudson River">Hudson River</a>. For example, it is both one of the country's biggest sources of pollution, and has the lowest per-capita <a href="/wiki/Greenhouse_gas_emissions" title="Greenhouse gas emissions">greenhouse gas emissions</a> rate and electricity usage.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Environmental_impact_reduction">Environmental impact reduction</span></h3>
<p>New York City has focused on reducing its <a href="/wiki/Human_impact_on_the_environment" title="Human impact on the environment">environmental impact</a> and <a href="/wiki/Carbon_footprint" title="Carbon footprint">carbon footprint</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYCCarbonFootprint_527-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYCCarbonFootprint-527">[525]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mass_transit" title="Mass transit">Mass transit</a> use in New York City is the highest in the United States. Also, by 2010, the city had 3,715 <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_electric_vehicle" title="Hybrid electric vehicle">hybrid</a> taxis and other <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Clean_diesel" title="Clean diesel">clean diesel</a> vehicles, representing around 28% of New York's taxi fleet in service, the most of any city in North America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT072710_528-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYT072710-528">[526]</a></sup> New York City is the host of <a href="/wiki/Climate_Week_NYC" title="Climate Week NYC">Climate Week NYC</a>, the largest Climate Week to take place globally and regarded as major annual climate summit.
</p><p>New York's <a href="/wiki/List_of_U.S._cities_with_high_transit_ridership" title="List of U.S. cities with high transit ridership">high rate of public transit use</a>, more than 200,000 daily cyclists as of 2014<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=New_York_City&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-529"><a href="#cite_note-529">[527]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_U.S._cities_with_most_pedestrian_commuters" title="List of U.S. cities with most pedestrian commuters">many pedestrian commuters</a> make it the most energy-efficient major city in the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYC_energy_consumption_530-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYC_energy_consumption-530">[528]</a></sup> Walk and bicycle modes of travel account for 21% of all modes for trips in the city; nationally the rate for metro regions is about 8%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-531"><a href="#cite_note-531">[529]</a></sup> In both its 2011 and 2015 rankings, <a href="/wiki/Walk_Score" title="Walk Score">Walk Score</a> named New York City the most <a href="/wiki/Walkability" title="Walkability">walkable</a> large city in the United States,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-532"><a href="#cite_note-532">[530]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-533"><a href="#cite_note-533">[531]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-534"><a href="#cite_note-534">[532]</a></sup> and in 2018, <i>Stacker</i> ranked New York the most walkable U.S. city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-535"><a href="#cite_note-535">[533]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Citibank" title="Citibank">Citibank</a> sponsored the introduction of 10,000 public bicycles for the city's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bike-share" title="Bike-share">bike-share</a> project in the summer of 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-536"><a href="#cite_note-536">[534]</a></sup> New York City's numerical "in-season cycling indicator" of bicycling in the city had hit an all-time high of 437 when measured in 2014.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-537"><a href="#cite_note-537">[535]</a></sup>
</p><p>The city government was a petitioner in the landmark <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Massachusetts_v._Environmental_Protection_Agency" title="Massachusetts v. Environmental Protection Agency">Massachusetts v. Environmental Protection Agency</a></i> Supreme Court case forcing the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/EPA" title="EPA">EPA</a> to regulate <a href="/wiki/Greenhouse_gas" title="Greenhouse gas">greenhouse gases</a> as pollutants. The city is a leader in the construction of energy-efficient <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Green_office_buildings" title="Green office buildings">green office buildings</a>, including the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hearst_Tower_(New_York_City)" title="Hearst Tower (New York City)">Hearst Tower</a> among others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-greenbuilding_182-1"><a href="#cite_note-greenbuilding-182">[182]</a></sup> Mayor Bill de Blasio has committed to an 80% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions between 2014 and 2050 to reduce the city's contributions to <a href="/wiki/Climate_change" title="Climate change">climate change</a>, beginning with a comprehensive "Green Buildings" plan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYCCarbonFootprint_527-1"><a href="#cite_note-NYCCarbonFootprint-527">[525]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Water_purity_and_availability">Water purity and availability</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Food_and_water_in_New_York_City" title="Food and water in New York City">Food and water in New York City</a> and <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_water_supply_system" title="New York City water supply system">New York City water supply system</a></div>
<p>The New York City drinking water supply is extracted from the protected <a href="/wiki/Catskill_Mountains" title="Catskill Mountains">Catskill Mountains</a> <a href="/wiki/Drainage_basin" title="Drainage basin">watershed</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-538"><a href="#cite_note-538">[536]</a></sup> As a result of the watershed's integrity and undisturbed natural <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Water_filtration" title="Water filtration">water filtration</a> system, New York is one of only four major cities in the United States the majority of whose drinking water is pure enough not to require purification through <a href="/wiki/Water_treatment" title="Water treatment">water treatment</a> plants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-539"><a href="#cite_note-539">[537]</a></sup> The city's municipal water system is the largest in the United States, moving over one billion gallons of water per day;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYTimes-Water-Investment-2018_540-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYTimes-Water-Investment-2018-540">[538]</a></sup>  a leak in the Delaware aqueduct results in some 20 million gallons a day being lost under the Hudson River.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DEP_541-0"><a href="#cite_note-DEP-541">[539]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Croton_Watershed" title="Croton Watershed">Croton Watershed</a> north of the city is undergoing construction of a $3.2 billion water purification plant to augment New York City's water supply by an estimated 290 million gallons daily, representing a greater than 20% addition to the city's current availability of water.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-542"><a href="#cite_note-542">[540]</a></sup> The ongoing expansion of <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Water_Tunnel_No._3" title="New York City Water Tunnel No. 3">New York City Water Tunnel No. 3</a>, an integral part of the New York City water supply system, is the largest capital construction project in the city's history,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-543"><a href="#cite_note-543">[541]</a></sup> with segments serving Manhattan and the Bronx completed, and with segments serving Brooklyn and Queens planned for construction in 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-544"><a href="#cite_note-544">[542]</a></sup> In 2018, New York City announced a $1 billion investment to protect the integrity of its water system and to maintain the purity of its unfiltered water supply.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYTimes-Water-Investment-2018_540-1"><a href="#cite_note-NYTimes-Water-Investment-2018-540">[538]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Air_quality">Air quality</span></h3>
<p>According to the 2016 <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organization</a> Global Urban Ambient Air Pollution Database,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-545"><a href="#cite_note-545">[543]</a></sup> the annual average concentration in New York City's air of particulate matter measuring 2.5<span class="nowrap"> </span>micrometers or less (PM<sub>2.5</sub>) was 7.0<span class="nowrap"> </span>micrograms per cubic meter, or 3.0<span class="nowrap"> </span>micrograms within the recommended limit of the WHO Air Quality Guidelines for the annual mean PM<sub>2.5</sub>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-546"><a href="#cite_note-546">[544]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Department_of_Health_and_Mental_Hygiene" title="New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene">New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene</a>, in partnership with <a href="/wiki/Queens_College,_City_University_of_New_York" title="Queens College, City University of New York">Queens College</a>, conducts the New York Community Air Survey to measure pollutants at about 150 locations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-547"><a href="#cite_note-547">[545]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Environmental_revitalization">Environmental revitalization</span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Newtown_Creek" title="Newtown Creek">Newtown Creek</a>, a 3.5-mile (6-kilometer) a long <a href="/wiki/Estuary" title="Estuary">estuary</a> that forms part of the border between the boroughs of Brooklyn and Queens, has been designated a <a href="/wiki/Superfund" title="Superfund">Superfund</a> site for environmental clean-up and remediation of the waterway's recreational and economic resources for many communities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-548"><a href="#cite_note-548">[546]</a></sup> One of the most heavily used bodies of water in the <a href="/wiki/Port_of_New_York_and_New_Jersey" title="Port of New York and New Jersey">Port of New York and New Jersey</a>, it had been one of the most contaminated industrial sites in the country,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PBS_549-0"><a href="#cite_note-PBS-549">[547]</a></sup> containing years of discarded <a href="/wiki/Toxin" title="Toxin">toxins</a>, an estimated 30 million US gallons (110,000 m<sup>3</sup>) of spilled oil, including the <a href="/wiki/Greenpoint_oil_spill" title="Greenpoint oil spill">Greenpoint oil spill</a>, raw <a href="/wiki/Sewage" title="Sewage">sewage</a> from New York City's sewer system,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PBS_549-1"><a href="#cite_note-PBS-549">[547]</a></sup> and other accumulation.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Government_and_politics">Government and politics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Government_of_New_York_City" title="Government of New York City">Government of New York City</a> and <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_New_York_City" title="Politics of New York City">Politics of New York City</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Government">Government</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:New_York_City_Hall_exterior,_October_2016.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="5249" data-file-width="12641" decoding="async" height="91" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/New_York_City_Hall_exterior%2C_October_2016.jpg/220px-New_York_City_Hall_exterior%2C_October_2016.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/New_York_City_Hall_exterior%2C_October_2016.jpg/330px-New_York_City_Hall_exterior%2C_October_2016.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/New_York_City_Hall_exterior%2C_October_2016.jpg/440px-New_York_City_Hall_exterior%2C_October_2016.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:New_York_City_Hall_exterior,_October_2016.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Hall" title="New York City Hall">New York City Hall</a> is the oldest City Hall in the United States that still houses its original governmental functions.</div></div></div>
<p>New York City has been a <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_municipality" title="Metropolitan municipality">metropolitan municipality</a> with a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Strong_Mayor" title="Strong Mayor">Strong mayor–council form of government</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-550"><a href="#cite_note-550">[548]</a></sup> since its consolidation in 1898. In New York City, the city government is responsible for public education, correctional institutions, public safety, recreational facilities, sanitation, water supply, and welfare services.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Mayor_of_New_York_City" title="Mayor of New York City">mayor</a> and council members are elected to four-year terms. The <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Council" title="New York City Council">City Council</a> is a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unicameral" title="Unicameral">unicameral</a> body consisting of 51 council members whose districts are defined by geographic population boundaries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-551"><a href="#cite_note-551">[549]</a></sup> Each term for the mayor and council members lasts four years and has a two <a href="/wiki/Term_limit" title="Term limit">consecutive-term limit</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-552"><a href="#cite_note-552">[550]</a></sup> which is reset after a four-year break. The <i><a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Administrative_Code" title="New York City Administrative Code">New York City Administrative Code</a></i>, the <i><a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Rules" title="New York City Rules">New York City Rules</a></i>, and the <i><a href="/wiki/The_City_Record" title="The City Record">City Record</a></i> are the code of local laws, compilation of regulations, and official journal, respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-553"><a href="#cite_note-553">[551]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-554"><a href="#cite_note-554">[552]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:New_York_County_Courthouse_-_Angle_Shot_(48129112547).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="4608" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/New_York_County_Courthouse_-_Angle_Shot_%2848129112547%29.jpg/220px-New_York_County_Courthouse_-_Angle_Shot_%2848129112547%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/New_York_County_Courthouse_-_Angle_Shot_%2848129112547%29.jpg/330px-New_York_County_Courthouse_-_Angle_Shot_%2848129112547%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/New_York_County_Courthouse_-_Angle_Shot_%2848129112547%29.jpg/440px-New_York_County_Courthouse_-_Angle_Shot_%2848129112547%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:New_York_County_Courthouse_-_Angle_Shot_(48129112547).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/New_York_County_Courthouse" title="New York County Courthouse">New York County Courthouse</a> houses the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Supreme_Court" title="New York Supreme Court">New York Supreme Court</a> and other offices.</div></div></div>
<p>Each borough is coextensive with a <a href="/wiki/Judicial_district" title="Judicial district">judicial district</a> of the state <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_York_State_Unified_Court_System" title="New York State Unified Court System">Unified Court System</a>, of which the <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Criminal_Court" title="New York City Criminal Court">Criminal Court</a> and the <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Civil_Court" title="New York City Civil Court">Civil Court</a> are the local courts, while the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Supreme_Court" title="New York Supreme Court">New York Supreme Court</a> conducts major trials and appeals. Manhattan hosts the First Department of the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Supreme_Court,_Appellate_Division" title="New York Supreme Court, Appellate Division">Supreme Court, Appellate Division</a> while Brooklyn hosts the Second Department. There are also several extrajudicial <a href="/wiki/Administrative_court" title="Administrative court">administrative courts</a>, which are executive agencies and not part of the state Unified Court System.
</p><p>Uniquely among major American cities, New York is divided between, and is host to the main branches of, two different <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._district_courts" title="U.S. district courts">U.S. district courts</a>: the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/District_Court_for_the_Southern_District_of_New_York" title="District Court for the Southern District of New York">District Court for the Southern District of New York</a>, whose main courthouse is on <a href="/wiki/Foley_Square" title="Foley Square">Foley Square</a> near City Hall in Manhattan and whose jurisdiction includes Manhattan and the Bronx; and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/District_Court_for_the_Eastern_District_of_New_York" title="District Court for the Eastern District of New York">District Court for the Eastern District of New York</a>, whose main courthouse is in Brooklyn and whose jurisdiction includes Brooklyn, Queens, and Staten Island. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._Court_of_Appeals_for_the_Second_Circuit" title="U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit">U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._Court_of_International_Trade" title="U.S. Court of International Trade">U.S. Court of International Trade</a> are also based in New York, also on Foley Square in Manhattan.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:151px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Eric_Adams_White_House.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="197" data-file-width="149" decoding="async" height="197" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a4/Eric_Adams_White_House.jpg" width="149"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Eric_Adams_White_House.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Eric_Adams" title="Eric Adams">Eric Adams</a>, the current and <a href="/wiki/List_of_mayors_of_New_York_City" title="List of mayors of New York City">110th</a> <a href="/wiki/Mayor_of_New_York_City" title="Mayor of New York City">Mayor of New York City</a></div></div></div>
<p>The present mayor is <a href="/wiki/Eric_Adams" title="Eric Adams">Eric Adams</a>. He was elected in <a href="/wiki/2021_New_York_City_mayoral_election" title="2021 New York City mayoral election">2021</a> with 67% of the vote, and assumed office on January 1, 2022.
</p><p>The Democratic Party holds the majority of public offices. As of April 2016, 69% of registered voters in the city are Democrats and 10% are <a href="/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)" title="Republican Party (United States)">Republicans</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-555"><a href="#cite_note-555">[553]</a></sup> New York City has not been carried by a Republican in a statewide or presidential election since President <a href="/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge" title="Calvin Coolidge">Calvin Coolidge</a> won the five boroughs in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election_in_New_York,_1924" title="United States presidential election in New York, 1924">1924</a>. In <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election_in_New_York,_2012" title="United States presidential election in New York, 2012">2012</a>, Democrat <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a> became the first presidential candidate of any party to receive more than 80% of the overall vote in New York City, sweeping all five boroughs. <a href="/wiki/Party_platform" title="Party platform">Party platforms</a> center on affordable housing, education, and economic development, and labor politics are of importance in the city. Thirteen out of 27 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._congressional_district" title="U.S. congressional district">U.S. congressional districts</a> in the state of New York include portions of New York City.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-556"><a href="#cite_note-556">[554]</a></sup>
</p><p>New York is one of the most important sources of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Political_fundraising" title="Political fundraising">political fundraising</a> in the United States. At least four of the top five ZIP Codes in the nation for political contributions were in Manhattan for the <a href="/wiki/2004_United_States_elections" title="2004 United States elections">2004</a>, <a href="/wiki/2006_United_States_elections" title="2006 United States elections">2006</a>, and <a href="/wiki/2008_United_States_elections" title="2008 United States elections">2008</a> elections. The top ZIP Code, 10021 on the <a href="/wiki/Upper_East_Side" title="Upper East Side">Upper East Side</a>, generated the most money for the 2004 presidential campaigns of <a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush" title="George W. Bush">George W. Bush</a> and <a href="/wiki/John_Kerry" title="John Kerry">John Kerry</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-557"><a href="#cite_note-557">[555]</a></sup> The city has a strong imbalance of payments with the national and state governments. It receives 83 cents in services for every $1 it sends to the federal government in <a href="/wiki/Taxation_in_the_United_States" title="Taxation in the United States">taxes</a> (or annually sends $11.4 billion more than it receives back). City residents and businesses also sent an additional $4.1 billion in the 2009–2010 <a href="/wiki/Fiscal_year" title="Fiscal year">fiscal year</a> to the state of New York than the city received in return.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-558"><a href="#cite_note-558">[556]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Transportation">Transportation</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transportation_in_New_York_City" title="Transportation in New York City">Transportation in New York City</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Image-Grand_central_Station_Outside_Night_2.jpg"><img alt="A row of yellow taxis in front of a multi-story ornate stone building with three huge arched windows." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3805" data-file-width="4726" decoding="async" height="177" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Image-Grand_central_Station_Outside_Night_2.jpg/220px-Image-Grand_central_Station_Outside_Night_2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Image-Grand_central_Station_Outside_Night_2.jpg/330px-Image-Grand_central_Station_Outside_Night_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Image-Grand_central_Station_Outside_Night_2.jpg/440px-Image-Grand_central_Station_Outside_Night_2.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Image-Grand_central_Station_Outside_Night_2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>New York City is home to the two busiest <a href="/wiki/Train_station" title="Train station">train stations</a> in the U.S., including <a href="/wiki/Grand_Central_Terminal" title="Grand Central Terminal">Grand Central Terminal</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>New York City's comprehensive transportation system is both complex and extensive.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Rapid_transit">Rapid transit</span></h3>
<p>Mass transit in New York City, most of which runs 24 hours a day, accounts for one in every three users of mass transit in the United States, and two-thirds of the nation's rail riders live in the New York City metropolitan area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MTAinfo_559-0"><a href="#cite_note-MTAinfo-559">[557]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-560"><a href="#cite_note-560">[558]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Rail">Rail</span></h4>
<p>The iconic <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Subway" title="New York City Subway">New York City Subway</a> system is the largest <a href="/wiki/Rapid_transit" title="Rapid transit">rapid transit</a> system in the world when measured by stations in operation, with 472, and by length of routes. Nearly all of New York's subway system is open 24 hours a day, in contrast to the overnight shutdown common to systems in most cities, including <a href="/wiki/MTR" title="MTR">Hong Kong</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-561"><a href="#cite_note-561">[559]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-562"><a href="#cite_note-562">[560]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/London_Underground" title="London Underground">London</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paris_M%C3%A9tro" title="Paris Métro">Paris</a>, <a href="/wiki/Seoul_Metropolitan_Subway" title="Seoul Metropolitan Subway">Seoul</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-563"><a href="#cite_note-563">[561]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-564"><a href="#cite_note-564">[562]</a></sup> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tokyo_Subway" title="Tokyo Subway">Tokyo</a>. The New York City Subway is also <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Metro_systems_by_annual_passenger_rides" title="Metro systems by annual passenger rides">the busiest metropolitan rail transit system in the Western Hemisphere</a>, with 1.76 billion passenger rides in 2015,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-565"><a href="#cite_note-565">[563]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Grand_Central_Terminal" title="Grand Central Terminal">Grand Central Terminal</a>, also referred to as "Grand Central Station", is the world's largest <a href="/wiki/Train_station" title="Train station">railway station</a> by number of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Train_platform" title="Train platform">train platforms</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:R160_E_enters_42nd_Street.jpg"><img alt="The front end of a subway train, with a red E on a LED display on the top. To the right of the train is a platform with a group of people waiting for their train." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4000" data-file-width="6000" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/R160_E_enters_42nd_Street.jpg/220px-R160_E_enters_42nd_Street.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/R160_E_enters_42nd_Street.jpg/330px-R160_E_enters_42nd_Street.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/R160_E_enters_42nd_Street.jpg/440px-R160_E_enters_42nd_Street.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:R160_E_enters_42nd_Street.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Subway" title="New York City Subway">New York City Subway</a> is the world's largest <a href="/wiki/Rapid_transit" title="Rapid transit">rapid transit</a> system by number of <a href="/wiki/Train_station" title="Train station">stations</a>.</div></div></div>
