<p>Public transport is essential in New York City. 54.6% of New Yorkers commuted to work in 2005 using mass transit.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-566"><a href="#cite_note-566">[564]</a></sup> This is in contrast to the rest of the United States, where 91% of commuters travel in automobiles to their workplace.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2001summary_567-0"><a href="#cite_note-2001summary-567">[565]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Comptroller" title="New York City Comptroller">New York City Comptroller</a>, workers in the New York City area spend an average of 6<span class="nowrap"> </span>hours and 18 minutes getting to work each week, the longest commute time in the nation among large cities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-568"><a href="#cite_note-568">[566]</a></sup> New York is the only U.S. city in which a majority (52%) of households do not have a car; only 22% of Manhattanites own a car.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-569"><a href="#cite_note-569">[567]</a></sup> Due to their <a href="/wiki/List_of_U.S._cities_with_high_transit_ridership" title="List of U.S. cities with high transit ridership">high usage of mass transit</a>, New Yorkers spend less of their household income on transportation than the national average, saving $19 billion annually on transportation compared to other urban Americans.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-570"><a href="#cite_note-570">[568]</a></sup>
</p><p>New York City's <a href="/wiki/Commuter_rail" title="Commuter rail">commuter rail</a> network is the largest in North America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MTAinfo_559-1"><a href="#cite_note-MTAinfo-559">[557]</a></sup> The rail network, connecting New York City to its suburbs, consists of the <a href="/wiki/Long_Island_Rail_Road" title="Long Island Rail Road">Long Island Rail Road</a>, <a href="/wiki/Metro-North_Railroad" title="Metro-North Railroad">Metro-North Railroad</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_Jersey_Transit_rail_operations" title="New Jersey Transit rail operations">New Jersey Transit</a>. The combined systems converge at Grand Central Terminal and <a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania_Station_(New_York_City)" title="Pennsylvania Station (New York City)">Pennsylvania Station</a> and contain more than 250 stations and 20 rail lines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MTAinfo_559-2"><a href="#cite_note-MTAinfo-559">[557]</a></sup> In Queens, the elevated <a href="/wiki/AirTrain_JFK" title="AirTrain JFK">AirTrain</a> <a href="/wiki/People_mover" title="People mover">people mover</a> system connects 24 hours a day <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/JFK_International_Airport" title="JFK International Airport">JFK International Airport</a> to the New York City Subway and the Long Island Rail Road; a separate AirTrain system is planned alongside the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Central_Parkway" title="Grand Central Parkway">Grand Central Parkway</a> to connect <a href="/wiki/LaGuardia_Airport" title="LaGuardia Airport">LaGuardia Airport</a> to these transit systems.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-571"><a href="#cite_note-571">[569]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-572"><a href="#cite_note-572">[570]</a></sup> For <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Intercity_rail" title="Intercity rail">intercity rail</a>, New York City is served by <a href="/wiki/Amtrak" title="Amtrak">Amtrak</a>, whose busiest station by a significant margin is Pennsylvania Station on the <a href="/wiki/West_Side_(Manhattan)" title="West Side (Manhattan)">West Side</a> of Manhattan, from which Amtrak provides connections to <a href="/wiki/Boston" title="Boston">Boston</a>, <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia" title="Philadelphia">Philadelphia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a> along the <a href="/wiki/Northeast_Corridor" title="Northeast Corridor">Northeast Corridor</a>, and long-distance train service to other North American cities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-573"><a href="#cite_note-573">[571]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Staten_Island_Railway" title="Staten Island Railway">Staten Island Railway</a> rapid transit system solely serves Staten Island, operating 24 hours a day. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Port_Authority_Trans-Hudson" title="Port Authority Trans-Hudson">Port Authority Trans-Hudson</a> (PATH train) links Midtown and Lower Manhattan to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Northeastern_New_Jersey" title="Northeastern New Jersey">northeastern New Jersey</a>, primarily <a href="/wiki/Hoboken,_New_Jersey" title="Hoboken, New Jersey">Hoboken</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jersey_City,_New_Jersey" title="Jersey City, New Jersey">Jersey City</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Newark,_New_Jersey" title="Newark, New Jersey">Newark</a>. Like the New York City Subway, the PATH operates 24 hours a day; meaning three of the six rapid transit systems in the world which operate on 24-hour schedules are wholly or partly in New York (the others are a portion of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chicago_%27L%27" title="Chicago 'L'">Chicago 'L'</a>, the <a href="/wiki/PATCO_Speedline" title="PATCO Speedline">PATCO Speedline</a> serving Philadelphia, and the <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen_Metro" title="Copenhagen Metro">Copenhagen Metro</a>).
</p><p>Multibillion-dollar <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Heavy_rail" title="Heavy rail">heavy rail</a> transit projects under construction in New York City include the <a href="/wiki/Second_Avenue_Subway" title="Second Avenue Subway">Second Avenue Subway</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/East_Side_Access" title="East Side Access">East Side Access</a> project.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-574"><a href="#cite_note-574">[572]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Buses">Buses</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Port-authority-terminal.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1297" data-file-width="2173" decoding="async" height="131" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Port-authority-terminal.jpg/220px-Port-authority-terminal.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Port-authority-terminal.jpg/330px-Port-authority-terminal.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Port-authority-terminal.jpg/440px-Port-authority-terminal.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Port-authority-terminal.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Port_Authority_Bus_Terminal" title="Port Authority Bus Terminal">Port Authority Bus Terminal</a>, the world's busiest bus station, at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/8th_Avenue_(Manhattan)" title="8th Avenue (Manhattan)">8th Avenue</a> and <a href="/wiki/42nd_Street_(Manhattan)" title="42nd Street (Manhattan)">42nd Street</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PABT_575-0"><a href="#cite_note-PABT-575">[573]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>New York City's public <a href="/wiki/MTA_Regional_Bus_Operations" title="MTA Regional Bus Operations">bus fleet</a> runs 24/7 and is the largest in North America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-576"><a href="#cite_note-576">[574]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Port_Authority_Bus_Terminal" title="Port Authority Bus Terminal">Port Authority Bus Terminal</a>, the main <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Intercity_bus" title="Intercity bus">intercity bus</a> terminal of the city, serves 7,000 buses and 200,000 commuters daily, making it the busiest bus station in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PABT_575-1"><a href="#cite_note-PABT-575">[573]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Air">Air</span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Aviation_in_the_New_York_metropolitan_area" title="Aviation in the New York metropolitan area">New York's airspace</a> is the busiest in the United States and one of the world's busiest air transportation corridors. The three busiest airports in the New York metropolitan area include <a href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_International_Airport" title="John F. Kennedy International Airport">John F. Kennedy International Airport</a>, <a href="/wiki/Newark_Liberty_International_Airport" title="Newark Liberty International Airport">Newark Liberty International Airport</a>, and <a href="/wiki/LaGuardia_Airport" title="LaGuardia Airport">LaGuardia Airport</a>; 130.5 million travelers used these three airports in 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-577"><a href="#cite_note-577">[575]</a></sup> JFK and Newark Liberty were the <a href="/wiki/List_of_the_busiest_airports_in_the_United_States#10_busiest_US_airports_by_international_passenger_traffic_(2012)" title="List of the busiest airports in the United States">busiest and fourth busiest U.S. gateways</a> for international air passengers, respectively, in 2012; as of 2011<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=New_York_City&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, JFK was the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World%27s_busiest_airports_by_international_passenger_traffic" title="World's busiest airports by international passenger traffic">busiest airport for international passengers</a> in North America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-578"><a href="#cite_note-578">[576]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:JFK_Plane_Queue.jpg"><img alt="Five jumbo airplanes wait in a line on a runway next to a small body of water. Behind them in the distance is the airport and control tower." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2414" data-file-width="3620" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/JFK_Plane_Queue.jpg/220px-JFK_Plane_Queue.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/JFK_Plane_Queue.jpg/330px-JFK_Plane_Queue.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/JFK_Plane_Queue.jpg/440px-JFK_Plane_Queue.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:JFK_Plane_Queue.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_International_Airport" title="John F. Kennedy International Airport">John F. Kennedy Airport</a> in Queens, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Busiest_airports_in_the_United_States_by_international_passenger_traffic" title="Busiest airports in the United States by international passenger traffic">busiest international air passenger gateway</a> to the United States</div></div></div>
<p>Plans have advanced to expand passenger volume at a fourth airport, <a href="/wiki/Stewart_International_Airport" title="Stewart International Airport">Stewart International Airport</a> near <a href="/wiki/Newburgh,_New_York" title="Newburgh, New York">Newburgh, New York</a>, by the <a href="/wiki/Port_Authority_of_New_York_and_New_Jersey" title="Port Authority of New York and New Jersey">Port Authority of New York and New Jersey</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-579"><a href="#cite_note-579">[577]</a></sup> Plans were announced in July 2015 to entirely rebuild LaGuardia Airport in a multibillion-dollar project to replace its aging facilities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-580"><a href="#cite_note-580">[578]</a></sup> Other commercial airports in or serving the <a href="/wiki/New_York_metropolitan_area" title="New York metropolitan area">New York metropolitan area</a> include <a href="/wiki/Long_Island_MacArthur_Airport" title="Long Island MacArthur Airport">Long Island MacArthur Airport</a>, <a href="/wiki/Trenton%E2%80%93Mercer_Airport" title="Trenton–Mercer Airport">Trenton–Mercer Airport</a> and <a href="/wiki/Westchester_County_Airport" title="Westchester County Airport">Westchester County Airport</a>. The primary general aviation airport serving the area is <a href="/wiki/Teterboro_Airport" title="Teterboro Airport">Teterboro Airport</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ferries">Ferries</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Spirit_of_America_-_Staten_Island_Ferry.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1009" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="139" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Spirit_of_America_-_Staten_Island_Ferry.jpg/220px-Spirit_of_America_-_Staten_Island_Ferry.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Spirit_of_America_-_Staten_Island_Ferry.jpg/330px-Spirit_of_America_-_Staten_Island_Ferry.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Spirit_of_America_-_Staten_Island_Ferry.jpg/440px-Spirit_of_America_-_Staten_Island_Ferry.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Spirit_of_America_-_Staten_Island_Ferry.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Staten_Island_Ferry" title="Staten Island Ferry">Staten Island Ferry</a> shuttles <a href="/wiki/Commuting" title="Commuting">commuters</a> between Manhattan and Staten Island.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Staten_Island_Ferry" title="Staten Island Ferry">Staten Island Ferry</a> is the world's busiest <a href="/wiki/Ferry" title="Ferry">ferry route</a>, carrying more than 23 million passengers from July 2015 through June 2016 on the 5.2-mile (8.4 km) route between Staten Island and Lower Manhattan and running 24 hours a day.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-581"><a href="#cite_note-581">[579]</a></sup> Other ferry systems shuttle commuters between Manhattan and other locales within the city and the metropolitan area.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/NYC_Ferry" title="NYC Ferry">NYC Ferry</a>, a <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Economic_Development_Corporation" title="New York City Economic Development Corporation">NYCEDC</a> initiative with routes planned to travel to all five boroughs, was launched in 2017, with <a href="/wiki/Second_grade" title="Second grade">second graders</a> choosing the names of the ferries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-582"><a href="#cite_note-582">[580]</a></sup> Meanwhile, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seastreak_ferry" title="Seastreak ferry">Seastreak ferry</a> announced construction of a 600-passenger high-speed luxury ferry in September 2016, to shuttle riders between the <a href="/wiki/Jersey_Shore" title="Jersey Shore">Jersey Shore</a> and Manhattan, anticipated to start service in 2017; this would be the largest vessel in its class.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-583"><a href="#cite_note-583">[581]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Taxis.2C_vehicles_for_hire.2C_and_trams"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Taxis,_vehicles_for_hire,_and_trams">Taxis, vehicles for hire, and trams</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Taxicabs_of_New_York_City" title="Taxicabs of New York City">Taxicabs of New York City</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:NYC_Toyota_Prius_v.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1080" data-file-width="2385" decoding="async" height="100" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/NYC_Toyota_Prius_v.jpg/220px-NYC_Toyota_Prius_v.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/NYC_Toyota_Prius_v.jpg/330px-NYC_Toyota_Prius_v.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/NYC_Toyota_Prius_v.jpg/440px-NYC_Toyota_Prius_v.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:NYC_Toyota_Prius_v.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Yellow medallion taxicabs are widely recognized icons of the city.</div></div></div>
<p>Other features of the city's transportation infrastructure encompass 13,587 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Taxicabs_of_New_York_City" title="Taxicabs of New York City">yellow taxicabs</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-584"><a href="#cite_note-584">[582]</a></sup> other <a href="/wiki/Vehicle_for_hire" title="Vehicle for hire">vehicle for hire</a> companies;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-585"><a href="#cite_note-585">[583]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-586"><a href="#cite_note-586">[584]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Roosevelt_Island_Tramway" title="Roosevelt Island Tramway">Roosevelt Island Tramway</a>, an <a href="/wiki/Aerial_tramway" title="Aerial tramway">aerial tramway</a> that transports commuters between <a href="/wiki/Roosevelt_Island" title="Roosevelt Island">Roosevelt Island</a> and Manhattan Island.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Streets_and_highways">Streets and highways</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Storm_at_Manhattan.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Storm_at_Manhattan.jpg/220px-Storm_at_Manhattan.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Storm_at_Manhattan.jpg/330px-Storm_at_Manhattan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Storm_at_Manhattan.jpg/440px-Storm_at_Manhattan.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Storm_at_Manhattan.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>8th Avenue, looking northward ("uptown"). Most streets and avenues in <a href="/wiki/Commissioners%27_Plan_of_1811" title="Commissioners' Plan of 1811">Manhattan's grid plan</a> incorporate a <a href="/wiki/One-way_traffic" title="One-way traffic">one-way traffic</a> configuration.</div></div></div>
<p>Despite New York's heavy reliance on its vast public transit system, streets are a defining feature of the city. The <a href="/wiki/Commissioners%27_Plan_of_1811" title="Commissioners' Plan of 1811">Commissioners' Plan of 1811</a> greatly influenced the city's physical development. Several of the city's streets and avenues, including <a href="/wiki/Broadway_(Manhattan)" title="Broadway (Manhattan)">Broadway</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-587"><a href="#cite_note-587">[585]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Wall_Street" title="Wall Street">Wall Street</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-588"><a href="#cite_note-588">[586]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Madison_Avenue_(Manhattan)" title="Madison Avenue (Manhattan)">Madison Avenue</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MadisonAveMetonym_357-1"><a href="#cite_note-MadisonAveMetonym-357">[355]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Seventh_Avenue_(Manhattan)" title="Seventh Avenue (Manhattan)">Seventh Avenue</a> are also used as <a href="/wiki/Metonymy" title="Metonymy">metonyms</a> for national industries there: the theater, finance, advertising, and fashion organizations, respectively.
</p><p>New York City also has an extensive web of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Freeway" title="Freeway">freeways</a> and <a href="/wiki/Parkway" title="Parkway">parkways</a>, which link the city's boroughs to each other and to <a href="/wiki/North_Jersey" title="North Jersey">North Jersey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Westchester_County,_New_York" title="Westchester County, New York">Westchester County</a>, <a href="/wiki/Long_Island" title="Long Island">Long Island</a>, and southwestern <a href="/wiki/Connecticut" title="Connecticut">Connecticut</a> through various <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bridges_and_tunnels_in_New_York_City" title="Bridges and tunnels in New York City">bridges and tunnels</a>. Because these highways serve millions of outer borough and suburban residents who <a href="/wiki/Commuting" title="Commuting">commute</a> into Manhattan, it is quite common for motorists to be stranded for hours in <a href="/wiki/Traffic_congestion" title="Traffic congestion">traffic congestion</a> that are a daily occurrence, particularly during <a href="/wiki/Rush_hour" title="Rush hour">rush hour</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-589"><a href="#cite_note-589">[587]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-590"><a href="#cite_note-590">[588]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Congestion_pricing_in_New_York_City" title="Congestion pricing in New York City">Congestion pricing in New York City</a> will go into effect in 2022 at the earliest.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-591"><a href="#cite_note-591">[589]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-592"><a href="#cite_note-592">[590]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-593"><a href="#cite_note-593">[591]</a></sup>
</p><p>New York City is also known for its rules regarding turning at red lights. Unlike the rest of the United States, New York State prohibits right or left turns on red in cities with a population greater than one million, to reduce traffic collisions and increase pedestrian safety. In New York City, therefore, all turns at red lights are illegal unless a sign permitting such maneuvers is present.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-594"><a href="#cite_note-594">[592]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="River_crossings">River crossings</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:George_Washington_Bridge_from_New_Jersey-edit.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="727" data-file-width="738" decoding="async" height="217" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/George_Washington_Bridge_from_New_Jersey-edit.jpg/220px-George_Washington_Bridge_from_New_Jersey-edit.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/George_Washington_Bridge_from_New_Jersey-edit.jpg/330px-George_Washington_Bridge_from_New_Jersey-edit.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/George_Washington_Bridge_from_New_Jersey-edit.jpg/440px-George_Washington_Bridge_from_New_Jersey-edit.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:George_Washington_Bridge_from_New_Jersey-edit.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/George_Washington_Bridge" title="George Washington Bridge">George Washington Bridge</a>, connecting <a href="/wiki/Upper_Manhattan" title="Upper Manhattan">Upper Manhattan</a> (background) from <a href="/wiki/Fort_Lee,_New_Jersey" title="Fort Lee, New Jersey">Fort Lee, New Jersey</a> across the <a href="/wiki/Hudson_River" title="Hudson River">Hudson River</a>, is the world's busiest motor vehicle bridge.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gwbridge_595-0"><a href="#cite_note-gwbridge-595">[593]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gwbridgepainters_596-0"><a href="#cite_note-gwbridgepainters-596">[594]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>New York City is located on one of the world's largest natural harbors,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-597"><a href="#cite_note-597">[595]</a></sup> and the boroughs of Manhattan and Staten Island are primarily coterminous with islands of the same names, while Queens and Brooklyn are located at the west end of the larger Long Island, and the Bronx is located on New York State's mainland. This situation of boroughs separated by water led to the development of an extensive infrastructure of bridges and tunnels.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/George_Washington_Bridge" title="George Washington Bridge">George Washington Bridge</a> is the world's busiest motor vehicle bridge,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gwbridge_595-1"><a href="#cite_note-gwbridge-595">[593]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gwbridgepainters_596-1"><a href="#cite_note-gwbridgepainters-596">[594]</a></sup> connecting Manhattan to <a href="/wiki/Bergen_County,_New_Jersey" title="Bergen County, New Jersey">Bergen County, New Jersey</a>. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Verrazano-Narrows_Bridge" title="Verrazano-Narrows Bridge">Verrazano-Narrows Bridge</a> is the longest <a href="/wiki/Suspension_bridge" title="Suspension bridge">suspension bridge</a> in the Americas and one of the world's longest.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-infoplease.com_598-0"><a href="#cite_note-infoplease.com-598">[596]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Verrazano-Narrows_Bridge_599-0"><a href="#cite_note-Verrazano-Narrows_Bridge-599">[597]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn_Bridge" title="Brooklyn Bridge">Brooklyn Bridge</a> is an icon of the city itself. The towers of the Brooklyn Bridge are built of <a href="/wiki/Limestone" title="Limestone">limestone</a>, <a href="/wiki/Granite" title="Granite">granite</a>, and Rosendale cement, and their architectural style is neo-Gothic, with characteristic pointed arches above the passageways through the stone towers. This bridge was also the longest suspension bridge in the world from its opening until 1903, and is the first steel-wire suspension bridge. The <a href="/wiki/Queensboro_Bridge" title="Queensboro Bridge">Queensboro Bridge</a> is an important piece of <a href="/wiki/Cantilever_bridge" title="Cantilever bridge">cantilever architecture</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Manhattan_Bridge" title="Manhattan Bridge">Manhattan Bridge</a>, opened in 1909, is considered to be the forerunner of modern <a href="/wiki/Suspension_bridge" title="Suspension bridge">suspension bridges</a>, and its design served as the model for many of the long-span suspension bridges around the world; the Manhattan Bridge, <a href="/wiki/Throgs_Neck_Bridge" title="Throgs Neck Bridge">Throgs Neck Bridge</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Triborough_Bridge" title="Triborough Bridge">Triborough Bridge</a>, and Verrazano-Narrows Bridge are all examples of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Structural_expressionism" title="Structural expressionism">structural expressionism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-600"><a href="#cite_note-600">[598]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-601"><a href="#cite_note-601">[599]</a></sup>
</p><p>Manhattan Island is linked to New York City's outer boroughs and New Jersey by several tunnels as well. The <a href="/wiki/Lincoln_Tunnel" title="Lincoln Tunnel">Lincoln Tunnel</a>, which carries 120,000 vehicles a day under the Hudson River between New Jersey and Midtown Manhattan, is the busiest vehicular tunnel in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-602"><a href="#cite_note-602">[600]</a></sup> The tunnel was built instead of a bridge to allow unfettered passage of large passenger and <a href="/wiki/Cargo_ship" title="Cargo ship">cargo ships</a> that sailed through New York Harbor and up the Hudson River to Manhattan's piers. The <a href="/wiki/Holland_Tunnel" title="Holland Tunnel">Holland Tunnel</a>, connecting Lower Manhattan to <a href="/wiki/Jersey_City,_New_Jersey" title="Jersey City, New Jersey">Jersey City, New Jersey</a>, was the world's first mechanically ventilated vehicular tunnel when it opened in 1927.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-603"><a href="#cite_note-603">[601]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-604"><a href="#cite_note-604">[602]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Queens-Midtown_Tunnel" title="Queens-Midtown Tunnel">Queens-Midtown Tunnel</a>, built to relieve congestion on the bridges connecting Manhattan with Queens and Brooklyn, was the largest non-federal project in its time when it was completed in 1940.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-605"><a href="#cite_note-605">[603]</a></sup> President <a href="/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt" title="Franklin D. Roosevelt">Franklin D. Roosevelt</a> was the first person to drive through it.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-606"><a href="#cite_note-606">[604]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brooklyn-Battery_Tunnel" title="Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel">Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel</a> (officially known as the Hugh L. Carey Tunnel) runs underneath <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Battery_Park" title="Battery Park">Battery Park</a> and connects the <a href="/wiki/Financial_District,_Manhattan" title="Financial District, Manhattan">Financial District</a> at the southern tip of Manhattan to <a href="/wiki/Red_Hook,_Brooklyn" title="Red Hook, Brooklyn">Red Hook</a> in Brooklyn.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cycling_network">Cycling network</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Cycling_in_New_York_City" title="Cycling in New York City">Cycling in New York City</a></div>
<p>Cycling in New York City is associated with mixed cycling conditions that include urban density, relatively flat terrain, congested roadways with "stop-and-go" traffic, and many pedestrians. The city's large cycling population includes <a href="/wiki/Utility_cycling" title="Utility cycling">utility cyclists</a>, such as delivery and messenger services; <a href="/wiki/Cycling_club" title="Cycling club">cycling clubs</a> for recreational cyclists; and increasingly <a href="/wiki/Bicycle_commuting" title="Bicycle commuting">commuters</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-607"><a href="#cite_note-607">[605]</a></sup> Cycling is increasingly popular in New York City; in 2017 there were approximately 450,000 daily bike trips, compared with 170,000 daily bike trips in 2005.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hu_608-0"><a href="#cite_note-hu-608">[606]</a></sup> As of 2017<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=New_York_City&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, New York City had 1,333 miles (2,145 km) of bike lanes, compared to 513 miles (826 km) of bike lanes in 2006.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hu_608-1"><a href="#cite_note-hu-608">[606]</a></sup> As of 2019, there are 126 miles (203 km) of segregated or "protected" bike lanes citywide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-609"><a href="#cite_note-609">[607]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="People">People</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/List_of_people_from_New_York_City" title="List of people from New York City">List of people from New York City</a></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Global_outreach">Global outreach</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_sister_cities_of_New_York_City" title="List of sister cities of New York City">List of sister cities of New York City</a></div>
<p>In 2006, the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Twin_towns_and_sister_cities" title="Twin towns and sister cities">Sister City</a> Program of the City of New York, Inc.</i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-610"><a href="#cite_note-610">[608]</a></sup> was restructured and renamed <i>New York City Global Partners</i>. Through this program, New York City has expanded its international outreach to a network of cities worldwide, promoting the exchange of ideas and <a href="/wiki/Innovation" title="Innovation">innovation</a> between their citizenry and policymakers. New York's <i>historic sister cities</i> are denoted below by the year they joined New York City's partnership network.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GlobalOutreach_611-0"><a href="#cite_note-GlobalOutreach-611">[609]</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" width="100%">
<tbody><tr>
<th>New York City Global Partners network
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><b>Africa</b><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r998391716">.mw-parser-output .div-col{margin-top:0.3em;column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .div-col-small{font-size:90%}.mw-parser-output .div-col-rules{column-rule:1px solid #aaa}.mw-parser-output .div-col dl,.mw-parser-output .div-col ol,.mw-parser-output .div-col ul{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .div-col li,.mw-parser-output .div-col dd{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}</style><div class="div-col div-col-small div-col-rules" style="column-width: 20em;">

<li><a href="/wiki/Cape_Town" title="Cape Town">Cape Town</a>, South Africa</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Lagos" title="Lagos">Lagos</a>, Nigeria</li>

</div><b>Asia</b>
<b>(<i>East</i>)</b><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r998391716" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="div-col div-col-small div-col-rules" style="column-width: 20em;">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Bangkok" title="Bangkok">Bangkok</a>, Thailand</li>

<li><a href="/wiki/Changwon" title="Changwon">Changwon</a>, South Korea</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Chongqing" title="Chongqing">Chongqing</a>, China<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-612"><a href="#cite_note-612">[610]</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Guangzhou" title="Guangzhou">Guangzhou</a>, China</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ho_Chi_Minh_City" title="Ho Chi Minh City">Ho Chi Minh City</a>, Vietnam</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a>, China</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Jakarta" title="Jakarta">Jakarta</a>, Indonesia</li>

<li><a href="/wiki/Manila" title="Manila">Manila</a>, Philippines</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Seoul" title="Seoul">Seoul</a>, South Korea</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Shanghai" title="Shanghai">Shanghai</a>, China</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Shenyang" title="Shenyang">Shenyang</a>, China</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Singapore" title="Singapore">Singapore</a>, Singapore</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Taipei" title="Taipei">Taipei</a>, Taiwan</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Tokyo" title="Tokyo">Tokyo</a>, Japan (1960)</li></ul>
</div><b>(<i>South</i>)</b><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r998391716" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="div-col div-col-small div-col-rules" style="column-width: 20em;">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Bangalore" title="Bangalore">Bangalore</a>, India</li>

<li><a href="/wiki/Karachi" title="Karachi">Karachi</a>, Pakistan</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Mumbai" title="Mumbai">Mumbai</a>, India</li></ul>
</div><b>(<i>West</i>)</b><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r998391716" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="div-col div-col-small div-col-rules" style="column-width: 20em;">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Dubai" title="Dubai">Dubai</a>, United Arab Emirates</li>

</div><b>Australia</b><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r998391716" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="div-col div-col-small div-col-rules" style="column-width: 20em;">

</div><b>Europe</b>
<b>(<i>Central</i>)</b><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r998391716" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="div-col div-col-small div-col-rules" style="column-width: 20em;">

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist reflist-lower-alpha">
<div class="mw-references-wrap"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-213"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-213">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Mean monthly maxima and minima (i.e. the expected highest and lowest temperature readings at any point during the year or given month) calculated based on data at said location from 1991 to 2020.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-215"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-215">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Official weather observations for Central Park were conducted at the Arsenal at Fifth Avenue and 64th Street from 1869 to 1919, and at Belvedere Castle since 1919.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214"><a href="#cite_note-214">[213]</a></sup></span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>

<li id="cite_note-autogenerated3-34"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-autogenerated3_34-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://www.nps.gov/diversity/stonewall.htm" rel="nofollow">"Workforce Diversity The Stonewall Inn, National Historic Landmark National Register Number: 99000562"</a>. <li id="cite_note-Lankevich2002-49"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Lankevich2002_49-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFLankevich2002">Lankevich, George J. </li>
<li id="cite_note-hudsonnni-50"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-hudsonnni_50-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-hudsonnni_50-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://www.newnetherlandinstitute.org/history-and-heritage/digital-exhibitions/a-tour-of-new-netherland/hudson-river/" rel="nofollow">"The Hudson River"</a>. <a href="/wiki/New_Netherland_Institute" title="New Netherland Institute">New Netherland Institute</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-59"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-59">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://www.s4ulanguages.com/laet2.html" rel="nofollow">"Pieter Schaghen Letter"</a>. <i>S4ulanguages.com</i>. 1626<span class="reference-accessdate">. It is 11,000 morgens in size ...)</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=S4ulanguages.com&amp;rft.atitle=Pieter+Schaghen+Letter&amp;rft.date=1626&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.s4ulanguages.com%2Flaet2.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANew+York+City"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-nyhsstuyvesant-67"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-nyhsstuyvesant_67-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-nyhsstuyvesant_67-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20160624011523/http://www.nyhistory.org/peter-stuyvesant" rel="nofollow">"Peter Stuyvesant"</a>. <a href="/wiki/New-York_Historical_Society" title="New-York Historical Society">New-York Historical Society</a>. </li>
<li id="cite_note-nnistuyvesant-68"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-nnistuyvesant_68-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-nnistuyvesant_68-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://www.newnetherlandinstitute.org/history-and-heritage/dutch_americans/peter-stuyvesant/" rel="nofollow">"Peter Stuyvesant"</a>. <a href="/wiki/New_Netherland_Institute" title="New Netherland Institute">New Netherland Institute</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-115"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-115">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://www.demographia.com/db-nyuza1800.htm" rel="nofollow">"New York Urbanized Area: Population &amp; Density from 1800 (Provisional)"</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Demographia" title="Demographia">Demographia</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. </li>

</li>
<li id="cite_note-Dieterle2017-131"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Dieterle2017_131-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFDieterle2017">Dieterle, David A. </li>

<li id="cite_note-Greenspan2013-133"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Greenspan2013_133-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFGreenspan2013">Greenspan, Elizabeth (2013). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=DMHzmpTK5rYC&amp;pg=PA152" rel="nofollow"><i>Battle for Ground Zero: Inside the Political Struggle to Rebuild the World Trade Center</i></a>. <a href="/wiki/St._Martin%27s_Press" title="St. Martin's Press">St. Martin's Press</a>/<a href="/wiki/Harvard_University" title="Harvard University">Harvard University</a>. p. 152. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-137-36547-7" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-137-36547-7"><bdi>978-1-137-36547-7</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Battle+for+Ground+Zero%3A+Inside+the+Political+Struggle+to+Rebuild+the+World+Trade+Center&amp;rft.pages=152&amp;rft.pub=St.+Martin%27s+Press%2FHarvard+University&amp;rft.date=2013&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-137-36547-7&amp;rft.aulast=Greenspan&amp;rft.aufirst=Elizabeth&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DDMHzmpTK5rYC%26pg%3DPA152&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANew+York+City"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-134"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-134">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20200103164156/https://old.panynj.gov/wtcprogress/transportation-hub.html" rel="nofollow">"World Trade Center Transportation Hub"</a>. <a href="/wiki/Port_Authority_of_New_York_and_New_Jersey" title="Port Authority of New York and New Jersey">Port Authority of New York and New Jersey</a>. Archived from <a class="external text" href="http://www.panynj.gov/wtcprogress/transportation-hub.html" rel="nofollow">the original</a> on January 3, 2020<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">February 9,</span> 2017</span>. <q>The state-of-the-art World Trade Center Transportation Hub, completed in 2016, serves 250,000 Port Authority Trans-Hudson (PATH) daily commuters and millions of annual visitors from around the world. At approximately 800,000 square feet, the Hub, designed by internationally acclaimed architect Santiago Calatrava, is the third largest transportation center in New York City.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=World+Trade+Center+Transportation+Hub&amp;rft.pub=Port+Authority+of+New+York+and+New+Jersey&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.panynj.gov%2Fwtcprogress%2Ftransportation-hub.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANew+York+City"></span></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-137"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-137">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://skyscraperpage.com/cities/?buildingID=7788" rel="nofollow">"One World Trade Center"</a>. <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/SkyscraperPage.com" title="SkyscraperPage.com">SkyscraperPage.com</a></i>. Skyscraper Source Media<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">February 9,</span> 2017</span>. <q>The roof height is the same as original One World Trade Center. The building is topped out by a 124-meter (408-foot) spire. So the tower rises 1,776 feet (541-meter) which marks the year of the American declaration of Independence.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=SkyscraperPage.com&amp;rft.atitle=One+World+Trade+Center&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fskyscraperpage.com%2Fcities%2F%3FbuildingID%3D7788&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANew+York+City"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-140"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-140">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFNocera2012"><a href="/wiki/Joe_Nocera" title="Joe Nocera">Nocera, Joe</a> (September 14, 2012). <a class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/15/opinion/nocera-two-days-in-september.html" rel="nofollow">"Two Days in September"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">May 6,</span> 2017</span>. <q>On the left, that anger led, a year ago, to the rise of the Occupy Wall Street movement. Thus, Anniversary No. 2: Sept. 17, 2011, was the date Occupy Wall Street took over Zuccotti Park in Lower Manhattan, which soon led to similar actions in cities across the country. The movement's primary issue was income inequality—"We are the 99 percent", they used to chant.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=The+New+York+Times&amp;rft.atitle=Two+Days+in+September&amp;rft.date=2012-09-14&amp;rft.aulast=Nocera&amp;rft.aufirst=Joe&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2012%2F09%2F15%2Fopinion%2Fnocera-two-days-in-september.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANew+York+City"></span></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-145"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-145">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20170604154033/http://life.bio.sunysb.edu/marinebio/fc.1.estuaries.html" rel="nofollow">"The Hudson River Estuary"</a>. <i>Life.bio.sunysb.edu</i>. <a href="/wiki/Stony_Brook_University" title="Stony Brook University">Stony Brook University</a>. <li id="cite_note-nytimes-146"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-nytimes_146-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFBerger2010">Berger, Joseph (July 19, 2010). <a class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2010/07/20/nyregion/20river.html" rel="nofollow">"Reclaimed Jewel Whose Attraction Can Be Perilous"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-160"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-160">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFBarry,_Dan2001">Barry, Dan (October 11, 2001). <a class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2001/10/11/nyregion/nation-challenged-new-york-new-york-carries-but-test-its-grit-has-just-begun.html" rel="nofollow">"A Nation challenged: in New York; New York Carries On, but Test of Its Grit Has Just Begun"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-161"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-161">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFSorrentino,_Christopher2007">Sorrentino, Christopher (September 16, 2007). <a class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/16/nyregion/thecity/16toug.html" rel="nofollow">"When He Was Seventeen"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-162"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-162">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFImmerso2002">Immerso, Michael (2002). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=i4POVzmwY9cC" rel="nofollow"><i>Coney Island: The People's Playground</i></a>. <a href="/wiki/Rutgers_University_Press" title="Rutgers University Press">Rutgers University Press</a>. p. 3. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8135-3138-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8135-3138-0"><bdi>978-0-8135-3138-0</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Coney+Island%3A+The+People%27s+Playground&amp;rft.pages=3&amp;rft.pub=Rutgers+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2002&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-8135-3138-0&amp;rft.aulast=Immerso&amp;rft.aufirst=Michael&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Di4POVzmwY9cC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANew+York+City"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-163"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-163">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFHughes2016">Hughes, C.J. <li id="cite_note-178"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-178">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20121106210644/http://www.emporis.com/statistics/skyline-ranking" rel="nofollow">Skyline Ranking</a>, <a href="/wiki/Emporis" title="Emporis">Emporis</a>. <li id="cite_note-179"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-179">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20170211080412/http://rew-online.com/2016/06/15/alchemy-borrows-220m-for-woolworth-conversion/" rel="nofollow">"Alchemy borrows $220M for Woolworth conversion"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Real_Estate_Weekly" title="Real Estate Weekly">Real Estate Weekly</a></i>. June 15, 2016. Archived from <a class="external text" href="http://rew-online.com/2016/06/15/alchemy-borrows-220m-for-woolworth-conversion/" rel="nofollow">the original</a> on February 11, 2017<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">February 9,</span> 2017</span>. <q>The neo-gothic Woolworth Building was commissioned by Frank W. Woolworth in 1910 as his eponymous company's new headquarters and designed by renowned architect Cass Gilbert. The building was completed in 1913 and was for 17 years the tallest building in the world.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Real+Estate+Weekly&amp;rft.atitle=Alchemy+borrows+%24220M+for+Woolworth+conversion&amp;rft.date=2016-06-15&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Frew-online.com%2F2016%2F06%2F15%2Falchemy-borrows-220m-for-woolworth-conversion%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANew+York+City"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-180"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-180">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFFischler1998">Fischler, Raphael (1998). <a class="external text" href="https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/01944369808975974" rel="nofollow">"The Metropolitan Dimension of Early Zoning: Revisiting the 1916 New York City Ordinance"</a>. <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Journal_of_the_American_Planning_Association" title="Journal of the American Planning Association">Journal of the American Planning Association</a></i>. <b>64</b> (2): 170–188. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1080%2F01944369808975974" rel="nofollow">10.1080/01944369808975974</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+American+Planning+Association&amp;rft.atitle=The+Metropolitan+Dimension+of+Early+Zoning%3A+Revisiting+the+1916+New+York+City+Ordinance&amp;rft.volume=64&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.pages=170-188&amp;rft.date=1998&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1080%2F01944369808975974&amp;rft.aulast=Fischler&amp;rft.aufirst=Raphael&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.tandfonline.com%2Fdoi%2Fabs%2F10.1080%2F01944369808975974&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANew+York+City"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-195"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-195">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://www.fao.org/docrep/004/y1997e/y1997e1g.htm" rel="nofollow">"Chapter 47. <li id="cite_note-227"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-227">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://www.centralpark.com/things-to-do/attractions/reservoir/" rel="nofollow">"The Reservoir"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Central_Park" title="Central Park">CentralPark.com</a></i>. <li id="cite_note-228"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-228">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFFoderaro2012">Foderaro, Lisa W. <li id="cite_note-230"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-230">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFFoderaro2013">Foderaro, Lisa W. (May 31, 2013). <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130601042251/https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/01/nyregion/surveying-effort-alters-sizes-of-some-new-york-parks.html" rel="nofollow">"How Big Is That Park? City Now Has the Answer"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i>. Archived from <a class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/01/nyregion/surveying-effort-alters-sizes-of-some-new-york-parks.html" rel="nofollow">the original</a> on June 1, 2013<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">February 9,</span> 2017</span>. <q>But the biggest loser was clearly Flushing Meadows. Previously the third-largest park in the city, it dropped to fourth place after the new analysis put its actual acreage at 897 (897.62 to be precise), down from 1,255 acres.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+New+York+Times&amp;rft.atitle=How+Big+Is+That+Park%3F+City+Now+Has+the+Answer&amp;rft.date=2013-05-31&amp;rft.aulast=Foderaro&amp;rft.aufirst=Lisa+W.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2013%2F06%2F01%2Fnyregion%2Fsurveying-effort-alters-sizes-of-some-new-york-parks.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANew+York+City"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-231"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-231">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">[Flushing Meadows Corona Park World's Fair Legacy; Celebrating the 50th &amp; 75th Anniversaries of the 1939 &amp; 1964 Fairs], <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Department_of_Parks_and_Recreation" title="New York City Department of Parks and Recreation">New York City Department of Parks and Recreation</a>. Retrieved February 9, 2017.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-232"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-232">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="https://www.nycgovparks.org/park-features/fmcp/usta-ntc-strategic-vision-project" rel="nofollow">National Tennis Center Strategic Vision Project</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Department_of_Parks_and_Recreation" title="New York City Department of Parks and Recreation">New York City Department of Parks and Recreation</a>. Retrieved February 9, 2017. "The 42-acre NTC is located within Flushing Meadows Corona Park on parkland leased by NYC Parks to USTA and is one of the world's largest public recreational tennis facilities. For 11 months of the year, NTC facilities are open to the public for indoor and outdoor tennis. The NTC is also host to the U.S. Open, one of the sport's four Grand Slam championship tennis tournaments."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-233"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-233">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">via <a href="/wiki/Associated_Press" title="Associated Press">Associated Press</a>. <a class="external text" href="https://www.nbcnews.com/id/25479453/ns/travel-destination_travel/t/ladies-gentlemen-bronx-blooming/" rel="nofollow">"Ladies and gentlemen, the Bronx is blooming!"</a>, <a href="/wiki/NBC_News" title="NBC News">NBC News</a>, July 2, 2008. Retrieved February 9, 2017. "Despite its urban image, the Bronx has 7,000 acres of park land, about 25 percent of its total area. In addition to Yankee Stadium and the Bronx Zoo, the borough's green spaces include the New York Botanical Garden; a 19th-century garden overlooking the Hudson River called Wave Hill; and Van Cortlandt and Pelham Bay parks, where you can bird-watch, play golf and ride horses."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-234"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-234">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="https://www.nycgovparks.org/parks/conference-house-park/highlights/10408" rel="nofollow">Conference House Park</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Department_of_Parks_and_Recreation" title="New York City Department of Parks and Recreation">New York City Department of Parks and Recreation</a>. Retrieved February 9, 2017. "On September 11, 1776, this house was the site of a conference between British Lord Admiral Richard Howe and Founding Fathers Benjamin Franklin, John Adams, and Edward Rutledge. The talks occurred just two months after the Declaration of Independence had been signed. With the British controlling New York City, Long Island, and Staten Island, the Americans seemed headed for defeat. Lord Howe offered to end the conflict peacefully if the American colonies would return to British control, but the Americans refused to give up their struggle for independence."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-235"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-235">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFJacobsonHarrisTaylorAnderson1980">Jacobson, Jerome; Harris, Mary; Taylor, James V.; Anderson, Albert J.; Ritchie, William A.; Funk, Robert E. (1980). <a class="external text" href="http://core.tdar.org/document/159627/burial-ridge-tottenville-staten-island-n-y-archaeology-at-new-york-citys-largest-prehistoric-cemetery" rel="nofollow"><i>Burial Ridge, Tottenville, Staten Island, N.Y.</i></a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Staten_Island_Institute_of_Arts_%26_Sciences" title="Staten Island Institute of Arts &amp; Sciences">Staten Island Institute of Arts &amp; Sciences</a>, 1980, at The Digital Archaeological Record<span class="reference-accessdate">. </li>
<li id="cite_note-236"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-236">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20110902235300/http://www.nps.gov/nagpra/documents/BASES.PDF" rel="nofollow">"Military Bases in the Continental United States"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nps.gov" title="Nps.gov">Nps.gov</a>. <li id="cite_note-237"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-237">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFJackson2010">Jackson, Kenneth T., ed. (2010). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=lI5ERUmHf3YC&amp;q=encyclopedia+of+new+york" rel="nofollow"><i>The History of New York City, 2nd Edition</i></a>. </li>
<li id="cite_note-EncNYC-238"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-EncNYC_238-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-EncNYC_238-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><i><a href="/wiki/The_Encyclopedia_of_New_York_City" title="The Encyclopedia of New York City">The Encyclopedia of New York City</a></i>, ed. Kenneth T. Jackson (Yale 1995, <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-300-05536-6" title="Special:BookSources/0-300-05536-6">0-300-05536-6</a>), p. 923, citing "U.S. Department of Commerce, Bureau of the Census, Census of Population 1960 (vol. 1, part A, table 28), 1970, 1980, 1990". After annexing part of the Bronx in 1874, the population of the then-New York City was 1,206,299 in 1880 and 1,515,301 in 1890, <a href="/wiki/Yale_University_Press" title="Yale University Press">Yale University Press</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-DecennialCensus-239"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-DecennialCensus_239-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.census.gov/programs-surveys/decennial-census.html" rel="nofollow">"Decennial Census of Population and Housing"</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Census.gov" title="Census.gov">Census.gov</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-pop-249"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-pop_249-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-pop_249-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-pop_249-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-pop_249-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20120812191959/http://www.census.gov/population/www/documentation/twps0076/twps0076.html" rel="nofollow">"Race and Hispanic Origin for Selected Cities and Other Places: Earliest Census to 1990"</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._Census_Bureau" title="U.S. Census Bureau">U.S. Census Bureau</a>. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">November 7,</span> 2021</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Race+and+Hispanic+Origin+for+Selected+Cities+and+Other+Places%3A+Earliest+Census+to+1990&amp;rft.pub=U.S.+Census+Bureau&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.census.gov%2Fpopulation%2Fwww%2Fdocumentation%2Ftwps0076%2Ftwps0076.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANew+York+City"></span></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-264"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-264">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://data.census.gov/cedsci/table?q=new%20york%20city&amp;tid=DECENNIALPL2020.P2" rel="nofollow">"2020 Decennial Census"</a>. <li id="cite_note-CityDiversity-267"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-CityDiversity_267-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CityDiversity_267-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFSemple2013">Semple, Kirk (June 8, 2013). <a class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2013/06/09/nyregion/new-york-citys-newest-immigrant-enclaves.html?pagewanted=all" rel="nofollow">"City's Newest Immigrant Enclaves, From Little Guyana to Meokjagolmok"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-NYC_immigration-268"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-NYC_immigration_268-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="https://www1.nyc.gov/assets/planning/download/pdf/data-maps/nyc-population/nny2013/nny_2013.pdf" rel="nofollow"><i>The Newest New Yorkers: 2013</i></a>, <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Department_of_City_Planning" title="New York City Department of City Planning">New York City Department of City Planning</a>, December 2013. Retrieved February 9, 2017. "The immigrant share of the population has also doubled since 1965, to 37 percent. With foreign-born mothers accounting for 51 percent of all births, approximately 6-in-10 New Yorkers are either immigrants or the children of immigrants."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-269"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-269">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFSemple2013">Semple, Kirk (December 18, 2013). <a class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/19/nyregion/chinese-diaspora-transforms-new-yorks-immigrant-population-report-finds.html" rel="nofollow">"Immigration Remakes and Sustains City, a Report Concludes"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-270"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-270">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFGoldstein2013">Goldstein, Joseph (November 28, 2013). <a class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/29/nyregion/bangladeshis-build-careers-in-new-york-traffic.html?hpw&amp;rref=nyregion&amp;_r=0" rel="nofollow">"Bangladeshis Build Careers in New York Traffic"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-271"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-271">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFSemple2011">Semple, Kirk (June 23, 2011). <a class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/24/nyregion/asian-new-yorkers-asian-new-yorkers-seek-power-to-match-surging-numbers.html" rel="nofollow">"Asian New Yorkers Seek Power to Match Numbers"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">July 5,</span> 2011</span>. <q>Asians, a group more commonly associated with the West Coast, are surging in New York, where they have long been eclipsed in the city's kaleidoscopic racial and ethnic mix. For the first time, according to census figures released in the spring, their numbers have topped one million—nearly one in eight New Yorkers—which is more than the Asian population in the cities of San Francisco and Los Angeles combined.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+New+York+Times&amp;rft.atitle=Asian+New+Yorkers+Seek+Power+to+Match+Numbers&amp;rft.date=2011-06-23&amp;rft.aulast=Semple&amp;rft.aufirst=Kirk&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2011%2F06%2F24%2Fnyregion%2Fasian-new-yorkers-asian-new-yorkers-seek-power-to-match-surging-numbers.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANew+York+City"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-272"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-272">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://www.ameredia.com/resources/demographics/asian_american.html" rel="nofollow">"Asian American Statistics"</a>. <li id="cite_note-ManhattanChinatownLargestConcentrationChineseWesternHemisphere-273"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-ManhattanChinatownLargestConcentrationChineseWesternHemisphere_273-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.introducingnewyork.com/chinatown" rel="nofollow">"Chinatown New York"</a>. Civitatis New York<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">August 28,</span> 2022</span>. <q>As its name suggests, Chinatown is where the largest population of Chinese people live in the Western Hemisphere.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Chinatown+New+York&amp;rft.pub=Civitatis+New+York&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.introducingnewyork.com%2Fchinatown&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANew+York+City"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-fact-sheet-274"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-fact-sheet_274-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">* <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://www.explorechinatown.com/PDF/FactSheet.pdf" rel="nofollow">"Chinatown New York City Fact Sheet"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. www.explorechinatown.com<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-Immigrants2014est-277"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Immigrants2014est_277-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Immigrants2014est_277-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Immigrants2014est_277-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20160804064953/https://www.dhs.gov/sites/default/files/publications/immsuptable2d_5.xls" rel="nofollow">"Supplemental Table 2. <li id="cite_note-HispanicLatino-293"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-HispanicLatino_293-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-HispanicLatino_293-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://archive.today/20200212213707/http://factfinder.census.gov/faces/tableservices/jsf/pages/productview.xhtml?pid=DEC_10_SF1_QTP10&amp;prodType=table" rel="nofollow">"Hispanic or Latino by Type: 2010"</a>. <a href="/wiki/United_States_Census_Bureau" title="United States Census Bureau">United States Census Bureau</a>. <li id="cite_note-LittleAustraliaNYC-304"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-LittleAustraliaNYC_304-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFBusuttil2016">Busuttil, Shaun (November 3, 2016). <a class="external text" href="https://karryon.com.au/lifestyle/travel-inspiration/crikey-welcome-to-little-australia-in-new-york-city/" rel="nofollow">"G-day! Welcome to Little Australia in New York City"</a>. KarryOn<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">May 23,</span> 2019</span>. <q>In Little Australia, Australian-owned cafes are popping up all over the place (such as Two Hands), joining other Australian-owned businesses (such as nightclubs and art galleries) as part of a growing green and gold contingent in NYC. Indeed, walking in this neighbourhood, the odds of your hearing a fellow Aussie ordering a coffee or just kicking back and chatting are high—very high—so much so that if you're keen to meet other Aussies whilst taking your own bite out of the Big Apple, then this is the place to throw that Australian accent around like it's going out of fashion!</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=G-day%21+Welcome+to+Little+Australia+in+New+York+City&amp;rft.pub=KarryOn&amp;rft.date=2016-11-03&amp;rft.aulast=Busuttil&amp;rft.aufirst=Shaun&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fkarryon.com.au%2Flifestyle%2Ftravel-inspiration%2Fcrikey-welcome-to-little-australia-in-new-york-city%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANew+York+City"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-305"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-305">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFMcLogan2017">McLogan, Elle (October 3, 2017). <a class="external text" href="https://newyork.cbslocal.com/2017/10/03/little-australia/" rel="nofollow">"Why Are There So Many Australians in New York?"</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/CBS_Television_Stations" title="CBS Television Stations">CBS Television Stations</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-306"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-306">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFReynolds2018">Reynolds, Emma (July 30, 2018). <a class="external text" href="https://www.news.com.au/lifestyle/food/eat/australias-secret-weapon-is-quietly-changing-new-york/news-story/c9d562e08881824b60ea58d8242f79da" rel="nofollow">"Australia's secret weapon is quietly changing New York"</a>. <a href="/wiki/News.com.au" title="News.com.au">news.com.au</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-307"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-307">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFGunner">Gunner, Siobhan. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20190603030121/https://www.justopenednewyork.com/australian-cafes-taking-nyc-breakfast-scene/" rel="nofollow">"The Australian Cafés Taking Over The NYC Breakfast Scene"</a>. <li id="cite_note-NYCMostDiverseMuslimPopulationWorld-339"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-NYCMostDiverseMuslimPopulationWorld_339-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://globalgates.info/resources-information/muslims-in-metro-new-york-part-2-specific-muslim-group-estimates/" rel="nofollow">"Muslims in Metro New York (Part 2) – Specific Muslim Group Estimates"</a>. <i>Global Gates</i>. <li id="cite_note-NYC_real_estate-381"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-NYC_real_estate_381-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-NYC_real_estate_381-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www1.nyc.gov/assets/finance/downloads/pdf/press_release/fy2017_tentative_assessment_roll.pdf" rel="nofollow">"Department of Finance Publishes Fiscal Year 2017 Tentative Assessment Roll"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Department_of_Finance" title="New York City Department of Finance">New York City Department of Finance</a>. January 15, 2016<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">November 26,</span> 2021</span>. <q>Today, Jacques Jiha, Commissioner for the Department of Finance, announced the publication of the Tentative Property Assessment Roll for fiscal year 2017, which shows the total Market Value for the upcoming year at about $1.072 trillion, an increase of $102.5 billion, or 10.6 percent from the 2016 Fiscal Year.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.atitle=Department+of+Finance+Publishes+Fiscal+Year+2017+Tentative+Assessment+Roll&amp;rft.date=2016-01-15&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww1.nyc.gov%2Fassets%2Ffinance%2Fdownloads%2Fpdf%2Fpress_release%2Ffy2017_tentative_assessment_roll.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANew+York+City"></span></span>
